—Let me make it clear that if the states view were to be accepted it would require them to adopt views in relation to recognition of skills. It would require them to look at a different approach to regional migration, particularly on the part of Victoria.
—The minister should draw his answer to conclusion.

—I will, Mr Speaker. I have one final point to make. One of the points I would make in relation to Victoria is that, while it has being arguing for a 50 per cent increase in skilled migrants to Australia, when it was given the opportunity to fill a mere 200 places within a designated regional migration program where all they would have to do is make the appropriate designations they could not fill one place. I have to say that if you cannot fill 200 places—
—The minister should conclude his reply.
—I don't know how you can argue to fill 50,000 places.
—Here comes Mr Smut again.
—Don't worry, Fishnets. Prime Minister, did you declare your interest or absent yourself—
—At least I'm not smutty.
—Don't lead, Glass Jaw.
—You have not made a serious point for two years.
—I suggest that the honourable member and the Minister for Foreign Affairs stop making exchanges across the bar table and the members of the government should allow—
—What have you got against fishnets?
—He's got nothing against them.
—When you remain silent on both sides, the honourable member for Hotham has the call.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, did you declare your interest or absent yourself when you presided over the October cabinet meeting which gave benefits to a company of which you were still a director?
—As I said before, I had no private personal financial interest in the company. Therefore, I had no interest.
—Guilty as charged.
—The honourable member for Brisbane will remain silent!

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Minister, can you inform the House of the benefits which residents of my electorate and that of my colleague the member for Wide Bay will receive as a result of a grant which is to be made out of the Commonwealth governments regional telecommunications infrastructure fund—Networking the Nation? Minister, can you further advise what other benefits will accrue to regional Australia?

—I thank the member for Hinkler for his question. Indeed, there has been an announcement by my colleague the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts about additional grants under the regional telecommunications infrastructure fund—that $250 million fund—to address the improvements of telecommunication services in regional Australia. Indeed, in your electorate and in the electorate of the member for Wide Bay there are two specific programs. I should draw attention to those.

answer.para: The Wide Bay electorate will receive $680,000-odd for the implementation of the 2020 growth management project, information access. The project will establish a digital network covering some 10 local shires in the Wide Bay and Hinkler electorates providing local call Internet access to all residents. Local councils will be encouraged to use the network to provide public access to the Internet within their localities. Information training and awareness will be a feature of this project. It will take the importance of the Internet right around those two electorates.

Also in the shire in your electorate there will be another $392,000 for the provision of five public access and training centres across a region of 15,000 square kilometres. What needs to be understood is that the distances in this nation need to be combated. We can do that only by successfully improving the communication services. These two projects specifically target in on that particular area and help that immensely.

Honourable members should be aware there are some 93 projects that have already been approved. The amount of $50 million has been expended to address these types of projects. I might draw attention to other projects that have been announced by my colleague today. The amount of $3.2 million in the Northern Territory for an electronic outback project which will involve a roll-out of satellite infrastructure. I cannot over emphasise the importance of satellite infrastructure to the development of linking regional and remote Australia to the rest of the world. It is exceptionally important. Fourteen remote communities will benefit from this project.

Another interesting one is $1.3 million for the women's justice network in south-west Queensland—16 locations for a three-year pilot to assist women needing independent legal advice through video conference sites, training for community workers and connections to the legal aid information database, taking legal aid in a practical way, utilising new technologies, to people who need it in remote Australia. There is also a project in Queensland where some $2.65 million will be expended to establish Internet service provider points. That will cover an area of 28 per cent of Queensland. It covers the electorate of my colleague the Minister for Veterans' Affairs from Roma to Charleville right down to the South Australian border.

Finally, one project that I am particularly pleased to see has been released is a telehealth Tasmanian network—$5.5 million to assist with a network of 50 telehealth facilities to improve health access to health services for regional and remote Tasmania. It takes in the two Bass Strait islands, Flinders and King Island, in the most decentralised state in this nation.

These are the sorts of projects that you people opposed. You opposed these projects to enhance the opportunities for regional and remote dwellers in this nation to connect with the rest of the nation. These are decisions that are about connecting all of Australia to the future. You opposed it. You should be ashamed of it.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, your consistent defence of Senator Parer, who also concealed his interest, has been that we should not show `that Senator Parer made specific representations on behalf of companies in which he had an interest'. Prime Minister, now that we have established that you presided over meetings of cabinet when you were still a director of a company, meetings which directly benefited that company, have you not breached your own code?
—No.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, are you aware of reports in today's media that the government is prepared to establish a framework for redundancy payments for wharfies? Are these reports accurate and how would the government's system differ from that of the Waterfront Industry Reform Authority model?

—I thank the member for Corangamite for his question. I have said repeatedly that in the maritime industry generally there is a significant problem of overmanning, and the more obvious symptoms of that are the fact that there are a lot of rorts and inefficiencies, a lot of idle time and very poor productivity levels. For example, in the blue water segment of the industry there is no question that there is overmanning. I discussed that with the MUA, the representative union, before Christmas and they acknowledged that there is overmanning, and there have been ongoing discussions about how that issue needs to be dealt with. For example, the government has taken a step to withdraw the Australian Maritime Safety Authority from the management of the pool.

answer.para: Similarly, in the stevedoring industry there is no doubt that there is significant overmanning. That is not, of course, acknowledged publicly by the union. But there is no doubt, again from the evidence of the restrictive work practices and the like, that something needs to be done to improve the efficiency of the industry.

I think it is fair to say that the industry generally is unique in respect of the stevedoring aspect. That was really recognised by the previous Labor administration when they set up the Waterfront Industry Reform Authori ty—the WIRA process. In that process a lot of taxpayers' funds were expended—something like $160 million—

talk.start.para: —The honourable member for Grayndler!
—And the end result, as we have demonstrated in this House day after day, is that we did not get the significant reform that we obviously need on the Australian waterfront.
—That is two minutes.
—If it is two minutes, I have two to go. Thank you very much. To have you marking time sitting there, Simon, is about all you are good for, I would have to say.
—Well, at least we have got that from you.
—The honourable minister will direct his remarks through the chair. The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Triviality is his specialty.
—We'll hold you to that!
—The honourable minister will direct his response through chair.

—The Labor Party oversaw the spending of something like $430 million and basically got nothing for it. The last thing I would say is that in this circumstance, obviously, where there is an overmanning situation—
—The honourable member for Grayndler!

—and where the companies take action to address that problem, where there are people leaving the industry, then their entitlement should be fully paid out. I have said that repeatedly—last month, the previous month and all the way back to December. The two differences between our approach, I suppose, and the Labor Party's approach are that our view is that, where there is a cost, that cost should be borne by the industry.
—The honourable member for Grayndler will remain silent.
—As to the mechanism for that, that is a secondary matter, but a cost associated should be met by the industry.
—Boring! Boring!
—The honourable members of the Labor Party will remain silent.
—But it is boring.
—I warn the honourable member for Grayndler.
—And, secondly, we look to the industry for genuine reform and genuine restructuring so that we can finally see for Australia a far more efficient waterfront.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development. Minister, you will recall my question to you on 23 March regarding your government's increase of jet departures over residential areas of Sydney by 300 per cent—and, incidentally, I accept your belated withdrawal and apology in this House two days later.
—The honourable member will direct his question.

—Will the Minister inform the House what is the government's response to the recent British paper in the Journal of Epidemiology and Community Health which found that children who were born and reside near airports and under flight paths are 20 per cent more likely than their peers who are not aircraft noise and pollution affected to die of leukemia and solid tumour non-blood cancers before they reach adulthood?
—I thank the honourable member for Lowe for his question. Just by way of correction, there was not an apology the other day.
—The honourable minister will respond to the question and not engage in other debate.

—I am not aware of the report that the honourable member refers to, but the honourable member raises the point about air traffic movements around Sydney. I do not know where he gets his 300 per cent from, but obviously the government's targets as far as the long-term operating plan is concerned are still in sight at 55 per cent of movements to the south over water, 17 per cent to the north, 15 per cent to the west and 13 per cent to the east. With regard to the environmental conditions that surround major airports such as Sydney and in the Sydney basin—
—On a point of order, Mr Speaker: my question—
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order relates to relevance. My question was specific in regard to the matter I raised about the results of the tests that were conducted in the UK.
—The minister is entirely in order in his response. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—I was just about to make a comment with regard to the environmental impacts around airports, such as in the Sydney basin where there is a lot of conjecture and different attitudes and levels of misinformation about the level of pollution. The important thing that members should note, particularly the member for Lowe, is that my understanding is that about two to three per cent of the pollution in the Sydney basin is from aircraft, about 70 per cent from motor cars and the balance from industry. It is not emanating from use of airports. I think the member for Lowe should recognise that in his further questions.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister inform the House of the results of his recent talks in Washington with the IMF, the World Bank and the United States administration and the measures Australia is taking to relieve the present difficulties in Indonesia? Can the minister further inform the House of the response from Indonesia to Australia's role?
—This should be a ministerial statement.

—I thank the honourable member for his question. Indeed, in response to the interjection from the member for Prospect, I point out that it is nice to know that there is a member in this House who is interested in serious policy issues—being, in this case, the member for Aston—because the fact is there is not one on that side of the House apparently.

answer.para: The Australian government does regard the relationship with Indonesia as one of our most fundamental relationships. We do not go out of our way to assist Indonesia simply because we want to help other people from the goodness of our hearts, although we do have good hearts. We also do it because we wish to promote our national interest, and it is in our national interest that Indonesia is both a prosperous country and a stable country. We have, therefore, been very concerned about the economic crisis that has beset Indonesia and we are doing everything we possibly can within the limits of our resources to assist that country maintain stability and rebuild its prosperity.

In that context, in response to the member for Aston's question, I visited Washington a couple of weeks ago and had discussions with the International Monetary Fund, the World Bank and senior United States officials about this situation. There were really three main focuses of my discussion—the IMF program, the private debt situation in Indonesia and the food security issue.

I can say that in my discussions with Mr Camdessus, the managing director of the IMF, the views of the Australian government were very well received. It is pleasing to see that there are positive signals now emerging that Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund are working constructively together and we would expect an announcement soon.

I also, as I mentioned, did take the opportunity to discuss the private debt situation in Indonesia because, clearly, until a way can be found through the restructuring of private sector debt, the economy is going to find it difficult to stabilise. It was an opportunity to discuss those issues with senior United States officials and also subsequently, when I was in Japan, to talk to the Japanese about that issue. Again, on the issue of private sector debt, we are optimistic that a statement will be made in the near future which should take the whole of that issue further forward.

Finally, let me say that, while I was in Washington, I had the opportunity to meet with Mr Jim Wolfensohn, the President of the World Bank, and I discussed with him a proposal that had been put forward by the Prime Minister to Mr Wolfensohn that the World Bank should coordinate a meeting of international aid donors in order to provide direct emergency assistance to the people of Indonesia—in particular, the poor people of Indonesia, who are suffering the most at this very difficult time. We on our part believe that we do have a humanitarian as well as a national interest responsibility to help the ordinary people of Indonesia as best we can at this time.

Mr Wolfensohn, I am very pleased to say, agreed that he would coordinate a meeting of donors in Washington on 1 April—that is today—so that meeting will be taking place today. Australia will be represented by Trevor Kanaley, the Director-General of AusAID, and a number of other governments will be represented at senior levels. Mr Wolfensohn himself will be there.

So over and above the assistance we have given with trade credits and the assistance we have given through the IMF package, the Australian government has given very significant diplomatic support to try to help with the resolution of the very difficult problems that Indonesia faces. It is important that members understand that it is in the national interest that we do that. We are not just doing it out of the goodness of our hearts; it is in the national interests we do that.

talk.start.para: —That is true, but why don't you make a public statement?
—I know the opposition does not wish to hear any of this. They are no longer interested in serious policy issues; they are only interested in childish tactics.

—Mr Speaker, on a point of order: this should have been a ministerial statement so that we could have had the opportunity to discuss this issue. That is the point that has been made by the opposition.
—The honourable member for Calwell will resume his seat. I would point out that—

—When the House resumes its silence, including the honourable member for Prospect. I would point out that the minister's response related to a meeting taking place today and, as a result, it seemed to me that the answer did have real relevance and answered the question without notice.

—My question is again to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, do you recall in defending your secret directorship last night that you claimed that the difference between you and Senator Richardson was that he held the directorship whilst minister for communications? Prime Minister, didn't Senator Richardson resign as director of 2HD just six days after he was appointed communications minister and three months before you raised it in the parliament, but didn't you retain your directorship for six months while Prime Minister? Isn't the only difference between your behaviour and that of Senator Richardson that he saw the potential conflict and acted to remove it while you did nothing until you thought you might be caught and then you hid it?
—My recollection is that I said there were a number of differences and one of them, which the honourable member did not refer to, was the fact that 2HD was a commercial operation.
—Non-profit.
—Oh!
—There is no difference.

—He says there is no difference. I think most Australians know the difference between a non-profit organisation and Coles Myer, and that is what is involved in this. You are once again wasting time on trivial issues. It is now one minute to three and there has not been one question from the Australian Labor Party on any issue of any relevance.
—No policy.
—No policy, no interest, no concern. You are utterly indifferent to the interests of ordinary Australians, and the longer you go on with this trivial muckraking, the more damage you do to yourself.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts. Will the minister inform the House of the benefits which will flow to young Australian music lovers from the government's decision to break the monopoly of multinationals in the compact disc industry?

—I thank the member for Sturt for his question. He is regarded as one who has a passionate interest in this particular issue and who has prosecuted the case on behalf of young Australians getting realistic pricings for CDs for some time, to the extent that he appeared on the Midday Show , quite successfully. I am quite envious of that.
—The minister will respond to the question.

—You did a very good job. Recent evidence provided to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee clearly dispelled the myth advocated by multinational record companies that Australians will not get cheaper CDs under the government's proposed legislation to introduce parallel importation of sound recordings. Indeed, several witnesses to the committee, including representatives of the ACCC and the Australian Consumers Association, believed that prices would actually come down and that there would be a greater range and choice of CDs as a result of breaking down the exclusive arrangements and distribution arrangements controlled by the current suppliers. Woolworths, a major operator in this country and one of the nation's largest retailers of CDs, told the committee that, if the government's plans were put in place, a 25 per cent to 30 per cent reduction in the retail price of CDs would flow. Indeed, that flows from the analysis done by the ACCC and the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics.

answer.para: Of great concern was the prediction by the Australian Consumers Association, which said there was considerable risk that CD prices would go up by another $2 if these amendments were not passed. Indeed, there have been surveys where 83 per cent of consumers believed that CD prices are in fact too high in this country. They are artificially high because of the current Copyright Act, which gives the big five foreign record companies an effective monopoly on imports and distribution of CDs. Those same companies exported payments of about $166 million in royalties in 1994-95, the bulk of that going to the United States and the United Kingdom.

I think it is fair to say that the arrangement at the present provides large profits to foreign companies and that those profits are a direct result of the current importation restrictions which allow those firms to set their own prices and to restrict the range of music available to Australian retailers. That is the nub of the problem. That is why we want to have a system of parallel importation—to break down the monopoly arrangements that currently exist. The opposition to parallel importation by the two lobby groups ARIA and AMRA is basically shoring up their interests at the expense of consumers. That is why this issue is passionately advocated on both sides—the government admits that—but we believe that our responsibility is to develop legislation to protect and further the interests of the consumers, the purchasers of CDs. Allowing parallel importing is the only way this can be achieved. Smaller retailers will be able to import a much wider range of CDs, and therefore the pricing points as they are reflected at the retail point of sale will provide a much better deal particularly for the young people of Australia.

It is interesting that the Democrats, along with the Labor Party, have indicated that they are going to oppose the government's legislation. We think that is particularly regrettable. We think that is interesting from the Democrats' point of view. The senator responsible for this area has been promoting herself as the protector of young people's interests and now, of course, has gone along and endorsed a position which will see prices go up. It will certainly see a situation where prices will not come down. That is why I think the Democrats' position on this matter is particularly regrettable.

talk.start.para: —The minister will draw his answer to a conclusion.

—I will, Mr Speaker. That flies in the face of what another member of the Democrats, Senator Murray, has said. He said he believed that, if the outcome was an increase in prices, that would be something that is regrettable. I do not believe the Democrats are united. I think it is a shame for Australia, particularly the young people and purchasers of CDs, that this matter has not been able to proceed.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's defence that he has not breached the guidelines because he did not stand to profit from his directorship of the Menzies Research Centre public company. I ask whether the Prime Minister recalls a statement by Senator Hill that:

question.para: Any reading of the Register of Ministers' Interests reveals that it is a statement of registrable interests, not pecuniary interests.
Indeed, it says here, `Statements of Registrable Interests.' Prime Minister, don't the same standards apply to you?

talk.start.para: —I repeat the defence that I gave at the beginning of question time in relation to the ministerial guidelines: it was based upon the argument that, by any plain meaning of the language, I was not a director of a public company.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, people in my electorate of Deakin have been very supportive of the government's job pathway program. Can the minister inform the House of the success of the job pathway program in assisting young Australian school leavers into jobs, including the success of the Maroondah Careers Network which is assisting school leavers in Melbourne's outer east to find jobs?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Deakin for his question. I acknowledge his great interest in helping young people in the electorate of Deakin to move successfully from school into employment. The Labor Party turned their back on the 70 per cent of young people who are not going from school to university. The apprenticeship system essentially dried up. The number of young people in apprenticeships and traineeships as a proportion of the work force was the lowest for three decades during Labor's last year and youth unemployment, as we know, hit a record 34 per cent.

answer.para: The job pathway program has been one of the government's most successful initiatives for young people. It involves extra funding for schools so that schools can take a proactive role in helping their school leavers get jobs. At the present time, more than 1,000 high schools across Australia are involved in job pathway and more than 20,000 school leavers will be helped by job pathway this year.

One of the most successful projects in the job pathway program is the consortium of 29 schools in the Mooroondah area in the electorate of the member for Deakin. In fact, this project, this consortium of 29 schools, also extends into parts of the electorates of Casey, Menzies, McEwen, Aston and La Trobe. Already, this project has had a 100 per cent success rate with school leavers at the end of last year. It contracted to place some 240 young school leavers in jobs and it has placed 240 in jobs in the retail, hospitality and construction industries.

One of the really interesting and important aspects of this success has been that 80 per cent of these placements have been in the government's new apprenticeships. These schools have provided counselling and individual support to 1,200 students at risk of leaving school early and have had very considerable success in encouraging these young people to stay on at school. These are practical initiatives to make a difference to the lives of thousands of young Australians. The government is not stopping there. At the end of January, the Prime Minister announced that the job pathway program would be further expanded with $13½ million of additional funding over the next two years.

talk.start.para: —Nobody is listening.
—You should be listening. It is very interesting that only one state government prohibited its government schools from participating in that program—
—Yes, New South Wales.

—And that was New South Wales. That was the Carr Labor government. That shows how little commitment the Labor party has to helping these young school leavers actually get jobs. If the Leader of the Opposition had any spine and backbone at all, he would go and tell his colleague the Premier of New South Wales, for the Labor party, to allow school leavers in that state to benefit from the job pathway program.
—Mr Speaker, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—I ask leave to move:

speech.para: That this House censures the Prime Minister:
(1) for breaching Ministerial standards in relation to (a) his own Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct and (b) the House of Representatives Register of Members' Interests in that:
(i) he failed to disclose his directorship of the Menzies Research Centre Limited, which he held for the first seven months of his Prime Ministership; and
(ii) he placed himself in a position of conflict of interest between his public duty and his directorship of that company;

(2) for presiding over a Cabinet meeting which agreed to $400,000 worth of grants to Menzies Research Centre Limited, as well as agreeing to tax deductibility for donations to the company, whilst he was a director of the company in a clear conflict of public duty and private interest;

(3) for his weak and secretive attempt to avoid both public scrutiny of his directorship and the need to reveal his breach to former Ministerial colleagues he had forced to resign for similar breaches of his Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct; and

(4) for his latest contortions and re-definition of the meaning of his own guidelines to suit his political needs, again doing so in a manner which has no regard to the standing of those guidelines, or to their consistent application, credibility or transparency.

talk.start.para: —Does the government accept the motion?
—We will take your suspension motion and then you can move the censure.
—The question is that standing orders be suspended. Those of that opinion—
—Sorry, hang on. I did not actually move that.
—Didn't you move the censure?
—No, I asked leave to move a censure motion.
—If you are asking for leave, you can have leave to move the censure motion.

—Could I say, before I call the honourable Leader of the Opposition, that I know that there has been a practice in this House of drafting extraordinarily long and complex motions. That one is extraordinarily long and raises questions of whether it is entirely within the standing orders. I suggest that all members, when they are raising matters of this sort, be careful that motions are entirely within the standing orders and the practice of this House.
—I move:

speech.para: That this House censures the Prime Minister:
(1) for breaching Ministerial standards in relation to (a) his own Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct and (b) the House of Representatives Register of Members' Interests in that:
(i) he failed to disclose his directorship of the Menzies Research Centre Limited, which he held for the first seven months of his Prime Ministership; and
(ii) he placed himself in a position of conflict of interest between his public duty and his directorship of that company;

(2) for presiding over a Cabinet meeting which agreed to $400,000 worth of grants to Menzies Research Centre Limited, as well as agreeing to tax deductibility for donations to the company, whilst he was a director of the company in a clear conflict of public duty and private interest;

(3) for his weak and secretive attempt to avoid both public scrutiny of his directorship and the need to reveal his breach to former Ministerial colleagues he had forced to resign for similar breaches of his Guidelines on Ministerial Conduct; and

(4) for his latest contortions and re-definition of the meaning of his own guidelines to suit his political needs, again doing so in a manner which has no regard to the standing of those guidelines, or to their consistent application, credibility or transparency.

We have here the guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. This document has about the same amount of relevance now to Australian political debate as do the Dead Sea scrolls. This is a useful piece of archaeology; it is a useful piece of archaeology which lends us an understanding of what time was once like in this country when governments exercised some degree of restraint in relation to themselves and some level of public accountability.

Like the Dead Sea scrolls, it is a document full of spirit which will enable archaeologists and historians to discern the attitudes of various sects at the time and to speculate interestedly on whether or not they have any relevance to a discussion of the head of state of the land or are in any way responsible for the politics of the time.

Like the Dead Sea scrolls, these things have become things of the spirit rather than things of actuality and of practical relevance to the considerations of the parliament today—that is, to everybody except those on this side of the House. For us this is a living document. For us this is a set of standards which our ministers adhered to. For us this is a set of standards against which we tested ourselves. For us this is basically what is expected of a standard of honour in this place for members of governments and members of parliaments. Without it, the very substantial reputation for honesty that federal politics in this nation exercises around the globe for an almost unique honesty and integrity goes down the tube.

The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has set an exercise in rendering black white when it comes to dealing with these standards of ministerial conduct, both in relation to Senator Parer and in relation to himself. As he redefines and finds himself trapped, he redefines again; he finds himself trapped, and redefines himself again. For example, he has said in the course of his remarks here today that, because he exercised no pecuniary interest in this, it actually has no meaning as far as he is concerned. I will get on to how much he obviously actually believes that, by his practical actions, a little later.

Suffice to say at this point, as I took that statement of Senator Hill and as I indicated in my question, this is a statement of registrable interests. Registrable interests have, for the Prime Minister, included everything from biros to membership of Rotary clubs. He has understood thoroughly, he has firmly fixed in his own mind, that the standard requires registrable interests, not just simply a pecuniary interest.

He was asking of us last week, `Ignore everything in my guidelines in relation to Senator Parer. What you in the Labor Party have to do is to demonstrate that he did that action in connection with this interest and as a result produced a conflict of interest.' So low is the moral sensibility now on that side of the House that they think that in those circumstances what you are actually discussing—particularly when it comes to a matter in which you are actually earning something from it—is a conflict of interest. In actual legal terms what you are discussing there is not a conflict of interest—perceived, real or actual. You are discussing corruption. So conflict of interest propositions went right out the window as far as the Prime Minister was concerned.

But, having established that test last week, that test was run across him on this matter here today. And on this matter we can identify two clear-cut breaches: first, a requirement for declaration was breached—that is a declaration to all of us—and, second, a requirement for declaration to the cabinet and for absenting yourself from a discussion that is directly relevant to matters of interest that you enter tain was also breached. So we have had those two breaches even under his own redefined standards.

What do we find today? We find it finally reduced to the point: `Unless you can prove that I put a bit of dough in my back kick, nothing matters, absolutely nothing else matters.' You can bring this very lengthy guideline down to one sentence: `Ministers may not make decisions that put dough in their back kicks.' End of story. That is the end of it.

talk.start.para: —But they worry about it only when they're caught.
—And then, as the honourable member for Hotham says, only when they're caught.
—And that's corruption.
—The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent.

—The Prime Minister said in his little episode in question time that what the opposition should be concerned about in question time is a whole range of issues that he says are of relevance to the Australian people. And so they are. And, if you ask me to evaluate this thing in the great scheme of life as to what is relevant to the average Australian, what puts bread on the table is more relevant in the daily life of the average Australian than the enforcement of ministerial codes of conduct.

speech.para: What is relevant to the average Australian is the question of the removal—as was pointed out by us in question time yesterday—of a whole range of entitlements, in clear breach of election promises by the Prime Minister. That is of far more relevance to the elderly Australian than questions of breaches of the code of conduct. The destruction of educational opportunity for a range of young people in relation to university is far more relevant to them than a ministerial code of conduct. The proposition of the privatisation of Telstra and the consequent likely disbenefits that are going to flow to a whole range of Australians, particularly those in the bush, is far more relevant than the ministerial code of conduct.

If the Prime Minister wants us to make a statement about that fact, we will. We are cheerful to own up to the fact that in our judgment—and no doubt in the judgment of the people of Australia—those things are far more relevant to them. And we have therefore been providing you with an opportunity to answer for yourselves on all those matters in question times and in MPIs over the last couple of weeks.

But there is one task that is uniquely performed in this chamber that cannot be performed by the average Australian, cannot be performed by somebody whose devotion of their daily attention is to their struggle for survival, the needs of their families and the jobs that they do. They are not in this place. They elect us to this place. They expect us to establish a set of standards that are broadly publicly acceptable, they expect us to adhere to them and they expect us at the end of the day to hold governments and each other accountable as far as those standards are concerned.

Indeed, when the Prime Minister was gallivanting around the Old Parliament House, as I do well recollect, at the time when he discovered that the then minister for education I think he was, Mr Dawkins, had in fact failed to declare that his mother was a shareholder in BHP, what did we get from the Prime Minister? Did he ask for the establishment of the fact of the minister of the day reaching into the pockets of BHP and putting into his own pocket as the standard? Did he want us down at that bottom line? No, he was prepared to go on with arguments about the appearance of that situation. He had very high standards then he did. He had very high standards which he was pleased to announce to the rest of the Australian people would be the standards that he would apply when he came into this place.

And what have we seen from this Prime Minister since then? Just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to the elderly of this nation as far as dental health is concerned, just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to the people of this nation as far as their access to nursing homes is concerned, just as he had weaseled out as far as the access of the unemployed people of this nation to decent support when it comes to labour market programs is concerned, just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to the young people of this country in relation to HECS, university places and a whole range of other activities, just as he has weaseled out on his promises on tax—as we see his massive increases in superannuation tax arrangements proceeding though here—just as he has weaseled out of his commitments to maintain spending as far as the environment is concerned, just as he has weaseled out of just about everything that Australians do regard as relevant to them in their daily lives, so he has weaseled out of this set of commitments. And there is only one place where he can be held accountable as far as that is concerned.

I have here a question that the Prime Minister asked in relation to former Senator Richardson. He dragged Senator Richardson's political wraith around him in his defence of himself on the Channel 9 show the other night. I never thought I would live to see the day when Richo was called to defend the reputation of a member of the government when I think of the hard things the Prime Minister had to say about Richo from time to time in this place and in other places. I want people to reflect upon this question that he asked the Prime Minister of the day:
My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's claim that it was common knowledge that Senator Richardson was a director of 2HD . . .

I repeat: `common knowledge that Senator Richardson was a director of 2HD.' What was the first answer to a question he gave here in this place? `Oh, it was common knowledge, Mr Speaker. I was leader of the Liberal Party. As far as everybody in this country was concerned, of course that would find them immediately identifying the fact that I was a director of the Menzies Foundation.' That was a marvellous defence as far as he was concerned. His question continued:

. . . when he participated in broadcasting discussions and decisions of the Cabinet. Was this statement by the Prime Minister not just an expression of personal opinion, or has the Prime Minister been personally assured by all Ministers present at the Cabinet discussions that they knew of Senator Richardson's directorship?
Well, Prime Minister, were you assured by all your ministers at the time that they knew about your directorship of your particular company on this occasion, and a declaration of it? He went on:

Is it not, therefore, the case that unless the Parliament is satisfactorily assured that Senator Richardson either disclosed his interest as a director of the radio station whenever he participated in Cabinet discussions or decisions on broadcasting matters—and not jut those relating to licence fees, but all broadcasting matters—or, alternatively, absented himself from those discussions, he must, in accordance with accepted Cabinet practice, resign from the Ministry and in default you ought to remove him?

That was the standard of the Prime Minister at the time. What is the difference between the Prime Minister's situation and Senator Richardson's? Senator Richardson sat in that cabinet for six days as a director of 2HD. The Prime Minister sat in it for six months. There is no evidence in that six days that there was any broadcasting matter before cabinet. There is every evidence, and the Prime Minister has effectively fessed up to it, that there was a matter precisely concerning the Menzies Foundation put before the cabinet during the Prime Minister's consideration of those concerns.

Furthermore, not only was there evidence of that but there is the evidence that the way in which he conducted himself around it was a representation of a pattern of deliberate deceit, and I will get on to that in a minute.

Let me finish with the Graham Richardson example, because there was a conclusion to the Graham Richardson example. It did not simply conclude with Graham Richardson—or me, as Leader of the House, or the then Prime Minister—standing up and defending himself and just flicking it off by saying, `These are trivial matters; it doesn't matter. I didn't get any pecuniary interest. I didn't benefit this particular company from any decision I took. It wasn't a public company.' You never got that as a conclusion from Senator Richardson. You got that as a conclusion from the current Prime Minister.

What did you get from Senator Richardson? He stood up in the Senate and made a substantial and clear-cut apology to the parlia ment for having, in his mind, inadvertently misled them. There was an apology to the parliament and an apology to the Prime Minister. What we get from this Prime Minister, who can never admit he is wrong and will destroy every standard that governs parliamentary activities, every rule that governs parliamentary activities, is that he can breach them; the rule is wrong, he is not wrong. He alone, uniquely, exercises the authority to redefine the rules every time he stands on his feet. Today, in question time, we had those rules redefined, I would suggest, at least four or five times as he retreated from or failed to answer every question that was put to him.

Let me turn to another aspect of this matter, in case people think it is a matter of some trivia or of no importance for us to consider. Consider what he was doing at the time. The Prime Minister, of course, had the lowered eyebrows, the sadness on his face, as he punted one minister after another during that period of time, as he clothed himself in the rock-ribbed armour of self-righteousness and the significance of these rules that he put down that he is prepared to uniquely claim. He got up and speculated for the people as to how he had so frequently had cause to remark to his ministers that they must observe these laws to the letter, even if it was just a bit inadvertent, even if it was trivial. Remember that he punted poor old Senator Short, one of his flatmates, for trivia. What a lousy cook he must have been and what a terrific one Senator Parer must be! An indication of a career afterlife when he has finally dealt with it.

What did the Prime Minister say about them during that period of time? Well, they had to go. But what was he doing at that point in time? Remember, he has had the cabinet meet on his Menzies Foundation and make a determination. That does not provoke anything from him at all. He has rung me. He has said, `Look, I intend to give a hundred grand to the Menzies Foundation and I'm going to give to you a hundred grand for the Evatt Foundation.' This was supposed to be one of his defences here—the fact that he rang me. I can tell you this, Prime Minister: I was perfectly cheerful to see resources given to the Menzies Foundation, I was perfectly cheerful to see them given to the Evatt Foundation, but you never told me you were a director of it. And you are going to be taking that to the cabinet—well, really!

First, he attempted to clothe himself in the wraith of Senator Richardson and then he attempted to clothe himself in my all-too-real presence. On both occasions, he did not manage to drag down what he desperately hoped for himself—that body over himself in the trenches so that none of the flak may hit him. We have both jumped up and moved away as far as that is concerned.

How must his colleagues feel? How must those colleagues who were humiliated by him feel? Those colleagues who obviously did not fully comprehend all the aspects of detail as far as these considerations were concerned—how must they feel about it? How must they feel about a Prime Minister who clearly understands the full range of things which he must declare and then, above all, how do they feel about a Prime Minister who is dragged kicking and screaming into this place to explain these matters because of exposure, because, even if inadvertently, he had not actually seen what was expected of him or remembered what was expected of him? He certainly did recognise it ultimately. One would have thought that what would have flowed from that was a correction when that revelation came to him, but there was none. And why? Obviously because he knew that, if he put this into the register of interests at the time when we were considering these other matters, we would have pointed it out and he would have suffered a massive degree of embarrassment.

What sort of Prime Minister is that? I would say it is a Prime Minister who is weak and sneaky. That is how I would describe a Prime Minister of that demeanour: weak and sneaky. He now seeks to defend himself—and I notice the bloke who is going to speak next, the Leader of the House (Mr Reith), also seeks to do that—saying that somehow or other you do not actually have to declare any of these things in business dealings related to your job if you happen to be leader. I am afraid that you do have to make those declarations. That is part of your job and your duty.

The fact that you happen to be leader and that that automatically puts you onto a public company or a company of any description has to be declared. That has to be in here. That has to be there so that it can be seen because decisions are taken by governments that benefit those particular companies from time to time. If I were a director of the Evatt Foundation, I would have to declare it and you would expect that I would have to declare it. If I were a director of anything, there would be an expectation that it would be declared in this place because the rules—this piece of archaeology that is left for us to use—demand it of you.
This Prime Minister is deserving of censure. This Prime Minister has scuttled out from this, but he will not scuttle out from the judgment of the people of this country on this matter. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I second the motion and reserve my right to speak, Mr Speaker.

—This motion deserves to be thrown out and to be dismissed for the triviality that it is. It says a lot about the opposition that they would even have the hide, the impertinence, the gall to move such a motion today. It just shows you what muckrakers they are. You can pat him on the back as many times as you like, Simon. But the read-out in the Australian community will be that, when there is a major waterfront dispute going on and when you have major problems within your own side because one of your own front benchers is about to launch a book attacking his own leader, people will understand that this is just an old tactic.

speech.para: How many times have you seen a political party that has its own internal problems struggle to find an attack on the government, their opponents, as a political distraction. It is telling indeed: here we are in the second or third burst of industrial strike action by the wharfies, yet the Labor Party is unable to ask one question on an issue which really is important and of substance. I have seen many weak, pathetic, irrelevant performances in my time, but that one certainly takes the cake.

To hear the Labor Party talking to us about standards: what a joke! It is April Fools' Day and the fools are out in full strength. It was 14 years ago that Mal Colston was fiddling the books and who were the ministers in charge of covering up Mal Colston? None other than Kim Beazley, now Leader of the Opposition, then minister in the Hawke government. Who was the other part of the Mal Colston defence team? It was none other than the deputy leader, Gareth Evans, the then Attorney-General. What did these great upholders of standards do? They were advised to send the Colston matter to the police; they buried it and kept paying him for years and years. And you have the impertinence to move a motion in this House today about standards.

No-one has done more to maintain standards in this parliament than the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). No-one has been prepared, more often, more regularly, more courageously to stand up and talk about standards and to maintain and enforce standards. You blokes would not know a standard if you fell over one. No-one has done more to enforce standards and to apply a commonsense approach to the whole issue of standards. A commonsense approach is something which you would have a lot of trouble understanding.

This motion today is just a distraction. It is a triviality in the extreme coming from an opposition that basically have absolutely nothing to say about the significant issues. They have just drummed this one up as a political distraction. The incredible impertinence and gall of these people! The Prime Minister today revealed that a decision was made to provide some dollars—less money than most wharfies earn, or a lot of them earn. It is not exactly big money we are talking about here—$100,000. I can show you wharfies earning more than that on the Australian waterfront, thanks to the Labor Party. This is all about the fact that when you become the leader of the Liberal Party you also become a director, a member of the Menzies Foundation.

talk.start.para: —Read the articles.
—I have the articles. I will read some of the articles to you.
—Well, read that one.
—The honourable member for Hotham will remain silent if he wishes to make his contribution in this place.

—There are two think-tanks, policy groups associated with the two major political parties. The Labor Party have the Evatt Foundation. They have named theirs after one of their greats, old Doc Evatt, and we have named ours after the greatest parliamentarian Australia has known, Robert Menzies—the Menzies Foundation.

speech.para: Mr Fitzgibbon interjecting—

talk.start.para: —For many years, when Labor was in government, the Labor Party looked after the Evatt Foundation. The Labor Party also looked after the unions—talk about conflict of interest. Thank you for reminding me about that.

speech.para: For many years, the Labor Party looked after the Evatt Foundation. When the Liberal Party came in, the Prime Minister said that there ought to be fair and equal treatment between the two parties and that each of them ought to have $100,000—which was a cutback for the Evatt Foundation, which was fair enough—and that there should be tax deductibility. When the Prime Minister became leader of the Liberal Party, he automatically took on the role of being involved in the Menzies Foundation.

As the leader of a political party, you get involved in lots of aspects of your organisation. You get involved in the think-tanks, the advisory committees, the executive of the party, and you get involved because you are the leader and you are expected to be involved in each and every part of the organisation. Part and parcel of being a senior member of a political party in this country is that you are involved in your party. Like it or not, we have a party system.

talk.start.para: —A strong party system.

—And on our side we have a very strong party system, and it is part of the success of our side of politics that we work the party system and we make sure that we have a strong and viable party system. The accusation against the Prime Minister essentially is that he is a member of the Liberal Party. That is their real complaint.

speech.para: What was revealed today was that when we got in we said that we wanted fair treatment for both sides. Before or at the time that the cabinet made the decision, the Prime Minister rang up the Leader of the Opposition and said, `Kim, your side has been creaming off the top very nicely over the years. Now that we have a change in government and we are controlling things, we will treat both sides equally and fairly. What do you say about that?' What was his answer? His answer came back, `That is a good idea. Thank you very much.'

Now Mr Beazley says, `That's no answer because you didn't tell me that you were a director.' So what! The accusation is that the Prime Minister is not associated with that Liberal Party when he rings up to have a discussion about funding for the Evatt Foundation and the Menzies Foundation. What a ridiculous, stupid, juvenile, pathetic claim to make. It is like saying, `Oh, I spoke to Kim Beazley about whether or not there should be funding for the Evatt Foundation, but of course I assumed that this was a matter beyond his interest because, as leader of the Labor Party, his interest in the Evatt Foundation was totally irrelevant.' It makes no sense.

Kim Beazley's interest in the Evatt Foundation is exactly the same as the interest in the Menzies Foundation that is held by the Prime Minister. As leader of the Labor Party, Mr Beazley is interested in what happens in the Evatt Foundation; Mr Howard as leader of the Liberal Party is interested in the circumstances and the arrangements for the Menzies Foundation. Quite frankly, that is all there is to it. I think I should just put my papers down and go and have a cup of tea and leave you lot to carry on.

talk.start.para: —Do it.
—I warn the honourable member for Hotham!

—Look at the Menzies Foundation—look at the things that it is not. Mem bers of the Labor Party say that it is a public company like BHP or Coles Myer—they are trying to suggest that this is a breach of the rules which refer to public companies. This is not a public company as everybody else understands a public company. Why? Because with a public company like Telstra you can buy and sell shares. Can you buy and sell shares in the Menzies Foundation? No, you cannot, because it is not a for-profit or trading corporation. It is a think-tank, for heaven's sake! It is not BHP. He is not trading in BHP shares here, Simon. This is a think-tank. This is a policy group that has nothing to do with any commercial operation.

speech.para: The first thing to say about the Menzies Foundation is that it is not a public company. That is the end of your case. Your case just disappeared. You do not have a case. There is no case. It is not a public company. It is not a for-profit company. There are no shares traded. What was the Prime Minister's involvement in it? Quite frankly, he didn't have much of an involvement in it. He never went to a meeting, unlike Richo—Senator Richardson, the former minister for communications—who attended at least a couple of the six meetings of his company. He was actively involved in the commercial trading operations of a radio station. That is a very different proposition to the circumstances of a policy think-tank.

Is there any conflict of interest? Of course there is not. How could there be any conflict of interest? Firstly, it is not a trading organisation but, even more comprehensively, the fact is that the PM did not have any interest in it anyway. Is this a matter of great importance? Is this a matter which should displace the matter of public importance? Is this a matter which is a hanging offence? Of course it is not. This is ridiculous. Even Richo, the great Sydney radio commentator—and Labor Party ex-minister—says:

Now, I'll disagree with the Labor Party here. I do not believe you should have to resign for breaching your own Code of Conduct. The breach is a minor one. And as far as I'm concerned, the Labor Party is wrong to suggest that you should resign.

Simon, your mate, your mentor, your great numbers man is telling you that it is a joke to be moving this. This is pathetic. Even Richo, a paid-up, fully operational member of the Labor Party is telling you that it is ridiculous that you should even raise the issue.

Have we had these issues raised before? As a matter of fact, we have. For example, in October 1983 there was some issue about ministers not dotting their i's and crossing their t's—and this was nine out of 27 ministers. What did Bob Hawke say about that? He said:

These mistakes were obviously made in good faith. I regret that they were made, but they were made in good faith. It will be clear from the amendments that they do not include anything that could lead to a potential conflict of interest.
In the present we have Richo, a voice from the past, telling us today that there is nothing in this; and 15 years ago Bob Hawke was telling us that this whole thing is trivial in the extreme.

What is the Prime Minister's crime? His crime is that he is the leader of the Liberal Party. They are moving a censure motion against the Prime Minister because he happens to be the bloke who runs the Liberal Party. You think it is a matter of censure. We might as well censure the Labor Party because Kim Beazley is the leader of the Labor Party. We may as well have a debate about party politics. We may as well have a debate to reveal it entirely. This is trivial in the extreme, so what is it really all about? The fact is, it is all about the Labor Party's problems. That is what it is about. This is about the failure of the Labor Party to start developing real policies.

A very interesting story which has been building up in the last few days is the story of the writings of the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham). He is the Young Turk. I know about this because—sadly, I have to say—I was there for the whole time our side was in opposition. I know what happens—it takes a while for you to realise that you have lost the election and then, when you lose the second election, you realise that you have to change your approach. These are the words of the member for Werriwa:

History tells us that whenever federal Labor has lost heavily at the polls it has had to fundamentally reinvent itself to regain office . . . the cause of Labor is never weaker than when the party has nothing more progressive to offer the electorate than a revival of ideas long past.

Dinosaurs they are, Mr Speaker. How relevant it would have been if he had said, `When the party turns to muckraking as an alternative to policy development, then as a party, we, the Labor Party, are going nowhere.' Paul Kelly, in his piece this morning in the Australian , said:

Mark Latham, a Gough Whitlam protege, has just smashed the myth of contemporary Labor politics. In a 390-page book that could be called a heavy read, Latham dares the ALP to forget the politics of nostalgia and follow Bill Clinton—
I do not know whether that is such a good idea—
and Tony Blair to invent a new position.

Mr Speaker, they do not have a new position. What they have are fractures within their own side which are opening up, so a weak leader who has got no case comes in to mount a case of triviality in the extreme—the most trivial I have ever heard.

It reflects on you, Leader of the Opposition. You are a weak leader; you have no policy position; you cannot put the member for Werriwa back in his box; you are unable to provide any leadership; and you cannot address the issues like the waterfront because the waterfront unions have got you tied hand and foot to their policy position. Ultimately, this is a reflection of a weak Labor Party, unable to find a position to adopt and unable to develop policies. In the end, we have the muckraker—the member for Hotham—basically running the Labor Party, being attacked by the member for Werriwa and with a failing Leader of the Opposition unable to give any direction to their side. We reject it, and I look forward to the contribution from the member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey). (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The code of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is rotten to the core, and now it has engulfed him. The Prime Minister has now breached his own code of conduct. He has been deceitful with the Australian public in failing to disclose the directorship not only as his code requires but as the members' register of interests in this parliament requires. He, like Senator Parer, has been deceitful with the Australian public in trying to hide what they knew should have been declared. In Senator Parer's case, it is a significant breach because he failed to disclose that, as coal minister, he had $2 million worth of shares in a coal mine.

speech.para: The Prime Minister was director of a company that he presided over and that benefited, in a cabinet meeting of which he was chair, to the tune of not $100,000 but now $400,000—benefited to the extent to which it has been extended tax deductibility for tax donations to it. But was there any declaration of that by the Prime Minister? Was there any declaration in the cabinet? The Prime Minister has been asked that question time and time again today, and he has refused to answer it.

He was specifically asked: did he declare his interest; did he absent himself from the meeting? The fact that he will not answer that question `Yes and yes' means, I am afraid, that he did not. That is where the opposition is saying the conflict of interest has occurred. He has failed to declare in the parliament his interest, according to his own code. There has been a direct benefit to the company of which he was still a director. And what have we got? We have now got him invoking Richo as his defence—the man that he maligned because he said, `Do whatever it takes.' Now the Prime Minister is doing whatever it takes to save his motley hide. John Winston Howard—Winston the weasel; that is what he is—is a person incapable of coming into this place and fessing up; a person who was given the opportunity this morning to come into the parliament and squibbed it; a person who sat down at every question he was asked, bar one, today, after he went to some lengthy answer that had been prepared for him by his lawyers.

But let us go to that question of the company. The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) has made great play of this—that it was not a company that traded in shares. It does not matter. In the case of Commonwealth Bank of Australia v. Friedrich, this is what the court said:

There is nothing in company law to suggest the standard expected of a part-time non-executive director of a company not for profit is different from the standard expected of any other director of a profit-making company.
In other words, the court said that the Prime Minister has not got a defence, and that is what the Leader of the House spent five minutes defending him on today. He is ruled out by the court.

Don't come in here and quote the Macquarie Dictionary when you have the Federal Court of Australia against you. This is how stupid the Prime Minister is, Mr Speaker. He thinks he can weasel his way out of what he has got himself into by relying on the dictionary definition, when he has his code against him, he has the declaration of registrable interests against him, and he has the Federal Court of Australia against him. Yet he says, `I didn't know nothing.' This is the Prime Minister of Australia—dumb struck when confronted with irrefutable evidence. He says, `I didn't know nothing.' What a brave man this wimp of a Prime Minister is. Where is he today? Defending himself? He is nowhere to be seen.

John Winston Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, was appointed a director to the Menzies Foundation on 29 September 1995. He was appointed a director five months before he became Prime Minister. He signed the articles of association. His signature is here. On page 23 of the articles, John Winston Howard signed the articles of association of the company.

No wonder the Leader of the House did not go to the articles of the association—I interjected to him that he said he would. What do the articles of association say? They do not automatically put the Prime Minister as a director of the Menzies Foundation. The Leader of the Liberal Party has the clear opportunity to appoint a nominee. So let us have none of this argument about automaticity. Let us have the argument about the state of knowledge and knowledge in the signing of the articles of association, but failure to declare to the public and to the parliament.

We know the Prime Minister knows his guilt. Why else would he go and resign in secret? Because he was guilty of failure to disclose. That is why he resigned in secret. If the penny has not dropped, we will keep repeating it for you. Members should understand the time sequence of this because it is very important. On 15 October John Winston Howard secretly resigned from the Menzies Foundation. Two days before he had lost two ministers—Jim Short and Brian Gibson. The minister for industry was embroiled in a real controversy associated with the mess with his family companies and his share trading. He was on the rack too. So foremost in the Prime Minister's mind would have been the fundamental significance of complying with his code. That is two days before.

He resigned secretly on 15 October 1996 and did his press conference the next day where he made those famous admonitions to his frontbench. He went bravely before the Australian public saying, `I'm Honest John. I'm enforcing my code. I have had lots of talks with a lot of my colleagues in recent days and I very forcibly reminded them of their obligations.' That is John Winston Howard, Winston the weasel. That is what he said. But at the same time as he was reminding them of their obligations, what was the weasel up to? He slipped in the back door, divested himself of his directorship and did not declare it.

talk.start.para: —On a point of order, Mr Speaker: the member for Hotham continues to refer to honourable members with derisive epithets that are both inaccurate and unparliamentary. I ask that he be required to refer to honourable members by their correct titles.
—This is a censure of the Prime Minister, but I think the honourable member for Hotham needs to bear in mind the admonition of the honourable member for Parramatta.

—I remember when the member for Brisbane (Mr Bevis) got up and objected to me being referred to as a grub and you said that was fair play. Perhaps you can give us a list of the animals that are in and those that are out.
—The honourable member for Hotham will resume his remarks.
—And I would be enlightened.
—If the honourable member wishes to persist in that remark, I will order him to sit down. Continue your response to the censure.
—Here we have the Prime Minister of Australia reminding his ministers and colleagues of their obligations yet he sneaked in the back door, tendered his resignation and did not tell anyone about it.

speech.para: On this question of the so-called trivia, the Leader of the House says $100,000 is not worth anything. I suppose when you have got a frontbench over there that is into family trusts and 16 shares that are worth $2 million, then I suppose $100,000 is just petty cash, it is just what you might draw out on the weekend to look after yourself and your family. One hundred thousand dollars is not much money? What sort of an April fool is that Leader of the House to come in and make that assertion? But it is not just $100,000; it is $400,000. That is what they have benefited from.

The Prime Minister says it was trivial that he was director of a company when he sat in a cabinet meeting, chaired it and gave them what is now worth $400,000, plus all the benefits of the tax deductibility. He might think that is trivia; we do not. Let us understand the Prime Minister's version of trivia. In his declaration of interests, the one where the directorship of the Menzies company does not appear, what does he declare? This is what he says—these are his own words:
I am writing to advise you that I have accepted honorary membership of the International Fellowship of Cricket Loving Rotarians.

I would have thought that that is absolute trivia, but he chose to declare it. How can he choose to declare that and not the fact that he is a director of a company that benefits to the tune of $400,000? It beggars belief. What have we also got?
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Yes, a couple of bottles of Grange Hermitage. Then in his declaration he mentioned the Gladesville RSL Club, the Lords Taverners Australia Cricketers Association, City Tattersalls, Sydney Cricket Ground, Ravenswood Fathers Association, Shore Parents Association, Earlwood District Rugby Union Club, Balmain District Cricket Club, but not director of the Menzies company. Talk about trivia.

speech.para: Just to get again this point of the state of mind of the Prime Minister in what he knew he had to declare in the declaration of interests, he wrote:

It will be obvious that some of the above organisations are ones to which I have belonged for some time. They were not included in earlier returns as I had not appreciated that membership of charitable/community organisations were ones that should be disclosed. However, it is apparent from a strict reading of the explanatory guidelines that they might need to be.

Who said that? John Winston Howard when he declared everything else except his directorship of the Menzies company. It is a sham to come in here and say that he did not have to declare. He was required to declare in accordance with his code and in accordance with the parliamentary register and he did not do so. He sought to cover it up and as consequence not only have we identified the conflict but he has also misled this parliament because he told this parliament in putting that declaration before them that he was not a director of any company. He misled the parliament. He is guilty on three counts.

Let us go to the exercise of his defence last night. He did not come into the parliament today to give his defence. He had the opportunity at 9.30 a.m. today and any time thereafter—after question time today. He has not added to an answer. He still has not answered the question as to why he did not disclose and why he did not absent himself from the meeting. This is what he said. Apart from the cover-up, apart from the non-disclosure, apart from the misleading of the House, these are his own words:
. . . unless the Parliament is . . . assured that Senator Richardson either disclosed his interest as a director of the radio station whenever he participated in Cabinet . . . decisions—
not the specific conflict but any discussion about communications; this is the John Howard test then—
on broadcasting matters . . . or . . . absented himself from those discussions, he must, in accord ance with accepted Cabinet practice, resign from the Ministry . . .

We are asking no more today of John Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, than that he applies the standards he himself was laying down for other people. Why should the standards change just because he is caught out? In these circumstances—a code of conduct rotten to the core, tatters flapping in the breeze, corpses all over the place—the Prime Minister of Australia says, `Oh, there's nothing different.'

We had thought the reason he was sticking by Senator Parer was not that his wife could cook a decent meal; it would cause a domino effect with Max Moore-Wilton, the departmental head who cleared them. The reason John Winston Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, has been sticking by Senator Parer is that he knows he has been caught. The Prime Minister has been caught. The Prime Minister cannot continue to lay down standards which he himself has breached and not cop the consequences of that.

That is what we have today. It is the next dimension in the argument. The dominoes will fall—Senator Parer, Max Moore-Wilton; they lead right to the oval office in this case. The code of conduct is rotten to the core, the Prime Minister of the country engulfed in it. No wonder he is sticking by Senator Parer, but the longer he does the more his standing will diminish. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —As I have a good recollection of the history of the Labor Party in this place, let me commence by reading a quote from page 3973 of Hansard on 28 November 1986. It was stated:

speech.para: At no point has the Treasurer indicated other than that this was a mistake and one which he regrets. There is all the difference in the world between a Minister, in this case the Treasurer, making a mistake of this kind, readily admitting it and immediately rectifying it and some suggestion that a question of propriety is involved. By any standard or criterion one would wish to apply to this matter there is no question of ministerial propriety involved. There is no question of a pecuniary or any other gain involved.

They are the words of Prime Minister Hawke defending his Treasurer, Paul Keating. On what charge? Failing to lodge two tax re turns—not one but two. The then Treasurer of the country failed to even respond to the very polite correspondence that he was receiving from the Commissioner of Taxation—`Treasurer, do you think you could send your tax returns in?' At that time it was a scandal throughout Australia that there were half a million unclaimed group certificates in the tax office, primarily the property of moonlighters.

What did the then Prime Minister say? `It's not really a problem. There was no act of impropriety. There was no conflict of interest that the poor old Commissioner of Taxation had to put his job at risk.' Yet we know how brutal that Treasurer could be with other people's employment if he crossed their path. The reality is that they were pleading with him to put in a tax return. It was a massive conflict of interest.
What was the response of the Labor Party? There were questions asked. And that was the then Prime Minister's answer. But there was also a censure motion in which the then Prime Minister said:
What I said was a factual statement of the position, that is, that for an ordinary pay as you earn taxpayer this would not be a matter of immense consequence.
He is excusing his Treasurer on the grounds that maybe the tax commissioner would not punish an ordinary taxpayer for failing to put in a tax return—not much, but what a defence!

What happened at the end of all this? As is traditional, we had a vote. There are still a few people sitting in the House—not many from the Labor Party side. I am sure I can find Bob Brown's name on that list. I can certainly find the name of the now Leader of the Opposition—Beazley K.C. I can certainly find the name of someone who had a shot at me as I stood up—McLeay, Leo. There is also Martin S.P.; Morris, Allan; Morris, Peter; O'Keefe, Neil; Hawke, R.J.L., the Prime Minister at the time; and Theophanous, A.C.—you would remember him, Mr Speaker, he keeps taking points of order on you. All of those people and all of the Labor Party came in here and voted to support the then Treasurer after it had been said that there was no conflict of interest, that it was nothing worse than some ordinary PAYE taxpayer. What does that come down to? Gross hypocrisy.

There were no standards in the Labor Party. We had the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) pontificating today. The way he rewrites history has to be the most outstanding effort in the world. `We were perfect,' he said, and of course the list is legion. I remind the House of Mick Young and the Ivanov affair—a situation where state secrets were leaked in a car park. The then Prime Minister even misled us. He said that Keating offered up honestly. That is a fact. After Jim Carlton wrote him a letter asking if a copy of a letter he had from the tax commissioner saying, `Treasurer, please lodge your tax returns' was true, he came in here at half past 10 one night with Mick Young standing behind him and said `Yes, it's true,' and Mick Young closed the parliament.

Yes, tell me about it. I remember the history in this place and so do you, Mr Speaker. The realities are that on another occasion I raised a question of pecuniary interest. The whole nation was afire because an entrepreneur called Holmes a Court, the major shareholder in Bell Group and Bell Resources, had a takeover offer that was just about imminent over Australia's biggest company, BHP. It is not surprising that the government of the day, the Labor government, put together a secret cabinet subcommittee to consider the government's position. What were the rules of that subcommittee? Whatever they considered, whatever information they had, would never come out. But the caucus was going to be told what to do by that committee. It was a massive situation.

There was a group of people there, including the Prime Minister. There was a fellow there called Senator Button.
