Of course, Senator Button had done the right thing, as we were told by the Leader of the Opposition, `in keeping with their high standards'. On 12 September 1983 he wrote to the Prime Minister saying:

I confirm that I have resigned any directorships in public companies, cease to engage in professional practice or in the daily work of any business, that I accept no retainers and derive no income from personal exertion other than arising from my duties as a minister and a member of parliament.

That is pretty clear. But what do we find on 11 April 1986, just three years later? An admission in the parliament that Senator Button is a director. Of what? A company, of course, that he did not think was a public company. But today we have been told the Menzies Trust is a public company. He is a director of a public company that just happened to have 58,000 shares in BHP. They were worth at that time some $371,000 and, if the takeover offer had been accepted, their value was going to jump to $452,000 and the $80,000 profit was tax free. He was sitting on this cabinet subcommittee making decisions about whether or not there would be a takeover of BHP and he was a representative of this company. I should find the name of the company because it is of great importance to us. I will come back to that in a minute.

I thought we should also have a look at who the shareholders in that company were—the beneficiaries of his actions. The beneficiaries are the Transport Workers Union of Australia, the Australia Post and Telecommunications Union, the Federated Gas Employees and Industrial Union, and the Australian Labor Party. Everyone in that cabinet subcommittee was a member of the Australian Labor Party. We had our Prime Minister today accused of having an association with one of these things. They were all shareholders in BHP. They were sitting there in judgment. But the irony gets better, because there was another fellow there. His name was John Dawkins.

I had—and it is all on the record—the pleasure of drawing to the parliament's attention how, through the operations of a company called Coomel, Mr Dawkins and his brother had practised every tax minimisation device available. By the way, what was the process they used? They were trusts. At a time when probate death duties were still around, to make sure they were going to pay none of that, they went so far as, on the day their father died, to liquidate the company, pulling it all out.

They went further. They sold a major property. In fact what had they done? They had actually capitalised the interest. They sold the property on terms but there was no inter est mentioned. The fellow made them an offer of X. The actual purchase price three years later was X plus a large amount of money, which worked out at 11 per cent, or whatever the current interest rate was at the time, but that was in the price. Of course in those days there was no capital gains tax. Dawkins was the liquidator of the family company. In all the distributions and for other reasons his mum just happened to have 250,000 shares in Bell Group. Please remember what the takeover was. It was Bell Group or Bell Resources—it was one or the other—taking over BHP.

So we have this secret cabinet subcommittee. The Labor Party is a beneficiary of 58,616 shares worth $371,000. They are all sitting there and in comes Dawkins. Of course he had been a great scourge on tax avoiders. He was the one who demanded of us in government under Fraser that we bring in retrospective legislation. He was going to fix up everything. Of course, every weekend he went home and worked out through Coomel how to protect his family from anything that was happening. He was also a great moralist. So he walked into this cabinet subcommittee and said, `I hope everybody here has declared a pecuniary interest.' What did they say? `We haven't got any.' Button did not have one. He was a director. He was a trustee of this fund.

Of course, what was the situation with Dawkins? We are told in the Hansard when we had another censure and Mick Young got up to defend him that the realities were that you could not possibly expect Dawkins to know everything his mum had. Well, we expect Senator Parer to know everything his kids have got, and we blame him for every bit of it!

talk.start.para: —That's because he is running the trust, you dill.
—And Dawkins was running the trust, too, you bigger dill—and you hypocrite.
—Order! The honourable member for O'Connor will direct his remarks through the chair.

—The reality is that you and your mob condoned all these things. You condoned a Treasurer who did not put his tax returns in and you voted in this place to say that he was honest and right and did not have a conflict of interest.
—Calm down!
—The honourable member for O'Connor will direct his remarks through the chair.

—You carry on and you tell us what the Prime Minister should have done, but you had a cabinet subcommittee—nothing bigger. The joke of it was, and I reminded the government at the time, that a tame caucus took their recommendation. They all had a pecuniary interest through their membership of the Labor Party. Senator Button was a director of the company three years after he had told his Prime Minister he had resigned all those directorships. Any suggestion that Dawkins did not know that mum had shares in Bell because they originated from the old Albany Woollen Mills, of which his uncle, Sir Ernest Lee-Steere, was of course the chairman of directors, defies reality. That was your argument at that time, but of course you are too big a mob of hypocrites today. You come in here and you have redefined yourselves. Is it not amazing that it was the Leader of the Opposition that accused us of redefining the issues? You never sacked anyone for a pecuniary interest. Of course, you did not sack too many anyhow; you came in and you defended them. Ros Kelly: what an outrageous arrangement—and you defended her for six months until public opinion demanded she had to go.

speech.para: In all of these cases the defence was by the Prime Minister, and you all came in here and you voted to back him. I will read you the names again. When Dawkins was censured in this place, Mr Beazley, the Leader of the Opposition, was in here in fact defending that outrageous situation. You cannot get much closer to a pecuniary interest than to own shares in a company or have your mother, whom you are very close to and whose business affairs you were conducting, owning shares. You go in and you say, `Has anyone got a pecuniary interest?' and they all say no.

The reality was that you were up to your eyebrows in it. You just make fools of yourselves by coming in here and trying to rewrite history. It is all in the Hansard; go away and read it. But do not come in here and tell me there is any difference between the Prime Minister's almost arms-length involvement in a research trust when in fact your people sat with hard dollars on behalf of the Australian Labor Party and went on and took secret cabinet subcommittee rulings. And you are still doing it—you are all members of your unions. You are all in here arguing industrial relations legislation. When have any of you put your hand up? (Time expired)

debateinfo.title: CARRIER LICENCE CONDITIONS (VODAFONE PTY LIMITED) DECLARATION 1997

subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr Warwick Smith)—by leave—agreed to:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent notice No. 18, private members business, being called on forthwith.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Carrier Licence Conditions (Vodafone Pty Limited) Declaration 1997 (Amendment No. 1 of 1997), made under subsection 63(5) of the Telecommunications Act 1997, be disallowed.

The purpose of this disallowance motion is to stop the federal government giving a huge financial bonus to a foreign owned company which is standing in the way of the analog mobile phone service being maintained for the people of rural and regional Australia. In 1992 the then Labor government made an agreement with Vodafone which allowed the British owned company to enter the Australian telecommunications market as the country's third mobile carrier providing an exclusively digital service. That privilege cost Vodafone a mere $140 million. Under that deal, the government agreed to phase out analog mobile phones by the year 2000, while in return Vodafone agreed it would take on majority Australian ownership by 2003.

When the Labor government made the decision in 1992 to phase out analog phones, it was not to know that the digital system would be so disastrously ineffective. It was a naive decision—how could any reasonable person predict technology and its impact eight to 10 years out? But now this government says that it cannot reverse the decision because it would have to pay compensation to Vodafone. At the same time, it is letting Vodafone back out of its side of the deal, meaning that it will no longer have to take on Australian ownership. What is this deal worth? Some who know more about this than I estimate that it could be worth as much as half a billion dollars. Vodafone does not have to shed half its value onto a glutted Australian telephony market, but is left free to sell to AT&T or British Telecom or whomever else down the track.

How much compensation would the government be liable to pay Vodafone if it moved to break its side of the deal and maintain analog? Again, it is guesswork—but some say it could be worth between $100 million and $200 million. Even allowing for a certain amount of misestimate, there is a big difference between the two figures: the off-the-hook bonus for Vodafone and a payment, which I believe could be defended in the High Court if necessary, in the interests of community services. The government wants to give Vodafone a half billion dollar concession, but says it cannot ask the company for anything in return, because it might have to pay a couple of hundred million dollars compensation.

The analog system is worth $3 billion alone; that is what Vodafone wants us to throw away. I put it to you that the government is deliberately misleading the Australian people on this issue. Members are going around the bush saying, `It was the Labor government that agreed to phase out analog, the government is now stuck with the decision, but because we'—that is, the government—`understand, we have now made a decision which will allow analog to be retained in areas where there is no "reasonably equivalent" digital coverage.' However, the analog will only continue in these particular rural areas if Telstra, Optus and Vodafone agree to it.

This undertaking is the biggest con job and the most hollow promise ever made to people in regional Australia. Let us take a look at my electorate. I seek to table these maps prepared by independent consultants which show the difference between analog and digital coverage from Mount Canobolas in the centre of my electorate. They are prepared by Tele Resources and used, in fact, by the Australian Communications Authority. I should point out that they give a much more accurate picture of the digital coverage compared to the highly exaggerated coverage maps put out by the phone companies themselves. These publicly available coverage maps from Telstra are a joke—you just have to compare the digital map with the public ones.

If you look at the map which I have sought to be tabled you will see the analog has a range of about 100 kilometres and more, reaching almost out to towns as far away as Bathurst, Wellington, Crookwell and Cowra from Mount Canobolas. Importantly, it covers little places like Hill End, Canowindra, Carcoar, Barry, Garland, Mullion Creek—all of which cannot be reached with digital. If you look at the digital map, you will note that the range is only about 30 kilometres—and there is nothing at Molong, where I live: I can vouch for that. There is nothing several kilometres east of Orange. I can also vouch for that, having tried, any day of the week, to contact my office and other constituents only a kilometre or two out of Orange. The digital transmitters on Mount Canobolas do not even provide effective coverage to parts of the city of Orange itself, let alone along the highway to Bathurst—despite what these pamphlets say.

Let us just take a look at the scenario that is certain to unfold in the next 12 months when the Australian Communications Authority starts negotiating to maintain sections of the analog network. It contacts Vodafone, which—remember—is the only carrier without analog and therefore the company with most to lose. It writes to Vodafone and says, `Do you mind if we keep the analog transmitter in operation up on Mount Canobolas?' By this time Vodafone has spent hundreds of thousands of dollars installing digital transmitters on Mount Canobolas, as well as putting others in a number of nearby towns, including Orange, because of course the one on Mount Canobolas really only provides effective coverage to the orchards and farms around the base of the mountain.

I might add at this point that Vodafone has outraged residents of Bathurst because, after installing a transmitter on Mount Panorama, it has found the coverage to be so inadequate that it has had to put another one on top of the post office dead in the centre of town, and it is right next door to a pre-school. Despite a big campaign by concerned residents to have the tower moved away from the pre-school, Vodafone has completely ignored the requests of the residents and the Bathurst City Council. So much for the community service obligations from telephone companies. And here we have a government prepared to do this company favours, to give them a huge financial windfall and say, `We'll leave it up to you to decide which areas of regional Australia can continue to have analog phones.' What an absolute farce of a telecommunications policy!

Of course Vodafone is going to say that the analog service on Mount Canobolas has to go, because it has what it would no doubt call a `reasonably equivalent' digital service there. Likewise, the analog service at Mount Panorama should also go. Vodafone would have spent hundreds of thousands of dollars on its digital network throughout the electorate. But as I've already pointed out, it doesn't even provide adequate coverage in the major regional centres.

Mr Deputy Speaker, take another look at those coverage maps—I invite all members to do so—and see how far the analog service does, in fact, go. The story is the same in every rural electorate and many metropolitan electorates right across the country. Some like to describe analog as inferior technology to digital. But what good is the better technology if you can't get a signal? We will probably see the same sort of disaster as we introduce digital television, because it is going to need a crowd of transmitters. It is going to cost an arm and a leg—far beyond the sort of money that the regional television stations are quoting at the moment. They have not even begun to work it out.

Analog phones have become an essential business tool to hundreds of farmers and rural business people in my electorate. We all know that farmers cannot afford to hire employees to help them these days. They are increasingly having to work on their own, doing business from the tractor seat, using mobile analog phones. Farming is one of the most dangerous and lonely occupations. Here is one tool that has made that job a little safer and more viable, and a Liberal-National Party government wants to take that technology away.

Andrew Prior, who runs a fertiliser spreading business based in Bathurst, is typical of those in my electorate who are alarmed by the way the government has handled this issue. He carries a mobile—an analog mobile—not so much to conduct business, but more as an emergency tool. He says his job has become increasingly isolated as farmers take on larger property holdings, while many also take on jobs in town during the day. He says:
If the analogue system is closed and a single efficient system is not introduced to replace it, then the safety of myself and many others is placed at greater risk.
On occasions, I am 8 paddocks from the nearest public road. In the event of an emergency I rely on my mobile phone to obtain personal assistance.
I am often 20 minutes drive from the nearest occupied house, say 40 minutes walk, assuming I am capable of walking.

He notes he uses his phones in rural areas like Paling Yards, Fosters Valley and Trunkey. None of those areas have any hope, I would say, of getting a digital signal. They are too far away from the major regional population centres and the highways, and there are not enough regular mobile users in the areas to warrant the expense of installing more digital based stations to provide the same coverage. Telstra is likely to deliver cable to these sorts of people and say, `Do it yourself,' for a normal phone service. That has happened in my electorate. That is why this decision to phase out analog has to be reversed. Unless technology is developed to improve the signal strength of digital, it will never be an adequate replacement for analog.

We have a ratio of at least four to one in digital to analog transmission points. That could rise to 10 to one in certain circumstances. Certainly it was Labor that made the decision. The coalition has the power to change it, but I wonder if it has the will. Rather, it has opted for a con job that will do absolutely nothing to help the farmers and agricultural workers like Andrew Prior in my electorate. I am sure there are others in other rural and regional electorates.

Another part of this deception is this weird promise that new satellite phones will soon be here and that they can be used anywhere. This is another deception because anyone with a passing knowledge of mobile phones can tell you this technology has not even been fully developed. Even when it is, the handsets will cost several thousands of dollars. The Iridium system, which is one of those being talked about, has handsets costing $US3,000. I do not believe that is a cost-effective replacement, even given reasonable take-up of this technology down the track. It is still moons away for the sort of people who can afford and rely on analog.

It might be okay for big mining companies and the like, but not for a struggling farmer, his wife driving a lonely rural road alone with the kids or the bush fire brigade captains who use analog throughout Calare. Forget about digital; they cannot even rely on the inadequate radio communication system for their fire control, but they can rely on analog, to a large degree.

Why do we have to wait for a system that is untried and expensive when we already have a system in place that is cheap and effective? It is because of this ridiculous promise made to Vodafone back in 1992 that this government says cannot be broken. I urge members not to fall for this con job by Vodafone. Vote with me to disallow this give-away to Vodafone so we can force this company to come to the negotiating table for the benefit of the people of rural and regional Australia.

Recently, we were visited by the very successful technological wizard, Bill Gates, who reminded us that we were only at the very start of the communications age. It is all very well for the majority of Australians, who live in capital cities and who have fibre optic cable laid to their front door, to pat themselves on the back and say, `Wow! We're leading the world. We're right up at the coalface. We're at the edge of technology. We're right in amongst it.' Compare this situation to that of many farmers in my electorate, given Telstra's dreadful service record of late—which I was accused as late as this morning of exaggerating. In his report to the parliament yesterday, the minister at the table, the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith), who represents the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) in this chamber, detailed some of those shortcomings. I have had a litany of complaints, not necessarily from within my electorate; some have been from outside my electorate. Compare this to Telstra's dreadful service record of only using copper wire. They believe that that is enough; that that is an adequate service. To many of these people out in the remote areas, having a fax or a computer or a transmission via modem seems little more than a pipedream. Now they are being told they will lose their mobile analog service.

From day one in this country the people of rural Australia have had to fight for equal access to communications. As we enter the communications age, there is a very real risk with the imminent sale of Telstra looming in the background that these people will be left behind unless the federal government makes the right decisions in this crucial policy area. These people are opposed to the further sale of Telstra because they know that, if it is purely left up to market forces to deliver services in the bush, there will not be an adequate service.

I urge the government members to consider, as we prepare to head into the next century, what sort of message they are sending to the people of rural and regional Australia when they start switching off what has become a crucial means of communication to satisfy a foreign owned company, a British company, which could never have any understanding of the distances, the isolation and the unique needs of the Australian bush, such as the scattering of people across vast distances. The make-up of our geographical spread of population and our particular needs do not bear any resemblance to any country in the world that I can think of. I commend this motion to the House.

talk.start.para: —During his speech the honourable member for Calare sought leave to table certain documents.

—I second the motion. The opposition supports this proposal for somewhat different reasons from those of the member for Calare (Mr Andren). We are in accord with the fact that this instrument should be rejected.
—You gave it away.
—And if we do not have to deal with those sorts of echoes on the line on the other side, we can go on with this.

speech.para: Mr Anthony interjecting—

talk.start.para: —How did you vote on this in 1992, Leo?
—The honourable member for Deakin and the honourable member for Richmond are not assisting, especially when they are interjecting out of their places.

—I think the problem that the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) has is that he has all these terrible guilt feelings, because the National Party got tripped up by the Liberals on all these policy issues on which he, as National Party Deputy Whip, has to come in here and dragoon the National Party members into putting their hand up for things they do not want. They will be putting up their hand for this motion, which is to keep analog out of the bush. That is what they will be doing in a few minutes. They will be putting their hand up to do precisely the opposite of what the honourable member for Calare has said that people who represent rural electorates should do. So we do not want to hear too much about hypocrisy from the National Party. In their little junior relationship with the government at present they are in terrible strife, because the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) does not bother telling them what he is up to and all these telecommunications issues trap them terribly. They did not even get told that the Prime Minister was going to sell the rest of Telstra. And they have no idea of the effect that that is going to have on them in the bush but they come in here willy-nilly and put their hand up, because basically they are mugs.

speech.para: The reason that the opposition is in support of this proposal to reject this matter is that we think that when both Vodafone and Optus are floated they should be in majority Australian ownership. We think that the amendments that the government wants to make to allow both of these companies to be foreign owned is just going down the wrong path. What the government is doing with Telstra and with these two companies will ensure that very little of the Australian telecommunications industry will be owned here in Australia by Australians. The government is allowing a fair amount of foreign ownership in Telstra.

talk.start.para: —What about the abattoirs and the slaughterhouses?
—There'll be blood in the bush over this.
—Order! The honourable member for Denison is not assisting at all.

—When there is a 30 per cent—I think that is that the government is allowing—foreign ownership in Telstra you will see that Telstra will come together with the other institutional owners of that company—
—How did you vote on this in 1992?
—Order! The honourable members for Deakin and Richmond. My earlier admonition does not allow them to return to their places and then interject. They will remain in silence.

—Thank you very much, Mr Deputy Speaker. They seem to have attracted the same problem as the member for Makin (Mrs Draper). She seemed to have one of these garrulous problems the other night, and that was the end of her. I suspect that the member for Richmond has contracted the same disease.

speech.para: The reason that the National Party are selling out the bush is something for them to salve their conscience over—not us. But our belief about both these companies is the same belief we have about Telstra, which is that we should ensure that these private companies are majority Australian owned. And we believe the government should maintain its ownership of Telstra so that we will ensure that we have a viable telecommunications support industry here in Australia. We make no apology for the fact that when we brought in this legislation part of the provision was that Vodafone had to become majority Australian owned.

We are surprised that the Treasurer (Mr Costello) has approved amendments to Optus's articles of association that have the effect of removing any references to foreign ownership in their articles of association, which effectively means that Optus could become and stay 100 per cent foreign owned. Indeed, were Optus to be floated, you could find that there was very significant foreign ownership there. So we believe that when Optus is floated there should be the opportunity given to Australians to purchase a majority of the shares in that company.

Those people in the National Party who are railing and ranting against this proposal should be aware of the fact that at the time they were supportive of the then government's proposal that Vodafone should be a digital network. And it was very clear at the time when Vodafone were given a licence that they were going to be a digital operator. Indeed, that was part of their licence conditions. The agreement, on giving them that licence condition, was that the AMPS system would be closed down. Vodafone have said that if the government—be it the current or a successive government—reneges on that arrangement they will sue the government. They will sue the government for loss of business and loss of equity in their company. That means they would be suing the government for hundreds of millions of dollars.

The National Party might try to tell us that they want to do something about that. Well, they have not tried to do anything about that at present. The member for Calare has quite rightly said that he has frequently spoken against the proposal to phase out the AMPS system. He has honestly stood up and said that. The National Party members of this House get up and say that the government should not close down the AMPS system but their problem is that they try to pretend that sometimes they are part of the government and sometimes they are not. The Prime Minister knows that they are not really part of the government, because he does not tell them anything, but they end up having to support government policy. The government's policy on this is the same as the previous government's policy, which was to close the AMPS system down, because that was the agreement which was made with Vodafone when they brought in the first fully digital licence.

I have no doubt that if the coalition had said at the time that they were not going to close down the AMPS system, the price that Vodafone paid for that licence probably would have been considerably less. Indeed, Vodafone or some other operator may not even have been willing to take up that licence, because there would not be too many digital operators who would put themselves in a position where the reach, cost and complexity of their telecommunications system would be more than that of their competitors who were using a cheaper form of technology—a form of technology that has a broader reach with fewer base stations.

That is a point of difference between the opposition and the member for Calare, but the point of congruence between the opposition and the member for Calare is that we believe that when these companies are put on the market they should continue to maintain majority Australian ownership.

talk.start.para: —What rot! When have you ever said that? What about Qantas? What about the Commonwealth Bank?

—The member for North Sydney obviously does not believe that these companies should be Australian owned. Of course, the National Party minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott), like his colleague the National Party Deputy Whip, has never learnt anything so he cannot forget anything. But I would have thought that the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) did at least learn to read and write, so he would have known that part of the legislation at the time which provided for diversity of telecommunications in this country was that the operators, after a period of time, had to become majority Australian owned. That was part of the legislation.

speech.para: There might be a bit of guilt on the Liberal Party side, too, because what they obviously do not understand—and they are going to speak in this debate—is that what these instruments allow is the watering down of that provision by the previous Labor government that these utilities had to stay in majority Australian ownership. If members of the government do not understand that, they should not bother speaking in this debate.

I am glad to see that the member for Bass (Mr Warwick Smith) has returned to the chamber, because he will be able to explain to his colleagues who do not understand that what the government's instrument seems to be about is doing away with the provision of the previous Labor government that Vodafone must become majority Australian owned. He might let the member for North Sydney know that. He thinks the Labor government said that Vodafone never had to become majority Australian owned. He is wrong, and you might tell him that later—whisper in his ear or explain it to him; don't embarrass him publicly. But tell the dope sitting next to you, because he has been shouting out and obviously does not understand any of it.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order—
—The honourable member will withdraw the comment that has caused offence.
—I will withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker, but I thought it was very interesting that the dope never took offence to it; the fellow sitting next to him did.
—No, the honourable member knows better. He will withdraw unequivocally.
—I withdrew the reference to his being a dope. The problem which the member for Bass has is that he does not want to sit next to a dope.
—Is he going to withdraw?
—The honourable member will simply withdraw.
—I did that.
—You have withdrawn unequivocally?

—I did. I can understand why the member for Bass never wants to sit next to dopes, because they make him look silly. Show me your friends and I will tell you your character. This is the problem which the National Party have: they do not understand what this policy is about; they do not understand what the government is trying to do here; and they do not understand the history of this issue.

speech.para: The history of the issue is that Vodafone was required, under the legislation of the previous Labor government, ultimately to become majority Australian owned. We think that is a good thing. We think that this regulation which will take away that provision should be disallowed. We also think that the decision made by the Treasurer to approve amendments to Optus's articles of association, which had the effect of removing reference to foreign ownership in their articles of association, is wrong. We believe that when Optus is floated it should become a majority Australian owned company. If that could happen, Australians might buy the shares. But it probably would have been better if the provision was not taken out of their articles of association.

As far as the analog system is concerned, I will be very interested to hear how the National Party attempt to weasel out of this. The problem for the National Party is that part of the agreement made by the previous government, and no doubt supported by the current government, is that if the government does not ultimately switch off the AMPS system, Vodafone will sue the government. If the government does not intend to switch off the AMPS system, I will be happy to hear them say that in this debate. Maybe the Chief Government Whip, the honourable member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew), the chairman of the government parties communications committee, the raucous National Party Deputy Whip, or the dopes in some other parts of the chamber, might get up and tell us—

talk.start.para: —Along your front bench.

—There is no-one else over here, just those in other parts of the chamber. What we might hear from one of them is: does the government intend to let the AMPS system go? The truth is that they will not, because they know that Vodafone will sue them. The fact is that all the rhetoric and palaver which the National Party want to say around the bush are fibs, because the government will switch the AMPS system off, otherwise they will have a big court case coming up. I would be happy to hear them say today that they are going to keep it going. (Time expired)

—I have just had the privilege of walking into the Parliament House shop where I purchased a copy of the book by the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) titled Civilising global capital: new thinking for Australian Labor. When he subtitled it `new thinking for Australian Labor', I do not think he thought he was providing information and creating debate in a vacuum. The vacuum has been endorsed here by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), who seems to forget that in 1992, when the licences were issued, it was the Labor Party that set down the phase-out timetable for AMPS. It is hypocritical for the member for Watson to come into this House, pretend that he is holier-than-thou and second a motion that can only be described as a cunning stunt. Why is this motion from the member for Calare (Mr Andren) a cunning stunt? Because it is totally unrelated to the phase-out of AMPS.

speech.para: I put this question to the member for Calare. The new Telecommunications Act of 1997, which was debated in this House, laid down in broad terms, in part 19, the phase-out arrangements for AMPS. It was debated in this House. Did the member for Calare even speak on the bill? No. How did the member for Calare vote on that bill? It was that bill, debated in detail by this House, that set down in legislation the phase-out arrangements for AMPS. Yet the member for Calare has the hide to come into this place today and to use ownership restrictions as a method in which to score a cheap, totally unrelated political point. The member for Calare and the Labor Party are in bed together because, from a socialistic point of view, it is a good thing to try to restrain and control commerce from the grave. The grave in this instance is the House because it is the Labor Party that is being entirely hypocritical on this issue.

Where was the Labor Party about foreign ownership restrictions when they were selling the Commonwealth Bank? Where was the Labor Party about majority foreign ownership restrictions when they were selling Qantas? Where was the Labor Party when they were talking about the sale of ANL and the sale of all the other assets, including TAA? When did it come down to foreign ownership restrictions being a part of the legislative intent at the time? Now the Labor Party has the hide to come into this House to preach holier-than-thou attitudes and to say to us, `Well, in this instance, we think that a wholly privately owned company should be restricted by the Commonwealth as to who should and should not own the shares.' They are doing that behind the guise of a cunning stunt from the member for Calare about whether or not the AMPS phase-out should be related to the ownership restrictions in relation to Vodafone.

Vodafone is headquartered in my electorate of North Sydney. They employ hundreds of people in my electorate. They have made major capital contributions to the Australian telecommunications market. I do not apologise for coming up here to defend Vodafone. I do not apologise for foreign capital coming into Australia, investing in Australian jobs, creating new Australian jobs, giving us the best telecommunications infrastructure in South-East Asia, arguably in the Western world. I do not apologise for that for a second. I do not apologise for the fact that rural Australia has better telecommunications under the Liberals and the Nationals than it ever had under the Labor Party. How ironic that the turncoat of the Labor Party should stand up to take a point of order!

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: I have brought this up on previous occasions. I do not think it is within the standing orders for speakers to be accompanied by drumming. It is very hard on the ears and I wish you would tell the member for North Sydney to stop the drum accompaniment.
—There is no point of order.

—That was a winner! You hit me there, right between the eyes. That was a killer! Let me point out something to you. The people in Kalgoorlie have never had better telecommunications infrastructure than they have now. People such as you have sold out the people from Kalgoorlie by supporting a cunning stunt, the motion by the member for Calare, to try to tie up in an intricate web the ownership restrictions of Vodafone with the AMPS phase-out, the same AMPS phase-out that went before this House last year. The member for Calare was not in the House at the time. The member for Calare did not debate the bill. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) probably did not debate the bill. The member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) probably did not debate the bill. But all of a sudden, when a cunning stunt comes on they are there for the headlines. When a serious policy debate is before the House, you people are nowhere to be seen.
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I have sat here—
—What is your point of order?
—My point of order is that I regard that as an attack on me personally.
—There is no point of order.
—You can bet it is an attack on you personally. I am calling this a stunt.
—I invite the member for North Sydney to address his remarks through the chair.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I can assure the member for Calare that it is a personal attack on him because I do not like the hypocrisy of someone coming in here and—
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the honourable member was doing quite well until he confirmed that it is a personal attack.
—What is your point of order?
—The standing orders provide that a personal attack on a member of parliament requires a substantive motion and, the member having so confirmed, is disqualified from continuing in that vein.
—The honourable member has made his point. I ask the honourable member for North Sydney to take cognisance of the remarks of the member for Denison.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am making a very simple point. When the issue relating to the phase-out of AMPS was before this House, the member for Calare was nowhere to be seen. When the substantive policy issue, which he says justifies this disallowance motion, was debated by this House, the member for Calare and the Australian Labor Party were nowhere to be seen on this fundamental issue of the phase-out of AMPS. What they are doing now is using the most deceitful and crass mechanisms to try to undermine the worth of a great company, a company that is making a substantial contribution.

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. As you know, it is an offence against the standing orders to reflect on the motives of another member in this place. As someone who is speaking on this matter—
—The honourable member for Moore will resume his seat. There is no point of order.
—Obviously I am hitting the mark, because the bottom line is that this is nothing more than a stunt. The hypocrisy of the Australian Labor Party—
—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: the standing orders are there to prevent ad hominem attacks in the form of debate. This is an ad hominem attack; it is not debating the issue.
—There is no point of order. The honourable member will resume his seat.

—I am obviously hitting a raw nerve with the Australian Labor Party as well, because it was nowhere to be seen when the substantive policy issue about the phase-out of AMPS was debated by this House. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that this is a stunt. It seeks to undermine investment in a great Australian company. It seeks to undermine the investment made in Australia by foreign organisations, investment which goes towards creating Australian jobs, which goes towards the creation of new infrastructure in Australia and which, at the end of the day, means jobs in my electorate, means jobs in the electorates of the member for Calare and the member for Watson, and means jobs for all Australians.

speech.para: If the members of the Labor Party are going to support such a base motion from the member for Calare then they are letting down the people that they seek to represent. They are, in a sense, throwing out their own rules. They are throwing out everything that they seek to claim in this instance because they cannot abandon, they cannot jettison, the history that they created. We are onto them about their history. We are onto the member for Calare about his policy backflip—but, in fact, it could not be a policy backflip because he had no policy today. When it really counted, the member for Calare was nowhere to be seen. Quite tragically, he has let down all the people in Calare, because when the substantive policy issue was debated by this House he was nowhere to be seen. He is trying to cover his tracks now, and we are onto him.

talk.start.para: —In rising to support the member for Calare's motion for disallowance of the Carrier Licence Conditions (Vodafone Pty Limited) Declaration 1997, I would like to point out a couple of things to the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey). If he were being to true to his philosophy of liberalism, which I am sure he would like to think he is, then he would in fact support this motion because it is quite clear, if one were to take the trouble to do any research or to study the issue of telecommunications policy, that it would be in the best interests of the liberal philosophy in relation to market and supply and demand, in particular in services like telecommunications, to allow for the fullest possible competition in service delivery in telecommunications.
—Absolutely.

—That would be, of course, allowing for there to be, simultaneously, digital and analog mobile phone services. The point is that the agreement that was made in 1992 by the then Labor government was for the withdrawal of the analog mobile phone service, a decision that at the time was wrong, in my view, and a decision that has been compounded by the regulations enacted with the telecommunications legislation. The point is that you have compounded the original mistake.
—How did you vote?

—The member for North Sydney substitutes lack of knowledge with a big, loud, booming voice. At the time when we were debating the telecommunications legislation, he stood there and accepted without demur the argument of the minister that Telstra would honour its community service obligations. We now find that the minister himself has had to concede that that particular commitment was not substantial enough to match consumer needs, and now they have to legislate in order to beef that up to satisfy consumer needs.

speech.para: I might also point out to the member for North Sydney, who represents one of the smallest geographical electorates in this country, that there are people in this place who represent larger electorates who have people in remote communities who are the victims of the failure of your government, the coalition government, to enact legislation that would have forced Telstra to honour its community service obligations.

I now turn—as I wanted to in the first instance, but unfortunately we have been distracted to a certain extent by what was an absence of argument from the member for North Sydney—to these telecommunications regulations that turn on the agreement made by the Labor government; a mistake that has been compounded by the regulations that were enacted by this government. The purpose of this disallowance motion is to stop the federal government giving what is, in effect, a huge financial bonus to a company providing a service in our community in telecommunications which is standing in the way of the analog mobile phone service being maintained for people in rural and regional Australia.

In broader terms, what we are talking about is the replacement of a mobile telephone service with another mobile format on the understanding that no-one will get a lesser service. The opportunity to deliver the new digital service was based on a commercial incentive offered to a company to enter the Australian communications sector. What has eventuated is a mobile telephone service which for many Australians is either an inferior service or non-existent. This is the nub of the argument relating to this disallowance motion.

This situation obviously cannot be allowed to continue. It is incumbent on this government, which was elected allegedly to govern in the interests of so many of the Australians affected by the loss of the analog network, to act decisively and to retain the analog network indefinitely. I am arguing that both networks should be maintained simultaneously. There is no reason why they should not, other than the agreement with Vodafone. That is the only reason why there is a restriction or an obstacle in the way of that. There are no technical obstacles—none whatsoever.

talk.start.para: —Yes there are.

—The member for North Sydney says that there are, but I ask him to prove one of them. He certainly did not during his 15-minute opportunity to do so. He certainly did not do that under any circumstances or any observations of the rules of debate. It is not good enough to claim that the government is simply bound by a poor decision by the previous government in the first place. That is one of the most facetious arguments I have ever heard. For somebody who purports to represent liberal philosophy in the coalition government to support such an argument is a dereliction of his duty to his constituents. This coalition was elected by people who thought it would listen to their concerns and act on their behalf.
—Here we go; the usual silly things like that.

—The Chief Government Whip is responsible for making sure that his members toe the line. That is his job; that is all he does. His is that responsibility, and we expect him to say silly things like that.
—More of the old school.

—Yes, more of the same—Tweedledum and Tweedledee. My electorate is a case in point. Moore is a metropolitan electorate in Perth's northern suburbs; it is not even a country electorate. About one-third of my electorate has no digital mobile telephone service. The service providers presumably do not cover the whole electorate because they do not consider it economical. This is at the crux of the flaws in this government's approach. Most of my constituents have an analog alternative at present, but of course under the current arrangements—these plans—that will not continue for much longer.

speech.para: Amongst other things, government exists in our tradition to provide essential services to the community. Communications are an essential service. During the years that digital mobile telephone communications have been available in Australia governments have allowed a commercial rationale to dictate who gets coverage. It has not ensured that the community service obligations related to mobile telephony coverage are raised and enforced to benefit all Australians. This obligation on government to ensure that a service is provided fairly, equally and as best as possible to all members of our community is at the base of this particular problem. That is their No. 1 objective and their No. 1 duty.

The digital mobile service providers have not been without blame in this area. Telstra, the potentially private corporation this government seeks to control through legislation, unfortunately has a poor record in service provision. Telstra's honesty in advertising has been less than good. It claims to cover 90 per cent of Australia with its digital service and implies in its hard-sell telemarketing that anyone switching from analog to a digital service will be getting better coverage. What it fails to say, and what it should be made to say clearly, is that it covers 90 per cent of the static telephone numbers in Australia. The vast majority of those are in close proximity to the central business districts of the capitals and major cities of Australia. It does not cover even outer metropolitan areas like my electorate, and it certainly does not cover most of regional Australia.

The problem is that if you are not standing in one of those areas serviced when you try to make a call, you might as well be on the moon. Telstra is displaying the concept that terra nullius is not dead. It wants us to believe that Australia is an empty, cavernous entity once you leave the central business districts of major cities, and it has been allowed to get away with pushing this view commercially. How can this government claim to be able to control a privatised Telstra when it clearly cannot restrain Telstra while it still owns a majority interest in it?

I want to talk about a specific example in my electorate. I have a number of constituents in the northern suburbs of my electorate, that is, in the northern suburbs of Perth, who are cray fisherman. They have a requirement to be able to communicate with each other at sea. Previously they used the analog system and used it successfully—it gave them good coverage. But the only drawback it had in the case of cray fisherman was when they were ringing each other to describe where the crayfish were. Obviously their competitors monitored their phones and they would start converging where most of the crayfish were located. Telemarketing by Telstra, and in this instance aggressive telemarketing, assured them that they could change to digital, get the security they needed and have coverage at least as good as the analog network. My constituents identified that they needed cover age out to sea, which is presently available through the analog network. They were reassured by the Telstra marketers, and the Telstra agent fitted the high-powered, expensive digital telephones to their cray boats.

After spending many thousands of dollars between them, they now find that there is no reliable coverage. Often the phones do not work more than 200 metres offshore and, when they do, the calls drop in and out without warning. As Professor Julius Sumner Miller would ask: why is this so? It is because the transponders in Western Australia do not face out to sea. Telstra then say, quite clearly once they have sold the equipment to these people, `Oh, but our maps show that it doesn't in fact provide a service out to sea.' Of course, with their heavily stylised maps, it is very hard to understand where their particular service boundaries are. If you look very carefully at them and their relationship to the maps and the stylisation of those maps, you will see that it is very difficult to identify where those boundaries occur.

Telstra is very happy to keep the analog network. Perhaps the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey) does not know this, but it is. In fact it has such a huge capital investment that it would see such a decision as preventing a huge capital waste. It is also a question of competition. By allowing Vodafone to operate exclusively within the digital environment, the government is actually reducing competition in the mobile phone sector. True competition would see both digital and analog systems operating side by side. They are different. Each has different strengths and weaknesses. They each bring different things to customers, and if this government were true to its own philosophy it would keep the analog network operating on the basis that competition between the networks is good for customers.

I thought that was one of the principles upon which this government based its policies until, of course, I saw it introduce its digital television decision, which I have to say has reinforced a somewhat jaundiced view about this government's commitment to true competition. It will drive technological advancement; it will provide better service; and it will drive prices down. This is the whole point of having the two networks side by side. I might also point out that in the United States, at one of the cutting edges of the telecommunications markets, analog and digital services will exist side by side. In fact American consumers will be able to choose. They will be able to use a system that allows for the merging or the interrelationship between the analog and the digital networks.

The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts, Senator Alston, was quizzed on this on a radio program. He was asked precisely about this particular facet of digital versus analog networks in the United States, and he made what was in fact a totally inaccurate comment that there was going to be a phone that could be used in both analog and digital networks within Australia. No such telephone exists.

talk.start.para: —It does exist.

—No. You have to carry two phones. I am sorry, you produce one for me; I would like to see it. That was a problem with another recent piece of legislation, the child care amendment legislation—which the minister is familiar with—where the technology was not quite available to be able to deliver the promised legislative change. He agrees with that and he knows that that was one of my criticisms then.

speech.para: As part of my contribution to this debate, all I am asking is for the government to think again. I do not think that is a particularly difficult thing for them to do, surely. All we are asking them to do is to review a decision made by the Labor government. It was a decision that was wrongly based; it was a decision that was not in the best interests of customers; and it was a decision not in the best interests of service delivery and fundamentally, and the member for Deakin (Mr Barresi) might want to be aware of this, it was a decision that was inconsistent with the coalition government's own philosophical commitment to competition and market forces because it restricts competition.

In the last few minutes of my contribution in this debate, I will deal with a couple of issues that were raised by potential customers, clients, when talking to one of the experts from the ACA's analog closure education program, Mr Warren Duncan, who appeared on 8 January 1998 on 3AW in Melbourne. He made some observations in response to questions, one of which was when the interviewer said that a knowledgeable caller suggested that the digital coverage would never cover the whole of Australia, that it was impossible. Mr Duncan conceded:
That could very well be the case.
He is the expert. Ask the expert. He says:

That could very well be the case, but the difference really is that . . . it's because of the nature of the technology, Doug. Analog can stretch out over quite considerable distances whereas, dependent upon where the base station is, digital may not cover the same extent, but that's why the government has gone for digital because in the future, in the areas even where there isn't analog at the moment, satellites will be covering these areas in a much more cost-efficient way than analog even is now because y'know we will be able to have dual handset . . . dual mode handsets which will enable people to talk via satellite . . .
I have to make an observation here: this is talking about technology that is not actually available to the Australian marketplace right now.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish. It's out there now. I've got a rural electorate.

—If the member had any idea of what he was talking about I would argue the case with him, but I do not think you can argue with an expert from the government's own agency. In fact, when asked the question about a preference in terms of the technology, the expert conceded:

speech.para: No, I really don't have a preference in terms of the technology. You'll find at any one mobile phone forum you'll have any different number of speakers who will stand up and support any different type of technology . . .

In the United States, the majority of mobile phone service consumers opt for analog. When they are given the choice of different levels of analog service, including encrypted analog, most of them go for standard analog service because it is more reliable, it has better coverage and, in many instances, it is cheaper. In this country we have restricted competition, made the marketplace more restricted, driven prices up and restricted the services to people who live in remote and regional areas. In actual fact, that is totally contrary to the philosophy of this government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am sure the member for Calare (Mr Andren) is motivated by the best intentions, although I would echo the words of the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey): if he felt so passionately about this at an earlier date, why was he not in here to challenge the legislation when the government brought it into the chamber?
—Because these are regulations; they are not actually in legislation.
—Okay, but he may have indicated some concern for his electorate at that time.
—That is why we've got a disallowance motion.
—Order! The honourable member for Moore has had his opportunity.
—Yes, but they interrupted me, Mr Deputy Speaker.

—Very little, I might add, Mr Deputy Speaker. However, I will just get on with the text of this. There is a bit of history involved with this, and it goes back to 1992 when the Labor government, to attract new players into the Australian mobile phone regime, agreed to turn off the analog network on 1 January 2000. Despite the fact that that was a very poor decision, there was one thing they did have to get right: sovereign risk. If you were going to ask people like Optus and Vodafone to come into the market with a new digital technology, there would have to be some certainty that they would have a share of the market and that, by the year 2000, the old technology would be removed.

speech.para: The member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) went into a lot of glib asides about being interested to hear what the National Party had to say about this. The National Party was saying things about this from the very minute we knew the analog system was not going to be overtaken by the digital system by the year 2000. We were out talking about it more than a year ago. We got the ear of the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), and the minister has put an interim measure in place. That interim measure is that, in those areas where the digital signal is not adequate, the analog signal will be extended to provide a reasonably equivalent service.

I did not hear the member for Calare at that time, or the member for Moore (Mr Filing), expressing those doubts. We knew what it was going to mean, but we also knew that there was a matter of sovereign risk involved, that there was a whole range of technologies coming to Australia in the next four or five years and that any government in the future—be it of our persuasion or the opposition's—would have to take into account the consequences of some ill-conceived idea that destroyed the credibility of the government's guarantee of sovereign risk. As I said, in those areas that do not have a reasonably equivalent service we have decided to allow the continuation of the analog system beyond the year 2000.

The member for Calare described areas of his electorate and said how important it was that these people have digital phones. I do not disagree with that for a minute, but you will find anywhere in Australia, as you did when we had only analog, that there are areas where you cannot get a signal. I have areas between Bundaberg and Gladstone in my electorate where we do not get a signal—analog or digital. The interesting thing is this—and none of the other speakers have mentioned this in the debate today: analog currently covers 93.8 per cent of the populated areas of Australia.

talk.start.para: —Static telephone numbers.
—Yes, static telephone numbers.
—What about geographical areas?

—Where most of the people live—I thank them very much for readily taking the point. Where most of the people live, it is 93.8 per cent. Interestingly enough, digital is now covering 94.1 per cent, to be precise. In fact, it has overtaken analog and is going ahead of it.

speech.para: I am not pretending for one minute to the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) or to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Andrews, that those two signal areas overlay completely. There will be some areas where there are gaps in the analog and there will be some areas where there are gaps in the digital. But the big point that the member for Calare is missing is this: we are now coming to yet another era of digital phone technology. Contrary to what the member for Moore said, we are on the threshold of having intermodal handsets. The technology that will be delivered is an American based digital technology called CDMA. CDMA will be the next technology offered to Australia. If we are going to have intermodal phones that can roam from one technology to the other, that opportunity will exist if companies are encouraged to come into this country in the same way that Optus and Vodafone were encouraged to come to Australia in 1992.

You could not say that they have not made a fair effort to do the right thing and to honour their side of the agreement. For example, Optus has invested at least $5 billion in Australia. If you want to take their television interests into it, it is possibly as high as $10 billion. At this stage, Vodafone has invested $1.2 billion. They did that in the clear understanding that the analog technology was going to be switched off in the year 2000, and that may or may not have been a good decision.

talk.start.para: —That was a rubbish decision.

—It was a bad decision, as it turns out. However, if we do not honour that agreement, as the member for Calare himself said, the government faces the risk of quite heavy litigation. To try to interfere with its shareholding after again giving an understanding to this company and using that as a method of blackmail would destroy any guarantee of sovereign risk being honoured in this country, would be the very thing that would drive companies away like those who wish to introduce CDMA, people like Hutchison Telecoms from Hong Kong, and would deny Australians a better quality technology.

speech.para: If you go back over the history of broadcast and telecommunications in Australia, we have not always been the first to adopt a new technology. We generally stand back a bit, have a look at the technology and then decide what will be appropriate for Australia. When we did this with black and white television, Australia per head of population embraced the medium to a greater level than anyone else in the civilised world. Then came colour television and, again, we were the frontrunner, but we waited to get the technology right. Again, with the advent of VCRs, we were a major user around the world. We are now on the verge in broadcast communications of this same argument of digital against analog. Obviously if we introduce digital properly and control it properly, we can have the best quality television in the world, no risk.

talk.start.para: —Talk about phones.
—I am coming back to phones. We already have the best free to air broadcast system in the world with two public broadcasters and three commercial broadcasters.
—It is basically four buckets of slop.

—That is hardly fair. I suppose it gives Australia's commercial broadcasters and the ABC an insight into what you think of them. I do not know if that is appropriate. I think we have very good public broadcasters in this country and, as commercial broadcasters go, quite good ones also. If we want to take that to the next plane, we have to create certainty that there will be a commercial return to those organisations at the end of the investment period, and the investment will be somewhere in the order of $700 million to $900 million, which is a huge investment.
—It's a licence to print money.

—It is not a licence to print money. The point I am making here is this: if we want people to come to this country or if we want existing players in this country to invest in new broadcast and telecommunications technology, then it is critical that we provide certainty. If we want to move from analog to digital, from digital to CDMA and beyond CDMA to low orbiting satellites, which will be absolutely crucial for the member for Kalgoorlie—
—You don't know what you're talking about.
—In fact, I was only briefed on this about three nights ago.
—Who by—Vodafone or Optus?

—Neither. Interestingly, the first player who will be delivering services will be doing so in October this year. You are obviously not aware of that. That technology will be available to Australia this year. If we want other players like Iridium, for example, which is going to be one of the early players in low orbiting satellites, to invest, we cannot tear this up every time we find a glitch or an inconvenience or a commercial arrangement made in an inept way by the previous government and throw all those things out the door. What I am interested in for the bush is not the basic technology of analog. That was the very first technology. That, if you like, was like the old wind-up phone connected to the exchange. In terms of electronic technology, it was the first. It was the caveman stuff.
—Why are the Americans sticking with it then?

—You guys remind me of a fellow who rang me up when one of the last telephone exchanges in my area was going over to automatic. He passionately wanted us to retain the old wind-up phone where you had to ask for the number. That is the sort of thing you are doing.
—That's ridiculous!

—No, it is not ridiculous. What you are ultimately trying to do is to take the Australian bush for a very short-term gain. I say to the member for Calare that, for a very short-term gain, you are going to take the whole of Australia's electronic communications back to the caveman stuff. The analog spectrum is going to be surrendered for television and it is eventually going to be surrendered for telecommunications. It will be reallocated to do other things for the Australian public in both the fields of telecommuni cations and broadcast communications. We need to move on.

speech.para: One of the problems in Australia is this ready take-up in broadcast and telecommunications that I explained to you. We tend to take on these technologies much quicker than other countries. The fact that we got to 93.8 in analog and 94.1 in digital already is evidence of how quickly we have taken up the technologies. Because we have done that, it is not perfect. I know that in Sydney sometimes my digital phone drops out. It is overloaded. I know there are parts in my electorate where I lose my digital signal.

If you ask me, on balance, whether I would rather go back to inferior technology and leave Australia in the doldrums or whether we should take on the new technologies such as CDMA and intermodal phones that can roam from one technology to another or whether I want people not just around Bathurst and Orange but the people out west who have not seen an analog or digital phone to get a high quality low orbiting satellite phone, I think it is important that we do not cave in to some shallow blackmail against Vodafone to make them leave in place technology that will not only slow down their operations, slow down Optus, but also drive away new competitors in the field.

The other thing you have to think about in the bush is not just having the raw technology but having the technology at a level that people can afford. We have got very low telecommunications costs in this country because, with normal telephony, Optus and other operators have offered competitive services to Telstra. We now have people offering competitive services to analog. I appeal to the member for Calare and the member for Moore to reconsider their stand. I think it is immature. I think it will not advance the cause of the bush getting high quality telecommunications. I therefore reject the amendment.

talk.start.para: —For one of my disposition, it is very difficult to sit still and listen to somebody totally misrepresenting the facts. Let us go back to the beginning of what actually happened. In 1992, the government gave an undertaking that GSM, global systems for mobile, would be the system for Australia. The reason for this was quite easy to understand. In Europe you had 15 different systems going across Europe. The French got together and said that this was crazy and they produced a system that unified Europe, a relatively small area, and it worked well.

speech.para: What happened in Australia? The government was confused and bluffed by the bureaucrats and they decided to adopt this system of GSM. This is what happened. Politicians at the time were entitled to believe the information they were given by the bureaucracy, so we ended up with GSM. In the meantime, along came the Americans and developed CDMA, code division multiplier access. This is a significantly different sort of digital. It does not batch the signal, as GSM does. It is therefore compatible with analog. The member for Hinkler (Mr Neville) is quite wrong, because there is no obligation in this country to introduce CDMA. It will be opposed by Vodafone and Optus because they do not have the technology. They just simply do not have it. They will oppose that as strongly as they will oppose maintaining analog.

In the United States, you have a seamless handset which will go from the CDMA to the analog. It works extremely well. When GSM was brought in we were told—and you believed it, as I believed it at the time—that the digital process would use a much narrower spectrum, therefore we would have more services. The truth is that by batching up like that you only have to hold your digital phone near your radio to hear the interference. Because of that large signal they cannot get them close together. Analog has just gone on developing because the rest of the world can see the value of it. What is happening in the cities? In the cities you can use an analog frequency here with a low level aerial and one block away you can reuse the same frequency. You cannot do that with digital. Analog ends up having many advantages that were not seen at the time.

What we are talking about is a commercial decision. This is not going to end here. Don't kid yourself. This is a big battle. People are not going to be deprived of the analog sys tem, and there is going to be a conflict. There is going to be a court case. Why in heaven's name would anyone, knowing there is going to be litigation, give away goodies like this? What we are talking about is bargaining chips with Vodafone and Optus. They are simply bargaining chips because they are asking us to make allowances for them when they agreed to it in the first place. Why should we do that? That is tradeable.

When the court case comes about and eventually sanity does prevail and we do maintain the analog, I expect Telstra will once more be milked to pay Vodafone off. But the bill will be a lot less if we say to them, `You agreed to those conditions. This is a commercial decision.' Let us face it: Vodafone are not going to provide service in the country, nor are Optus. The member says that he was briefed recently. I can tell you this: I have a real battle in my electorate with television. Optus decided we had to go to digital television—for very good reasons, but it was their idea. Telstra beat them to the punch and got the system up and running. So what did Optus do? Optus, loaded as it is with ex-staffers from the Labor Party, went into political mode and set about lying to everybody. When you get briefed, sir, be very careful. The only people I know who will give an accurate briefing an technical matters are in Telstra. The others lie their heads off.

The truth is this: you say, `We're going to have competition in communications.' What a lot of nonsense! The Labor Party gave away a great swag of property of the people of Australia to Optus. It gave them basically free entry. What you are doing is you are not having free entry of the technology. In the United States they say, `Let the technology fall where it may.' Let us have that in Australia. Let us have free technology. If you do that, somebody will introduce CDMA. It will probably be Hutchisons. It will certainly be Telstra. They will certainly do it. They know they can marry their analog service and give you a single service.

Right across the bottom of Australia you have a line of microwaves. This is technology of 30 years ago. It was a great improvement. I can remember when all the telecommunica tions between east and west were carried on six hard wires across the Nullarbor. Then they brought in microwave and opened it almost exponentially. That is now out of date. We now have glass fibres in. Those towers are there. I suggest that the cost of pulling those towers down is greater than the scrap value. It would be better to leave those towers there, attach analog to them and provide an analog service across Australia—a whole new vast area of Australia would open up. But that can only be done with analog because the towers are too far apart for digital.

talk.start.para: —For 10 people.
—And all the people who travel. What you have forgotten is this—
—They're citizens.

—North Sydney is a classic case: there is not a city in this country that lives on its intrinsic worth. They all live on the sweat of the wealthy hinterland. Sydney produces nothing. It is those people out there that you despise that keep you in your comfort, and you should realise that. It will not be realised by Vodafone. It will not be realised by Optus. And I can tell you this: when the community service obligation is given to government of any shade, Liberal or Labor, it will be cut away to nothing because governments in this country—Liberal and Labor—know that if they can win in Sydney and Melbourne the rest of the country does not matter in the short term.

speech.para: Mr Neville interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You, sir, have been sitting there quite contentedly. You say we had an opportunity at the time. Yes, we did. We were misinformed. We now know better. It is a city thing not to change your mind when you have more information. We have the information now: we know that CDMA is a far better system than GSM. We know that if we remove the barriers, CDMA will be brought in here, certainly by Telstra, almost certainly by Hutchisons. It will give us a seamless connection.

speech.para: You people talk as though analog was somehow inferior. Analog has advanced by leaps and bounds since those days. Analog now carries about the same data transmission capability. It can be encrypted. It speaks of service that most people do not want. But the big thing is that in the United States the message is there: where people have the option they have opted for analog because of the longer service. The fact is that analog gives you line of sight. That is why it gets a longer service. When you see these figures put forward they are fictional figures because they talk about phone numbers, not geographical area. Remember this: if Telstra were to go around and put analog services on all the places they have installed digital, there would be an enormous increase in coverage area. It would increase rapidly again. The cost of that is infinitesimal.

talk.start.para: —It's there already.

—Of course it is there already. What we are talking about really is freedom of technology. Let the technology fall where it may. But you have a government guided by Public Service and vested interests that say, `Oh no, we think GSM is the best technology.' It may have been at the time. It has been passed by. But Vodafone only has that technology. Optus only has that technology. Let the technology fall where it may.

speech.para: What I am saying is irrefutable. There is no doubt of that. You cannot disprove what I am saying because it is factual. On that basis, this battle is far from over. This government will turn off analog at its peril. There is going to be a court case. Let us have the court case; let us pay Vodafone out. But they will not get anything like as much as they are expecting if we leave these provisions in the act. Why would we give them this, knowing we are going to litigation? Why would we give these goodies out to them? It makes no sense at all. For this reason the member for Calare (Mr Andren) has done a service to the people of Australia. What the member for Calare is doing is, unlike the member for North Sydney (Mr Hockey), looking at the taxpayers of Australia. We are going to have this battle. There is going to be compensation paid. It will be greatly reduced if we do not give away these goodies now.

There is absolutely no doubt that CDMA technology is better. You cannot keep it out forever. It is only the CDMA technology that gives you the seamless connection. The member for Hinkler (Mr Neville), I think, was talking about the satellite. The cost of the satellite is very high. The service is there now; it is true. It is very expensive. It is all right for mining companies and people in the Aboriginal industry who have their bills paid by the taxpayer. It is no good for the general public. It is a useful tool, but it will not replace the CDMA system. If you have transmission by satellite, it will almost certainly be CDMA anyway. It will be in that format because of that ability to have the seamless connection between analog and the CDMA. You cannot have it with a GSM system. It is simply technically not possible.

Telstra have been working on it and one has to admire Telstra's ability. They say they are looking to double the length to which the GSM signal will go. It is actually going to halve the number of lines available. In remote areas that does not matter. Optus, on the other hand, say, `We are not bothering with that technology, we do not think it will work.'
