It is obviously in some doubt about it, but still it is going to be a very second best option.

For heaven's sake, commonsense says that the system is working, it gives much better coverage, and the only thing it does not really provide is security. Most people do not care about that. I am one of those people. I do not really care who listens to my phone calls because I have got nothing to hide. This is a system working now; it covers a lot of Australia—the CDMA technology which the government is conspiring with the Labor Party to stop entering Australia. They are holding us back by planting the technology. It is meaningless to say we are going to have free enterprise and competition if you keep a rein on the technology, because it is simply within the one paper bag.

talk.start.para: —It's not going to rein in the technology.

—Of course it is because CDMA will not be allowed in this country because the guarantee is that this country will have GSM. I can tell you now that Vodafone and Telstra are terrified of CDMA. They simply do not have the technology. For that reason, the agreement in Australia is that the digital service will be GSM. Why will we be taking the analog out anyway? The answer is simple: we are taking the analog out because GSM cannot compete. It is as simple as that. Don't you understand? We are taking this out because the companies say, `We sold you a pup. We sold you a French system and you bought it, but we cannot make this work against the analog; therefore, you have got to remove the analog.' That is why it is being removed. GSM cannot compete with the digital. If it can, if it is a superior technology, then let the cards fall where they may. Let both play.
—You know that Telstra would dominate the market.

—Telstra gives a good service to remote areas, unlike your friends. It does not matter what you say to your friends. I know Vodafone in your electorate and I know that they look after you very well, but I have to think about the interests of Australia. The fact is that it is simple, it is as clear as day. If the technology is superior, it will beat the analog. It cannot beat the analog, therefore, you must remove it.

speech.para: The people will not cop that. This government at the end of the day will be faced with such outrage that it will back down, it will be faced with litigation, it will be faced with compensation. For heaven's sake, do not give away these trump cards now. If the member for North Sydney cannot understand the logic of that, it is just as well he comes from a legal background, because he never would have survived in business.

I just want to say this: we have heard a lot from this government about the community service obligation and, if the Labor Party were in government, we would hear the same from them. The reality is this—and people in the bush understand this intuitively—if the community service obligation is an off budget payment, if it has left the government, it will diminish and diminish and diminish. They will say, like the member for North Sydney, `But there is no-one out there. There are only a handful of people.' That will be their mentality because what we have in Australia today is a political system where there is no real conflict between Liberal and Labor. You are, as the member for Moore (Mr Filing) said, Tweedledum and Tweedledumber. The real battle developing in Australia is between rural Australia, which creates the wealth, and urban Australia, which spends it. That is the battle that has to be fought in this country and this is part of that battle, because communication is vital in maintaining some sort of equity in this country.

We have seen infrastructure in this country gutted in country areas. We have seen it gutted right through the country. We have seen no real enthusiasm from the present government to restore it. It was gutted by Labor and not restored by this government, and it will not be. There will be continual pressure on infrastructure in the country areas. That is why communication is absolutely vital.

What we are saying is that we know we get a good service with analog. It works over a much wider area. Digital does not work. In my own town of Kalgoorlie, Telstra tells me that they have got the digital coverage. I know, because I live there, that I only have to go out of town on the north side and the coverage ceases. They said, `But we put a system in Coolgardie and now you can get coverage all the way.' They might have much more powerful receivers than I have, because I cannot get that coverage. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have been very interested in some of the comments in this debate and it is good to see the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) here. The member for Kalgoorlie was speaking very passionately this morning in the Main Committee about child support. He was referring to France's child-support arrangements, and I noticed he was just talking about the French system of mobile phones. He obviously must be spending too much time with the member for Holt (Mr Gareth Evans) if he is using the French analogy.

speech.para: The debate today though is about this motion that was moved by the member for Calare (Mr Andren). I think it is important to go back and look at some of the contributions, particularly those by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), the member for Calare and the member for Kalgoorlie. As previous speakers from the coalition side have stated, the whole reason we are in this predicament about analog phones is that the legislation that was put in place was put in place in 1992 by the Australian Labor Party. They put that in place. Not only did they do that, they compounded the problem when it came to pay TV. They legislated to have two cable TV carriers, and an enormous amount of public capital was put in place with Optus and Telstra.

The reason for some of these changes to Vodafone is clear. When you look back at the Optus case, they were forced by legislation—again, that was poor policy by the Australian Labor Party—they did not have enough equity and they had to raise more capital through their British company. The whole indignity here of the Australian Labor Party is that, firstly, this is diminishing the communications systems to rural Australia and, secondly, it is increasing foreign ownership. Let us look at foreign ownership and let us look at foreign debt.

talk.start.para: —Let's look at telephones.

—We will get back to that, but that was the point introduced by the member for Watson. Let us look at the number of companies that were sold. Lifesavers and Allens went to Rowntree. Speedo and Tooheys Castlemaine were sold to New Zealand. King Gee and Stubbies went to the USA. Sidchrome went to the USA. A big chunk of Fairfax media went to Canada. The Ten Network went to Canada. A big chunk of Qantas went to the UK. Other big names to be sold were Brashs, Aeroplane Jelly, Arnotts, BTR Nylex, National Mutual—another French company—Peters ice cream, Eagles and on it goes, particularly in the rural sector and particularly in the telecommunications sector. So do not come in here and parade the virtues of Australian ownership when you have just about sold the whole farm. What we are trying to do is let people who are staying on the farm have a proper communications system to help get them through to the next century.

speech.para: So we come back to AMPS. The decision was made in 1992 by the Australian Labor Party to phase out AMPS by the year 2000. In a very courageous decision on 5 February this year we introduced legislation, and I will quote from the Australian Communications Authority in relation to this. The member for Kalgoorlie should listen to this, as should the member for Calare, because if a review is being done now on Mount Canobolas, the member for Calare should be putting in a submission.

In February 1998 the Australian Communications Authority said that a number of packages were announced for regional Australia which currently receive mobile phone coverage. If they do not receive adequate digital coverage beyond the year 2000, then the analog system will remain and it will remain until there is a proper GSM digital coverage. What could be more appropriate policy—particularly for our rural party and members of the Liberal Party in rural Australia—than ensuring that there are adequate communication facilities, whether you are sitting out the back of Orange, whether you are in Kalgoorlie or whether you are in a suburb of Sydney, but they have pretty good communications systems there already.

talk.start.para: —What about Perth?
—Or in Perth, I should mention that. So some good policy initiatives have been introduced by this government to ensure that regional areas are taken into account.
—Introduced by the Labor Party.
—No, that was not introduced by the Labor Party. That was introduced by us recently.
—You were conned by the Labor Party.
—You were conned. You were in the Labor Party and you voted with them and you have acknowledged that.
—So did you.

—I was not in the Labor Party. I never have been and I never will be. I obviously must have made an impression on the member for Kalgoorlie because he thinks I have been here for a long time, but I only came in at the last election.

speech.para: Let us take on board what was said by the member for Hinkler (Mr Neville). He talked about the actual coverage of analog. It is 93.8 per cent at the moment and digital is 94.1 per cent. I acknowledge that these are not the actual number of people and does not take into account people in remote areas, but the fact is that it is a wider coverage. What we are trying to do is enhance that coverage and make sure that the bush areas that do not have adequate coverage will continue to get coverage beyond the year 2000—whether it is through Vodafone, Optus, Telstra or new carriers that will come into the place—

talk.start.para: —Why not keep analog then?

—We have. We have said that—until they are covered by an adequate GSM system. We have actually said that. Are you blind to it? We have actually done that. If you are a farmer, one of the reasons for digital is that you can get other services. You can get data transfer, you can get the Internet, you can get a whole bunch of stuff—and a lot of it you cannot get on analog. That is why we want a better system. That is why, when we privatised part of Telstra, a big chunk of that—$250 million—went back into building regional telecommunications infrastructure. I suspect, when the next tranche is sold, there will be another commitment to put money back. As the member for Kalgoorlie knows, when the Labor Party was in government—when they privatised Qantas, the Commonwealth Serum Laboratory and the icon, the Commonwealth Bank—it went back into recurrent expenditure.
—Just watch where your old man puts the money then.

—That is a good point. I am glad he is bringing up the history of the coalition. In 1983, when the Labor Party got into power, they reduced a lot of the foreign ownership requirements. Instead of having 51 per cent Australian ownership in the North West Shelf, as you well know, it was the Labor Party that reduced it. That is why we have a lot of foreign carriers here.

speech.para: The member for Hinkler also made some very good points about sovereignty. As the member for Kalgoorlie knows, there is a huge amount of Australian investment and a huge amount of foreign investment in the mining industry—in your industry, Graeme. Your people are working there because of foreign investment. To use Vodafone as a bargaining chip—it is populist; it has a nice ring about it—is poor policy and you cannot just blackmail Vodafone. Can you imagine blackmailing some of your mining companies like that? You cannot do that. That is the problem with it. A policy was put in place by the previous government. Now they are trying to renege on that and trying to use it as a bargaining chip. Let us follow that argument through. Even if you achieve that, if Vodafone maintain this analog system and they do not put in any digital system—

talk.start.para: —They haven't got an analog system.

—That is absolutely correct. Part of the problem is that we want to ensure that we do have proper ownership, proper equity, and that when people come into this country and buy certain slabs there is not an element of sovereign risk. That is precisely the reason why.

speech.para: Mr Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is. Part of the motion—and you should have listened—is that there could be an increase in foreign equity in Vodafone.
—That is restrictive trade practice.

—Perhaps it is, but I would say that if it were tested it would not be successful. As the member for Hinkler said, look at some of the other carriers that are coming into place. It was talked about recently. I know that we can only take Iridium at their word, but they are bringing in a facility at the end of this year. When you look at satellite communications, yes, they are very expensive. No-one is denying that having a CDMA phone is very expensive. But, gentlemen, when you look back to when the computer first came in in 1968 or 1970, the units cost about $10 million. Today the equivalent computer technology—and even the member for Kalgoorlie would recognise this—is about $2,500. So, with the advent of new technology, prices come down. Obviously it is up to the consumer and who actually takes delivery. It is not an argument to say that this new technology, particularly with digital—because that is the main focus at the moment—will not replace some of these systems.

speech.para: A lot of the rationale used today, particularly by the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay), was fairly unintelligible. There were thoughtful comments perhaps, although I think they were misguided, from the member for Calare, and the member for Kalgoorlie represents an enormous constituency, but the fact is that this policy was put in place by the previous government.
Mr Filing interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It was the wrong policy for pay TV. You cannot turn the clock back. That is why I think it is terribly important that, in the next phase of the Telstra sale, we see a large chunk going back into maintaining services. The most important point is that this government has recognised it, because if there are not appropriate services covered by digital by the year 2000 analog will remain.

—It only remains for me to indicate to the House the government's position with regard to the motion moved by the member for Calare (Mr Andren). In the summing up it is not usual to thank honourable members, but I think it has been an interesting debate. If we remove some of the emotion from it, I think that there are lots of issues there and members have had a good opportunity to canvass them.

speech.para: The government takes the view that it will not support Mr Andren's motion. The declaration that he seeks to overturn basically is designed to remove from Vodafone the licence condition requiring it to achieve majority Australian ownership by 1 July 2003. It gives effect to the decision by the Treasurer (Mr Costello) on 14 August last year wherein the government decided to remove, with immediate effect from the date of that announcement, the foreign ownership restrictions that are specific to Optus and Vodafone and that all proposals by foreign interests to invest in Optus and Vodafone would be subject only to the general applicable provisions of foreign investment policy. Essential ly, the application of the contrary-to-the-national-interest test under the Foreign Acquisitions and Takeovers Act would apply.

We considered that it was no longer necessary to constrain foreign involvement in Optus and Vodafone and that, from the point of the announcement of 14 August, foreign involvement of these two entities would be treated the same as cases involving the establishment of new entrants to the telecommunications sector. While prior approval is required, proposals would normally be approved unless judged contrary to the national interest. The government considers that it is important from the competition viewpoint that participants in the telecommunications sector not be unnecessarily constrained by foreign investment regulation. That is the basis of what we are talking about today. That is the reason why this is before the House and why we reject Mr Andren's motion.

I will address some of the points in the broad. The original proposal was in the Telecommunications Act 1991. I have not had the opportunity to re-read my own speeches from that time but, to the best of my recollection, Minister Kelly was the minister who took advice and made the decision that there should be a change and a commitment to a new GSM technology and that we would move progressively to a universal application of the digitalised use of GSM technology by the year 2000. The reason for that was to provide additional competition and better utilisation of the finite resource of the spectrum. There were at the time some concerns about determining technology usage so far out, and I think those of us who voiced concerns at the time have been proved to be correct. Indeed, if the decision by the people of Australia in 1993 had been different, there may well have been an opportunity to have a look at it at that stage.

The legislation in section 70 provided the opportunity for agreements to be entered into between the government and putative carriers. Minister Collins was the minister at the time—1992—who entered into a section 70 agreement. The section 70 agreement—the actual agreement, being a commercial agreement—was not available to the opposition at the time. But we now find ourselves—some years having gone along, Vodafone having been awarded a licence and there being substantial investment for the roll-out to meet the objectives of the 1991 act—in the position where there is a real legal risk that action can be taken under the compensation on just terms arrangements under the acquisitions provisions of the constitution. The extent of the pay-out for these situations is arguable, but if we look at the roll-out of the exclusive digital facility provided by Vodafone it is well over $1 billion.
Mr Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I think it would be nice if you just let me finish, Graeme. That is the reason we are proceeding in the way that we are. The Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston) made the decision last year that we would continue with the commitment to have a universal digitised approach to the mobile phone system, but we made an announcement at that stage that it would be subject to safeguards.

speech.para: That brings me to the next issue that was the subject of discussion by colleagues, that is, the use of the technology. I do not want to enter into a detailed overview of that.

talk.start.para: —You don't know.

—Perhaps I do. The first point I would make is that satellite opportunities, prospectively provided by Iridium, Globalstar, ICO and Elipso will be coming on stream—September this year will see Iridium start—and that will provide an opportunity. The arrangements with regard to the proposed auction in July this year of the spectrum—that is, the 800 megahertz and the 1.8 gigahertz areas—will leave some spectrum. Half the new spectrum will become available to new service providers which will be able to utilise whatever technology they decide. It could be code division multiple access or time division multiple access which will see the capacity for the utilisation of dual handsets which are available now. I think some members have made reference to these matters. The residual amps spectrum in the regional areas will see the emergence of possible dual operation.

speech.para: The other major point was made by my colleague the Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts in his press release of 5 February which recognised that there is a capacity to utilise the amps spectrum in regional and remote Australia in a continuing way beyond the year 2000. It is to be subject to an immediate Australian Communications Authority review—it was described as an urgent review to be completed by 30 June this year—to examine, in each regional area, concurrent services where they currently receive amps service; to determine whether the phase-out of the amps could leave that area without an alternative mobile coverage; and to offer a quality of service and breadth of coverage reasonably equivalent. So the opportunity is to be pursued.

We made known by way of this announcement that, where there cannot be agreement between the carriers for ongoing amps coverage—and remember Vodafone do not have an analog system; they only have a digital system—we will retain for ourselves the capacity to give further directions to existing carriers to mandate that there should be a service in those areas. We will also consider mandating roaming between parts of the GSM networks which are installed under those roll-out obligations if it is technically feasible and commercially appropriate as this may be a very practical way of reducing the cost to the three carriers given the expansion of GSM coverage.

We recognise that there is an issue here. We are looking for a commonsense approach, a practical approach, utilising the emergence of the technologies. The member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) spoke eloquently about these matters. We are looking for some ways in which that can be accommodated within the proposals. I recommend that you look closely at the 5 February statement by the minister. There is an understanding of the issues, particularly in regional and remote Australia, surrounding the utility of the amps systems. As we stand here today we do not know, as the member for Richmond (Mr Anthony) mentioned, the extent to which we will see price movements in the low orbit satellites and the middle orbit satellites in the very near future. That may be a solution that will solve, in part, some of these problems.

I assure honourable members that the minister, the department and I are fully aware of the challenges that the decision in 1991 delivers to this country. Whilst I can understand the approach taken by the member for Calare in his motion, the government could not, in reality, given its need to address the broad responsibilities it has to taxpayers, take a conscious decision which could cause it to enter into litigation which it would be sure to lose and which would have the consequence of an extremely large cost that it would need to bear. For those reasons, the government will not be supporting the motion for disallowance.
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Andren's ) be agreed to.

talk.start.para: —Let us remember what it is that we are dealing with, and I will then conclude my remarks on this piece of legislation, the Workplace Relations Amendment (Superannuation) Bill. What we are dealing with here is a bill which is innocuous in its appearance, but which, for those people who are affected, is very significantly detrimental.

speech.para: This bill says that superannuation is no longer an allowable matter in awards. In future, it may be that most people can enter into arrangements that will put their superannuation arrangements which are not covered by the superannuation guarantee legislation in certified agreements or other such arrangements. Not everybody will, and if time permits, I will come to that. Most evidently, tens of thousands of Australians will be affected. The figure might be more than 100,000, if you could get behind the figures and find all the individual cases. But it is on the record, uncontested, that tens of thousands of low paid Australians will be affected—people working part time and casually in the hospitality industry and the textile, clothing and footwear industry, earning less than $450 a month. These are not fat cats that we are talking about; these are usually second income earners, mainly women, in families, battling to make arrangements that will enable them to assist in funding their and their family's retirement.

If this bill is passed, it will mean that those people will, from 1 July or from when this bill takes effect, lose their superannuation entitlement because they are not covered by the superannuation guarantee legislation, as they earn below the threshold.

Imagine if what we were saying involved an Australian who owned a piece of property and we were going to pass a law and take it away. There would be an outcry. But all the people affected by this are people in weak bargaining positions, otherwise they would not be affected by it. They would be able to get their superannuation rights by virtue of their bargaining strength or under the superannuation guarantee legislation. Tens of thousands of Australians who currently have a legally enforceable entitlement and, each month, have money going into their superannuation account, will all lose.

The government promised that no-one would be worse off. The government promised that no-one would lose their award entitlements. The government promised, `Your superannuation will be secure.' There are tens of thousands of Australians who, under this bill, will lose, and nobody wins.

It is not one of those circumstances where you can say there is a cost benefit. Maybe the benefit to others is such that the loss to these people can be justified. But the problem is that, first and foremost, the losers are the weakest, not the strongest. This is not a case of redistribution by the government in order to try to assist people in the weaker position. This is a case of the weak losing.

The government often talks about the terrible circumstances imposed in industrial relations by powerful unions and portrays themselves as the defenders against the strength of powerful unions. I can tell you that nobody in a strong union, nobody in a strong industrial relations bargaining position, is getting caught under this. It is often the people in very good, well-organised unions but which do not have industrial strength. That is why they are on such low incomes. It is why they have had the award as their underpinning. There has been substantial research done in these two industries where you do not find highly paid workers—the hospitality industries, the clothing, textile and footwear industries—and they are losing.

What worries us is that this is part of the emerging pattern of Australian industrial relations. As regulation is pulled out, what inevitably happens—not just in industrial relations, but that is the matter that we are dealing with at the moment—is that those in the weakest positions lose. As the framework of regulation is withdrawn, as the potential for, in this instance, the Industrial Relations Commission to intervene in the interests of fairness on behalf of those who are not in strong bargaining positions is withdrawn, as we enter into free bargaining, those with the most bargaining power win and those in the weakest positions lose.

If that is the world you are trying to achieve, you should vote for this bill. But if you think that Australians have a broader sense of fairness and there ought to be some protections in place for the weak, the powerless, those who cannot otherwise enforce their rights, you should oppose this bill. As I said, who is losing? Casual workers, part-time workers and, on all the evidence, predominantly women workers, in the main earning less than $450 a month.

People are excluded from the superannuation guarantee legislation for other reasons, not just because they fall below the $450 per month threshold. Sometimes they lose because of age or the nature of their industrial classification. People can and do lose, or do not gain, under the superannuation guarantee legislation, which has been a great leveller, a great equaliser, in superannuation. It has done a lot of good, but it cannot solve all the problems. This bill is saying, `If you don't get caught under that act, too bad.'

The other side is to say that superannuation is no longer an industrial relations matter which the Industrial Relations Commission is entitled to arbitrate. It cannot make an award about this. So in the circumstances where there is a dispute about superannuation, the Industrial Relations Commission will not be in the circumstance to resolve it. This is not a new matter; this is a matter we have been drawing to the government's attention since it first proposed to withdraw superannuation from allowable matters for awards in the first half of 1996.

It is now nearly two years that we have been saying, why is it, given that the guarantee that was given in the pre-election policy called Better Pay for Better Work explicitly stated that existing award superannuation entitlements would be guaranteed minimum for all workplace agreements, that, under that circumstance, none of these 26,000 employees, or others in similar circumstances who entered into a workplace agreement, will be guaranteed any superannuation benefits at all? Many employees, especially those with little or no bargaining power, will suffer a manifest injustice.

You cannot pass a law to say that there should not be any disputes about certain matters. Disputes arise when employers and employees cannot agree, and Australia has a traditional method of reconciling those disputes, that is, in the Industrial Relations Commission, and their findings can be and often are incorporated in awards.

Where is the mischief that is caused by superannuation being an allowable award matter? Where is the crisis that is emerging? Where is the damage that is being suffered? Even if you read the arguments of the advocates, what they say is, `This ought to be done by agreement or ought to be left to the superannuation guarantee legislation.' Some people fall through the cracks in the superannuation guarantee legislation, excellent legislation that it is. I am glad the Liberal Party finally gave up its opposition to it and allowed it to continue. It is excellent legislation and a very important part of increasing savings in Australia and improving the equity of access to superannuation. It has transformed superannuation in this country.

The government has other measures which are going to undermine it, make it worse, fragment it and deny access to lower income Australians, but they are not before us in this bill. The package of them will make superannuation less fair in this country. It will make low income Australians and low income Australian families less secure in their retirement. It will take away, for no benefit and for no advantage to any other Australians, the rights of these people. It is a very strange concept. It is not something that I thought anybody came into this parliament to do, that is, to say, `I have a clever idea. I'm going to pass a law to take away some of your rights.' But that is what we are doing here. We are doing it explicitly in breach of the commitment which the government made before the election in Better Pay for Better Work and in speeches by the Prime Minister (Mr Howard), then the Leader of the Opposition.

If you had to sum up what Australian working people felt about superannuation, what they would say is, `Stop changing the system. There have been too many changes already. Let it remain as it is. It is complex, but we know what our entitlements are now. Stop changing the system.' But this government cannot stop fiddling. There will be other legislation to follow this legislation. I say: do not pass this legislation, which achieves no positive purpose. All it does is take away legitimate rights and aspirations from low income Australians, for no benefit, and it should accordingly be rejected.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the amendments be agreed to.

The Productivity Commission Bill 1996 was passed by the Senate on Monday, 30 March 1998 after the Senate had made a relatively large number of amendments. In particular, amendments have been made to the functions of the commission provisions, clause 6; the general policy guidelines for the commission, clause 8; the commissioner appointment provisions, clause 30; the meetings of the commission provisions, clause 43; and the engagement of the consultants provision, clause 49. While some of the amendments are significant, the government considers that overall the amendments do not affect the integrity of the bill. Hence, the government accepts the Senate's amendments.

Parliamentary consideration of the bill has been both slow and difficult. The government is keen to complete the process so that the commission can settle down and focus on promoting policies at both the government and business levels to improve the competitiveness and dynamism of the Australian industry. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —We will not be opposing the amendments which have been put forward, which strike us as neither improving nor diminishing the legislation or the operations of the Productivity Commission generally. We want to place on the record that the opposition has not seen the Productivity Commission as the most appropriate vehicle for conducting industry policy. Indeed, a resolution was carried at the Labor Party National Conference in Hobart in January of this year to the effect that a Labor government would abolish the Productivity Commission. That was certainly a resolution that I was happy to support.

speech.para: Applying the Productivity Commission's own yardstick to these matters, it takes the view that any industries which are not world's best practice and are not seen to be efficient, effective and productive ought to be put out to pasture. In recent times, the Productivity Commission has delivered reports on the future of the motor vehicle industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear industry. Those reports have been rejected by the government. They have been rejected by the government because the Labor opposition, employers, unions and state governments mounted a concerted campaign against those recommendations, which were out of step with the need for Australia to have a modern manufacturing industry.

Those recommendations would have led to the demise of the motor vehicle industry and the textiles, clothing and footwear industries in this country, with the loss of many jobs and to some extent the loss of national sovereignty—our capacity to produce the things which sustain us and make us prosper. Those recommendations were of very little value. The Howard government—under sustained pressure, let me say—decided to reject those recommendations.

If the best that the Productivity Commission can come up with is recommendations which get rejected, it does not seem to us that it has much of a future. That is Labor's view concerning the Productivity Commission. Having said those things, as I said, these amendments are not in and of themselves controversial and, therefore, we will not be opposing them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be here tonight to see the government agree to these amendments that have come from the Senate. These are very important amendments that have been made to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Youth Allowance) Bill 1997 which will see significant improvements made to the youth allowance.

speech.para: I am sorry to say that the most important amendments moved by Labor in the Senate were rejected by this government. Those amendments were to maintain the age of independence for unemployed young people at 18. Young people will now be treated as dependent on their parents until they reach the age of 21. This is a very retrograde step for young people, who are trying to make the best of it out there in a very difficult employment market and finding it very hard to get a job. They are now being told by this government that, if their parents earn more than $23,500, their unemployment benefits will be reduced. This will see significant disruptions emerge in families.

But, on the positive side, there are some improvements in this legislation as a result of the amendments that we are now considering. As I said, it is pleasing that the government has decided to accept them. We had a series of provisions in the bill when it was before the House and before the Senate that would have seen unemployed people and students face a whole range of different notification provisions. Anyone having had anything to do with the Department of Social Security would know how important it is to have clear requirements rather than rules saying in one instance that you could be notified in writing and in another that you could be notified orally. Some of these rules required seven days, others 14 days. Frankly, it was a mess. As a result of the amendments moved by the opposition, this has now been cleaned up. People will now have notifications sent out in writing and be given 14 days notice. That is a significant improvement.

Another amendment that is also very important and which we on the Labor side are very pleased about is that young people who are unemployed and under the age of 18 will now be able to receive unemployment benefits—if they are willing and able to partici pate in case management. We did not want to see a situation where young people who, for whatever reason, would not or could not go back to school found themselves without any means of support. It is very significant that the government has decided to accept this amendment, to ensure that young people under the age of 18 who are unemployed and for whatever reason cannot go back to school will in fact be helped to get work. That is the critical issue: they want to work. They need to be helped to get work and not be left with absolutely nothing—which was, of course, the original intention of the government.

The Labor opposition also moved an amendment in relation to the age of independence for students. We moved, and got a commitment from the Senate, that the independence age for students should be progressively reduced from 25 over time. The age of 25 for students is unrealistic and it is a commitment that I know students will be very pleased to see. There is also a very important change to the rules about work attachment when determining whether or not a young person is independent. The government originally said that a young person had to have worked for 18 months since leaving school, and to have earned 50 per cent of average weekly earnings in that period. That was a completely unrealistic expectation to put on young people, given the job opportunities that are out there and the wages that are paid to young people these days. What this amendment does is soften the criterion so that a person now needs to have earned the lower amount, represented by 75 per cent of the maximum Commonwealth training award. (Extension of time granted)

These changes are very significant and important and, as I said, I am very pleased that the government has seen fit to make these amendments. Most unfortunately, the most significant amendment was rejected by the government. It was about the issue of the age of independence for young unemployed people. It is not the case that families with incomes between $23,500 and $42,000 are well off, as the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) likes to say. They are not well off and families with an income of $35,000, with young unemployed adults aged between 18 and 20 in them, will, from 1 July, be $55 a week worse off. Young unemployed people will find themselves $55 a week shorter in their unemployment benefits and having to front up to mum and dad, who do not have a high family income, to get the money out of them.

Not surprisingly, parents of adults expect those young people to be out there supporting themselves—out there in the work force, trying to make the best of it and trying to earn their own living. The reason we pay unemployment benefits is that these young people cannot find a job.

As we know, this government has not moved youth unemployment rates at all. They are stuck at 26 per cent, and this measure is not going to do anything whatsoever to improve youth unemployment. All it is going to do is make families worse off, make family relationships more difficult and make life for young unemployed people that much more difficult.

It is a measure which the government should reconsider. We would call upon them to come back into the parliament as soon as possible to reduce the age of independence for young unemployed people to recognise that these people are independent and that they do not live in families that can afford to see their family incomes reduced by anything from $55 to over $80 a week. That is just putting the burden of unemployment on to low and middle income families. That is what this government is all about with this measure that we are debating again tonight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Ordered that the bill be taken into consideration forthwith.
Unresolved question—
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —in reply—I would just like to make some summing up comments on the debate which has been held on this matter. I would like to express the government's appreciation for the report tabled on 12 March by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, report No. 356, entitled An advisory report on the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 . It is the fifth by the committee on the rewriting of the income tax law, and the fourth which specifically covers the tax law improvement project. The joint committee's ongoing involvement in the review of the work of the project has been important in ensuring the quality of the rewrite and public confidence in the rewrite process.

speech.para: The government is accepting all of the committee's recommendations for technical changes to the bill. The government has also made changes to the explanatory memorandum along the lines recommended by the committee. There is a table in the supplementary explanatory memorandum setting out these changes to the bill and explanatory memorandum. The government is considering other recommendations in report No. 356 that go to wider policy matters and will provide responses on those other matters later on.

I would like to underline the importance the government attaches to the work of the tax law improvement project and our desire that this bill—the third instalment of the rewrite—be passed by 30 June so that it can start to apply for the 1998-99 income year. The joint committee supports this commencement date.

The main feature of the bill is the rewritten capital gains tax rules. They are much clearer than the existing law and contain positive changes that taxpayers should be able to benefit from as early as possible. The bill also contains rewrites of the provisions about intellectual property, company bad debts, horticultural plants, environmental expenditure, the averaging of primary producers' tax liabilities and evening out the effects of the above average income of some professionals. These rewrites also include some minor policy changes which will help to make the law simpler, clearer and less burdensome for the taxpayers.

I would like to underline the thanks of the government to the people who have been working on this Tax Law Improvement Bill. It has been going on for quite a substantial amount of time, and a lot of work is going into this. I am sure it will make it much more
readable and understandable to those people who need to read it. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

para.inline: 126-85 Effect of roll-over on certain liquidations

subdebate.1.para: (1) A *capital gain or *capital loss a company (the holding company ) makes because *shares in its *100% subsidiary are cancelled (an example of *CGT event C2: see section 104-25) on the liquidation of the subsidiary is reduced if the conditions in subsection (2) are satisfied. The reduction is worked out under subsection (3).
(2) These conditions must be satisfied:

(a) there must be a roll-over under this Subdivision for at least one *CGT asset (the CGT roll-over asset ) being *disposed of by the subsidiary to the holding company in the course of the liquidation of the subsidiary;
(b) the subsidiary must have acquired each CGT roll-over asset on or after 20 September 1985;
(c) the disposals must either:
(i) be part of the liquidator's final distribution in the course of the liquidation; or
(ii) have occurred within 18 months of the dissolution of the subsidiary if they are part of an interim distribution in the course of the liquidation;

(d) the holding company must have beneficially owned all of the shares in the subsidiary for the whole period from the time of the disposal, or the first disposal, of a CGT roll-over asset until the cancellation of the shares;

(e) the market value of the CGT roll-over asset or assets must comprise at least part of the *capital proceeds for the cancellation of the shares in the subsidiary that are beneficially owned by the holding company;
(f) one or more of the shares that were cancelled (the post-CGT shares ) must have been acquired by the holding company on or after 20 September 1985.
(3) The reduction of the *capital gain or *capital loss is worked out in this way.
Step 1. Work out (disregarding this section) the sum of the *capital gains and the sum of the *capital losses the holding company would make on the cancellation of its shares in the subsidiary.

Step 2. Work out (disregarding this Subdivision) the sum of the *capital gains and the sum of the *capital losses the subsidiary would make on the *disposal of its CGT roll-over assets to the holding company in the course of the liquidation assuming the *capital proceeds were the assets' market values at the time of the disposal.
Step 3. If, after subtracting the sum of the *capital losses from the sum of the *capital gains, there is:
(a) an overall capital gain from Step 1 and an overall capital gain from Step 2; or
(b) an overall capital loss from Step 1 and an overall capital loss from Step 2;
then continue. Otherwise there is no adjustment.
Step 4. Express the number of post-CGT shares as a fraction of the total number of shares the holding company owned in the subsidiary.
Step 5. Multiply the overall *capital gain or *capital loss from Step 2 by the fraction from Step 4.

Step 6. Reduce the overall *capital gain or *capital loss from Step 1 by the amount from Step 5. The result is the *capital gain or *capital loss the holding company makes from the cancellation of its shares in the subsidiary.
Note: This Subdivision is modified in calculating the attributable income of a CFC: see section 419 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 .

subdebate.1.para: Parts 3-1 and 3-3 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (about capital gains and capital losses) apply to assessments for the 1998-99 income year and later income years.

para.inline: 102-5 Working out capital gains and capital losses

subdebate.1.para: (1) In working out whether you have made a capital gain or a capital loss from a CGT event that happens in relation to a CGT asset in the 1998-99 income year or a later income year, you use only the provisions of Parts 3-1 and 3-3 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (or a provision of an Act that modifies the operation of those Parts) unless a provision of this Part or Part 3-3 of this Act also requires you to use another provision.

Note 1: This means that, for example, in working out your cost base of the asset, you will apply the new law to circumstances that occurred before the 1998-99 income year (except where this Act requires you to use another provision).
Note 2: In most cases, the other provision is a provision of this Act. However, in some cases, other provisions may be relevant (for example, provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 ).
Note 3: Part X of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 includes provisions that modify the operation of Parts 3-1 and 3-3 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 .

(a) an entity acquired a CGT asset before the start of the 1998-99 income year as part of a transaction or event or series of transactions or events in respect of which there was a same-asset roll-over or replacement-asset roll-over under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 ; and
(b) the entity owned the asset just before the start of that income year; and
(c) a CGT event happens in relation to the asset in that income year or a later one;

the provisions of Parts 3-1 and 3-3 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 apply to the asset from the time when the roll-over happened except that the first element of the cost base and reduced cost base of the asset (when the roll-over happened) is the amount the entity is taken to have paid as consideration in respect of the acquisition of the asset under the relevant provision of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 .

(1) In working out whether you have a net capital gain for the 1998-99 income year, the amount of any net capital loss for the 1997-98 income year or an earlier income year must be worked out under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 .

(2) If you had a net capital loss for the 1997-98 income year, or some unapplied net capital loss for either of the 2 preceding income years, under Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 , it can be carried forward to a later income year to be applied under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 .
Note: The way in which capital losses can be applied may be affected by other provisions: see section 102-30 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 .

(3) If you had a net listed personal-use asset loss for the 1997-98 income year under Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 , it is taken for the purposes of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to be a net capital loss from collectables for that income year.

para.inline: 130-60 Shares or units acquired by converting a convertible note

subdebate.1.para: (1) The modification in item 1 of the table in subsection 130-60(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 does not apply to shares or units in a unit trust you acquire by converting a convertible note (that is a traditional security) that you acquired after 10 May 1989 and before 16 August 1989. Instead, the first element of the cost base and reduced cost base of the shares or units is the sum of:
(a) what you paid or gave to acquire the note; and
(b) any amount you paid in relation to the conversion;
if that sum is more than the market value of the shares or units (at the time of conversion).

(2) The modification in item 2 of the table in subsection 130-60(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 does not apply to shares you acquire by converting a convertible note (that is not a traditional security) that you acquired before 20 September 1985 where you paid or gave something in relation to the conversion. Instead, the first element of the cost base and reduced cost base of the shares is the sum of:
(a) the market value of the note at the time of the conversion; and
(b) what you paid or gave in relation to the conversion.

(3) Subsection 130-60(2) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 does not apply to the acquisition of shares by the conversion of a convertible note that you acquired before 20 September 1985 if you did not pay or give anything in relation to the conversion. Instead, you are taken to have acquired them when you acquired the convertible note.
(1) This Subdivision applies to shares, or rights to acquire shares, you acquired under an employee share scheme if:

(1) A capital gain or a capital loss a trustee makes when a beneficiary becomes absolutely entitled to a share or right in a company is disregarded if these conditions are satisfied.
(2) The beneficiary must be:
(a) a PAYE earner of the company or of another company (at the time the beneficiary first became beneficially entitled to the share or right); or
(b) an associate or affiliate company of such a PAYE earner.
(3) The terms of the trust must have required or authorised the trustee to transfer the share or right to the PAYE earner or associate.
(4) The PAYE earner or associate must not have acquired the share or right for more than the cost base of the share or right (in the hands of the trustee) at the time of the transfer.

(5) There must have been an acquisition of a share or a right to acquire a share by the PAYE earner or associate under a scheme for the acquisition of shares by employees to which section 26AAC of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 applies.
A capital gain or capital loss a trustee makes from transferring a right to acquire shares in a company to an individual is disregarded if:

(a) the individual dies and an amount is included in the assessable income of the trustee of the deceased's estate under subsection 26AAC(9) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as a result of that trustee acquiring shares because of the exercise or operation of the right; and

(b) the deceased acquired the right under a trust the trustee of which is required or authorised to transfer shares in a company to employees of the company or another company or to relatives of those employees; and
(c) the deceased did not acquire the right for more than the right's cost base (in the hands of the trustee) at the time of the transfer.
Section 170 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 does not prevent the amendment of an assessment at any time for the purpose of giving effect to this Subdivision.

subdebate.1.para: A CGT asset a company owns has the necessary connection with Australia if:

para.inline: Schedule 2—Net capital losses and the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997
Effect of transferring a net capital loss
170-110 When a corporation can transfer a net capital loss

subdebate.1.para: (1) A transferring corporation within the meaning of the Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Act 1993 (the loss company ) can transfer an amount of its *net capital loss for an income year of the loss company (the capital loss year ) to a receiving corporation within the meaning of that Act (the gain company ) if the conditions in this Subdivision are met.
(2) The amount transferred can be the whole or part of the *net capital loss.
Note: A PDF cannot transfer a net capital loss, except one for a period before it became a PDF: see section 195-30 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 .

(3) However, the *loss company cannot transfer so much of the *net capital loss as the loss company has applied, or can apply, in working out its *net capital gain or *net capital loss for an income year before the one in which the amount is transferred.

(1) If an amount of a *net capital loss is transferred, the gain company can apply the amount in working out its *net capital gain for the income year of the gain company for which the amount is transferred or for a later income year. The income year for which the gain company applies the amount is called the application year .
Note: A company's net capital gain or net capital loss for an income year is usually worked out under section 102-5.
(2) The loss company can no longer apply the transferred amount and is taken not to have made the *net capital loss to the extent of that amount.

para.inline: 170-120 Gain company is taken to have made transferred loss

subdebate.1.para: (1) If an amount of a *net capital loss is transferred, the amount is taken to be a *net capital loss of the gain company for the capital loss year.
(2) However, if the capital loss year is the same as the application year, the amount is taken to be a *capital loss of the gain company for the application year.

para.inline: 170-125 Tax treatment of consideration for transferred tax loss

subdebate.1.para: (1) If the loss company receives consideration from the gain company for the transferred amount:
(a) the consideration is neither assessable income nor exempt income of the loss company; and
(b) the loss company does not make a *capital gain because of receiving the consideration.
Note: However, the consideration may affect how section 170-175 modifies the cost base of direct and indirect interests in the loss company.
(2) If the gain company gives consideration to the loss company for the transferred amount:
(a) the gain company cannot deduct the consideration; and
(b) the gain company does not make a *capital loss because of giving the consideration.
Note: However, the consideration may affect how section 170-175 modifies the cost base of direct and indirect interests in the gain company.
170-128 Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Act 1993 must apply to asset transfer from loss company to gain company
If it were assumed that:

(a) an asset (within the meaning of the Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Act 1993) had been transferred by the loss company to the gain company on the last day of a particular income year of the loss company (the notional transfer year ); and
(b) the requirements of paragraphs 7(6)(a) and (b) of that Act were satisfied in relation to that transfer;
then it must be the case that that Act would have applied to that transfer.
The *loss year must be either:
(a) the income year in which the Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Act 1993 commenced; or
(b) an earlier income year.
(1) The *transfer year must either:
(a) end at the end of the *notional transfer year; or
(b) correspond to the income year of the *loss company that next follows the *notional transfer year.
(2) Also, the *transfer year must be one of the 5 income years after the income year in which the Financial Corporations (Transfer of Assets and Liabilities) Act 1993 commenced.
(1) It must be the case that the loss company was not required to calculate the *net capital loss:
(a) under section 165-114 (because of a change in ownership or control); or
(b) under section 175-75 (because of an injected capital gain or loss).

(2) Also, it must be the case that neither Subdivision 165-CA nor Subdivision 175-CA would have prevented the loss company from applying the *net capital loss in working out its *net capital gain for the application year if it had made enough capital gains in that year.
Note 1: Subdivision 165-CA deals with the consequences of changing ownership or control of a company. Subdivision 175-CA deals with using a company's net capital losses to avoid income tax.
Note 2: A company's net capital gain or net capital loss for an income year is usually worked out under section 102-5.

(1) If the capital loss year and the application year are not the same, the gain company must not be prevented by Subdivision 165-CA or 175-CA from applying the transferred amount in working out its *net capital gain for the application year.
Note 1: Subdivision 165-CA deals with the consequences of changing ownership or control of a company. Subdivision 175-CA deals with using a company's net capital losses to avoid income tax.
Note 2: A company's net capital gain or net capital loss for an income year is usually worked out under section 102-5.

(2) If the capital loss year and the application year are the same, it must be the case that the gain company was not required to calculate its own *net capital gain or *net capital loss for the application year:
(a) under Subdivision 165-CB (because of a change in ownership or control); or
