talk.start.para: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 7) 1997 contains a large number of unrelated taxation matters, including in particular relating to the introduction of the new government savings rebate scheme, on which I will have something to say, together with a major proposed change to the superannuation system, known as the `choice regime', on which I will have rather less to say, leaving the primary carriage of this to the shadow parliamentary secretary, the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson).

speech.para: This debate takes place against the background of the so-called tax reform debate taking place in Australia at the moment. I say `so-called' because there is no debate really taking place, and that is for the reason that the government, specifically the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), refuse to participate in one. As recently as Wednesday, the Treasurer specifically refused to debate me in this House on the question of what the government was going to do about the growing use of trusts for tax avoidance purposes, leaving it to honourable members rather lower down the food chain to defend the government's honour in this respect. The Treasurer refused an invitation from the ABC—not for the first time—to debate with me again the same issue last week on the 7.30 Report.

It is a fair question as to why the government will not come clean on this issue. Why has the promised discussion paper on the taxation of trusts been suppressed? Is it because so many coalition frontbenchers have trusts? Is it because so many coalition backbenchers have trusts and there would be a party room revolt if the government were to do something decent and effective about tax avoidance in this area? Is it because of some other deal that we know nothing about?

We have the ludicrous situation where these two leaders, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of the government, are constantly denigrating Australia's tax system generally through false claims or wild exaggerations of the scale of particular problems, yet they absolutely refuse to tell us what they are planning to do. What they are engaged in is a concerted effort to falsely worry Australian businessmen and families that the Australian taxation system is broken. We know, and we have certainly argued, that that is patently untrue. The truth of the matter is that the tax system is in very much better shape than it was when Labor came into power in the early 1980s. Then it was fair to say that the tax system really was broken, and it was broken because of the negligent stewardship of the then Treasurer, the current Prime Minister.

It was not broken because the necessities of life—food, clothing, shelter and utility services—were exempt from tax. Rather, it was broken because paying tax was optional for those with access to specialist taxation advice. Then Treasurer Howard refused to act for years on the taxation advice provided by Tax Commissioner O'Reilly. He was, to put it at its most charitable, asleep at the wheel or, rather worse, and I suspect more accurately, he was deliberately protecting a small minority of the community.

The problems we confronted after 1983 when we came into office were, as a consequence of that, quite enormous. For a start, capital gains were generally quite outside the tax net. As a result, quite literally, the rich could get richer without any contribution being made to the general community. It did fall to Labor to address that glaring anomaly, and we did so. What was the coalition's response to that issue? It was to oppose passage of the capital gains tax tooth and nail.

When the present Prime Minister was campaigning in the 1987 election as the then Leader of the Opposition, he proposed to abolish capital gains tax and to substitute a paltry so-called speculative gains tax which only taxed gains made on assets bought and sold within a year. It was only when Dr Hewson became opposition leader that the conservative side of politics was brought to the grudging and reluctant acceptance that a capital gains tax is an essential part of an equitable, modern taxation system.

The second area where the tax system in this country was genuinely broken when we came into office was in the area of fringe benefits. The law as it then existed attempted to include the value of non-cash benefits, but it was a joke to the tax planning industry. The provision could be avoided effortlessly, and it was consistently. This meant that executives could arrange their affairs to pay little or no income tax whereas their employees had to pay tax on all of their wages. In present value, billions of dollars of income avoided tax. It did fall to Labor again to fix that disgraceful anomaly. Again, the coalition, under the leadership of the present Prime Minister, opposed that progressive and equitable reform.

Fortunately, the efforts of the coalition were unsuccessful in stopping real tax reform on those occasions, but it was not for want of trying. It should be recalled for the record that, on occasions like this when we succumb to daily bouts of hypocrisy on the subject of the present tax system, the coalition also subsequently opposed the raft of foreign source income measures which brought foreign income earned by Australians into the tax net for the first time. They also opposed the clampdown on the use of tax havens and a number of other measures which have massively increased the fairness of the current tax system. All of those reforms were achieved—it is important to emphasise— without having to resort to the punishment of ordinary families when they do their shopping or pay their bills, as will of course happen under a GST.

This objective of the Prime Minister's is despite the fact that prior to the last election he promised, in language that leaves absolutely no room for wriggle, that a GST would not be the future policy of the coalition. I think it is worth reading into the record what he said in that famous or—perhaps better—notorious doorstop at Tweed Heads on 2 May 1995:
JOURNALIST: So you've left the door open for a GST now, haven't you?
HOWARD: No, there's no way a GST will ever be part of our policy.
JOURNALIST: Never, ever?
HOWARD: Never ever. It's dead. It was killed by the voters at the last election.
JOURNALIST:—
he was a very indefatigable journalist—
Were you misquoted in today's Australian then?

HOWARD: Well, any suggestion that I left the door open is absolute nonsense. I didn't. I never will. The last election killed the GST. It's not part of our policy and it won't be part of our policy at any time in the future.
JOURNALIST: If the concept of the GST comes up in the polls . . . would you go back and revisit that area, or look at it again?
HOWARD: No . . . No, because we are against it . . . It is absolutely out of the question.

A wry smile from the honourable member for Adelaide (Ms Worth) opposite. The truth of the matter is that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, in committing themselves to this particular `reform' of the tax system, are acting absolutely against what they said their stated policy was in an absolutely unprecedented way.

A truly amazing thing about the current situation is that while the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are trying to build up a false case against the current system, arguing its decrepitude and unworkability, they do steadfastly refuse to detail what they intend to propose to the Australian people. They are running around saying, `The system is broke. It's terrible.' But they refuse to spell out even in broad terms what they are planning to do. They still refuse to admit what is supremely self-evident—that the main objective, the central objective, of their agenda is the introduction of a comprehensive GST.

We have had a tax task force secretly meeting since last August. We have established that it has already spent over $1.2 million of public money, yet it keeps no record of its meetings. It meets without having formal agendas. All of the work that it produces, most importantly, is kept secret by the government. We know that the identification of the various options has already been completed. If the Treasurer is interested in a genuine, well-informed public tax debate all he has to do is release that information that has been generated by the task force, paid for with taxpayers' money, so that the community can evaluate the real options that are available.

It is not necessarily a matter of putting down at this stage the government's own preferred approach to this, desirable as that would be. The most important thing is simply for the range of options that has already been generated, costed and quantified by the task force to be made public. Then the full range of those options can be known by the community. The worthiness of the government's package can be judged in its proper context, if and when it is released. Why is the government afraid of this process? Why don't we have an open, inclusive process, as we did in 1985, with the publication of a substantial draft white paper canvassing various options?

The reason is, I suggest, that the government knows that its agenda simply will not stack up under detailed scrutiny. They know that the unfairness inherent in their basic objectives cannot be hidden. It certainly cannot be hidden if the facts are on the table for an extended period. So they refuse to put that information into the public arena. They want it out at the last possible moment. It is a clear strategy to avoid a real debate. It is not to engage in one. The government really does stand condemned for its cynicism.

Looking at the particular provisions of this bill, which, as I say, are introduced against that background but do not tell us much what the ultimate tax package is going to be, there are a number of major proposals contained in the bill. I will quickly go through them, spending most time on the first, because it is the most substantial—the savings rebate. This was announced in the 1997-98 budget as a really, I have to say, pathetic substitute for Labor's national superannuation co-contribution regime, which was abandoned at the same time in that budget. The savings rebate is really a savings option in the context of that last budget. It certainly does not constitute a net gain to the vast majority of working Australians. Rather, it is an enormous future cost.

Moreover, the abandonment of co-contribution was a deliberate repudiation of the solemn commitment that was given by this government prior to the last election that it would in fact honour the co-contribution proposed by Labor. Unless anyone is in doubt about that, let me quote from a speech by the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Costello, the member for Higgins, to the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia on 2 November 1995. He said:

We will deliver the full tax dollars earmarked by the Budget back into superannuation or like savings vehicles on the schedule set down. We reserve the right to vary the mechanism to provide the most effective and equitable delivery of these dollars. Further details will be made known during the election period. But they will be paid in full.
Minor variations, possibly, yes. Basic concept, basic dollars, clearly there committed.

It was a classic example of a non-core promise, as we have come to understand all too unhappily in so many other contexts—promises strongly delivered then abandoned when it is convenient to do so. Other people call them by their proper name, that is, broken promises—nothing more and nothing less than that. The crucial thing is that this particular deception of the Australian people is coming at a tremendous cost. The co-contribution was a visionary plan which would have massively increased the retirement income of future generations of Australians. It would have delivered security in retirement and would also have delivered Australia a huge increase in national savings in the future.

On the first aspect of it, increasing security in retirement, the superannuation guarantee scheme, which will deliver superannuation contributions of nine per cent of people's income when it is fully implemented, is itself a tremendous base for adequate retirement income for average Australians. Even that was voted against by the coalition, just as they voted against any other decent reform in recent years. However, what needed to happen was the supplementation of that nine per cent base with another six per cent, three plus three, in order to provide completely adequate retirement income. That is exactly what the co-contribution regime was designed to do, and that is why its abandonment is such a tragedy for the Australian community.

The effect of this has been estimated by the Commonwealth's retirement incomes modelling task force, or RIM task force, which estimated that a worker who was 35 years old in 1994-95 earning average weekly ordinary time earnings and who retires at age 65 would have had a superannuation benefit under our scheme of around $280,000 in real terms. However, without the benefit of the co-contribution regime, with its abandonment, that worker's final benefit will not be $280,000 but only $170,000 in the same dollars.

This decision has cost that particular worker and millions of others around 40 per cent of his or her final retirement benefit and significantly reduced the standard of living capable of enjoyment by such workers in retirement. The fact that all of this has not been really widely understood in the community is absolutely no excuse for this appalling decision.

The second area of lost opportunity in the government's decision here was the effect of that decision on the future level of national savings, which has just been devastating. With the Asian crisis about to beset us, indicating a very serious current account deficit problem in the future, it is even more vital that the level of national savings be maintained and that the whole burden of doing so not fall on public savings through the budget.

The estimate by the RIM task force was that the co-contribution would have increased aggregate national savings by $400 billion over and above what it otherwise would have been by the year 2020. By this time it would have been increasing the level of national savings around two per cent of GDP per annum. We would have benefited both those in retirement and we would have benefited the nation by significantly increasing the pool of domestic savings, increasing the funds available of course for domestic investment and job creation.

Instead of all that—and it has all been abandoned—we have now this savings tax offset known as the savings rebate. It will provide a rebate of 15 per cent of the tax that would otherwise be payable on up to $3,000 worth of non-salary and wage income earned after 1 July 1999. Non-deductible superannuation contributions do also qualify for this rebate, with a 7½ per cent rate applying for this 1998-99 year.

The greatest irony, indeed tragedy, about the savings rebate is that it has little or nothing to do with improving savings. It really has nothing to do with increasing national savings nor with rewarding Australians in any very direct way for increasing their savings. It is, in fact, a subsidy to be paid to people who are deriving unearned income. If you work as an employee and receive salary or wages then you pay normal tax. But if you get considerable unearned income or business income, then you will get the benefit of this particular rebate, enabling you to pay $450 less tax a year.

Ordinary employees, as a result, not only lose the higher level of retirement income that our co-contribution scheme would have delivered; they will also generally not qualify for the full $450. That is because the average interest earned by something over five million taxpayers, I understand, is less than $150 a year. If this were the only source of non-salary and wage income, as it is for most people—earnings of interest and so on of that order of magnitude—then what you are talking about is only a savings rebate of around $22.50 or less than 50c a week, and only half of that for good measure in this current year of 1998-99.

To pretend that the savings rebate is a major benefit to most people is quite simply a joke in bad taste. It is a device which lowers the tax for all types of unearned income—interest, dividends, trust and partnership distributions, rent and so on—and for superannuation pensions and eligible termination payments. It rewards people who are living off their savings rather than rewarding people for engaging in saving, other than—and there is an exception—in the case of direct superannuation contributions.

The critical thing to understand about all this is that it can actually reward people who are engaged in dis-saving. On the assumption that people are earning, say, six per cent on the long-term bond rate on their savings at the moment, that means that so long as you have $50,000 invested somewhere you will be generating the $3,000 of unearned income which will enable you to receive the full rebate. That means, for example, if you started a year with $75,000 invested and ran down that capital so that at the end of the year you only had $50,000—in other words, if you dis-saved to the tune of $25,000—you could still collect the full $450 rebate. This is absolutely absurd and the second reading amendment that I will be moving at the conclusion of my remarks points up that particular absurdity.

We have previously established in Senate estimates that the savings rebate will not result in an increase in national savings, according to the government's own retirement incomes modelling task force. That is an issue that we will be further pursuing and fleshing out in the Senate when this legislation gets there. The cost of the savings rebate to budget is large. It is rising to over $2 billion in the year 2000-01; presumably it will grow still further in future years. One would have thought that the government would have been very proud of such an initiative. In fact the reverse was true. It will be remembered that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was so embarrassed that he would qualify for the full rebate that he announced in fact to this parliament on the day after the budget last year that he would not be claiming it.

However, the problem for him became that the savings rebate will be calculated automatically. There is no provision for him not to claim the benefit. Indeed, advice from the bureaucracy indicated that to create a system that would allow the Prime Minister or anyone else to opt out would have cost some millions of dollars in administrative costs. Even though he knows it is unfair—knows it so well that he got up in public and said that he would not accept it—the Prime Minister will in fact benefit from this provision. That is why we consider not only this whole thing to be a nonsense but also that, if it was to be applied at all, it should certainly have been done on the basis of a decent means test. Again, my second reading amendment goes to this point.

Despite the measure being considered unfair by Labor, as it was and still is—that is, only rewarding those with savings related income—the savings rebate was in fact the centrepiece of last year's budget. We take the view that opposition to it in this place, or more significantly in the Senate, is inconsistent with Labor's general position that governments are entitled to their major budget measures, however wrong-headed those measures might be. Accordingly I do indicate now that the opposition does not propose to oppose this measure. We think it is very bad policy. We think it is a disgrace, certainly, compared with the company-contribution regime that it replaced. However, it is the government's measure for better or worse and we will not oppose it.

I cannot let the debate pass on this issue without pointing out just one other thing—I have already mentioned it but I will emphasise it—that is, the savings rebate does also apply to distributions from trusts. Far from cracking down on trusts, the government is proposing to actually reward the use of trusts for income splitting by providing a further maximum additional benefit of $450 per trust beneficiary. So in the case of a trust with multiple beneficiaries—a family consisting of a husband, wife and, let us say, seven children—the family could obtain an additional benefit of nine times $450, or $4,050 a year. How that could possibly be in the national interest is beyond our ken.

The second measure—and I will be much briefer about all these other elements in the bill—goes to distributions from private companies. It is longstanding practice for private companies to not distribute their profits to shareholders to avoid the tax that may be payable thereby on the dividends, but rather for a loan to be made to the shareholders. That loan is very often on non-commercial terms—with no interest payable and it being repayable on demand—which means that the shareholder effectively gets the income without having to pay tax on it. The income tax law has for many years had a provision attempting to deal with this issue, but it has proven ineffective in meeting its objectives. Last year's budget contained an announcement to tighten the law to ensure that non-commercial loans by private companies to their shareholders were subject to punitive tax to stamp out that practice, and that is achieved in the bill by strengthening the existing provisions—sections 108 and 109.

These proposals have been particularly controversial with the small business community, which has lobbied strongly against them. The government has relented on some aspects, specifically those concerning benefits paid to shareholders in their capacity as employees, which contained a myriad of unintended consequences sometimes involving double or even triple taxation.

Incredibly, the backdown on employee benefits was announced not by the Treasurer but by the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp, who was left to clean up the Treasurer's mess in this respect. The Treasurer always runs for cover when it comes to anything remotely embarrassing in the conduct of his portfolio.

While supporting the proposals in principle in the soon to be amended bill, the opposition is concerned that there may be some further anomalies which do treat small businesses unnecessarily unfairly. We believe that these provisions should be properly examined by a Senate committee and that is the course that we have supported. Perhaps it is embarrassment over this issue which has caused quite outrageous behaviour, I have to say, by the government in regard to proper Senate scrutiny of this legislation. I understand the government is proposing that a Senate inquiry into this legislation should report by this Thursday—tomorrow—and it secretly scheduled hearings into the bill on Monday, before this House had even considered the government's amendments. Some of the complex raft of amendments, which have not even been dealt with in this House yet, were released last Friday evening, so people only had a few hours—no more than that—to lodge submissions to the committee. That is a bad joke in terms of the government's respect for parliamentary process, and it should come back to haunt them.

The third measure goes to dividend imputation anti-avoidance. The 1997-98 budget contained a number of initiatives to counter abuse of the dividend imputation system. This bill proposes to implement two of these initiatives: namely, firstly, general anti-avoidance provisions specific to imputation and, secondly, anti-streaming rules—that is, rules to counter the practice of companies paying dividends, and giving other benefits, to shareholders in such a way as to give shareholders who benefit most from imputation credits a greater imputation benefit than those who would not benefit to the same degree.

The general anti-avoidance rules will apply to schemes to obtain a tax advantage in relation to imputation credits—that is, trading in those credits or streaming. The tax commissioner has the choice of whether to limit the company's imputation credits or to deny shareholders the benefit of the credits, depending on the type of scheme and the circumstances of either party. These general anti-avoidance rules will supplement the specific provisions for anti-streaming and the announced, but not yet introduced, provisions aimed at countering trading in imputation credits.

The industry is complaining that this represents a double jeopardy problem for taxpayers—namely, even if they comply with the specific requirements under the anti-streaming provisions or the upcoming anti-trading in imputation credits provisions, they may still be caught by general anti-avoidance provisions. In addition, some are concerned by the wide drafting of the anti-avoidance provisions, and the relaxation of the normal test from tax avoidance being the dominant purpose for the transaction to being other than incidental to the transaction.

We are concerned that some of these criticisms may be valid, especially in the context of the potential impact on collective instruments, such as superannuation and managed investment funds, which are continually trading in shares, presumably for non-taxation reasons. We in the opposition certainly recognise the dilemma that, without general anti-avoidance provisions, wealthy taxpayers can be expected to devise ways to get around the specific provisions. God knows we fought long enough and hard enough to give real teeth and substance to part 4A in this respect. Accordingly, while strongly supporting the proposals in principle, the opposition is concerned that there may be some further anomalies which affect taxpayers unfairly, so what we want is for these provisions to be properly examined by the Senate Economics Legislation Committee.

There are a number of other specific matters in respect of which the opposition takes the view that they are, on their face, reasonable and do not require any further serious investigation by a Senate committee. I am referring to provisions about employers' remittance systems and about capital gains tax and an assets register in relation to that. Then there are much smaller matters like election expenses for the Constitutional Convention, gifts to the National Nurses Memorial Trust, provisions about charitable trusts and also some minor changes to the sales tax regime. I indicate as to all of those measures that the opposition does not oppose them.

The remaining part of the bill—and it is a very substantial part of the bill—goes to the question of choice of superannuation funds. I will leave detailed discussion of those matters, as I foreshadowed, to the member for Wills, whose bailiwick this is and whose knowledge of this subject is immense. What I do simply want to foreshadow, as he will spell out in more detail, is that Labor does propose a number of amendments to this part of the legislation. They will include delaying the start date for choice until 1 July 2000 for both new and existing employees; ensuring that default funds contain specific investment choice and insurance cover features to protect those employees who do not make an active choice from winding up in an inappropriate fund; outlawing commission based sales of products which receive superannuation guarantee contributions; removing clause 32V, which overrides industrial awards; redefining the definition of `industry based fund' to include the requirement that such funds operate on a not-for-profit basis; and inserting third-line forcing provisions which will prevent employers from forcing employees into a fund from which employers will receive a benefit.

In addition to those amendments, and hopefully substituting for them and making them unnecessary, the member for Wills will be seeking the support of this House for a completely alternative approach to the whole question of choice of fund. We believe that there is a substantial case to be made for a quite different model, which would be a two-stage one in which, as the first stage, all super funds with more than 50 fund members would be required to offer investment choice options to all fund members and, as a second stage, after an extensive education and consumer protection campaign, there would be implemented a genuine employee choice super model whereby employees could nominate to have super contributions paid into a fund other than that set out in an industrial award with the agreement of their employers.

We believe that here our model would lead to a much better choice arrangement which is driven by those whom this government should be most concerned about but whom it is manifestly not concerned about—that is, the Australian workers. If the government were concerned about workers here as elsewhere, then it would not be proceeding with this costly complicated choice of fund model that will in fact result in lower retirement incomes. I move:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"whilst not opposing the second reading of the bill, the House notes that the Government in this legislation has:
(1) broken its firm promise made before the last election to deliver the full amount of the superannuation co-contribution; and
(2) instead proposed a much less valuable and much less equitable savings rebate and notes that the policy;
(a) only specifically actually rewards saving in the form of superannuation contributions;
(b) enables the full amount of the rebate to be received notwithstanding the taxpayer has actually engaged in dis-saving;
(c) will result in the level of national savings being significantly lower than if the superannuation co-contribution arrangements were implemented;
(d) is not means tested and is therefore inequitable in its impact; and
(e) is so unfair that the Prime Minister announced to this House that he would not claim his entitlement".

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.
—Order! It being approximately 7.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Tonight I want to express my abhorrence at this government's divisive and confrontational actions in vilifying Australia's working men and women, their families and their unions. Australians elect governments to solve problems, give leadership, unite us and build our nation. What we have is a government that sets out to deliberately create problems and to divide Australians. It is setting Australian against Australian, pitting worker against worker and painting unionists and unions as lazy, overpaid, underworked and un-Australian, so encouraging the vilification of their families, even in their own communities. Why? Because the objective of the government is to destroy the trade union movement, to bust unions, to Americanise our workplaces and to make it easier to reduce working conditions, pay and entitlements.

speech.para: Mr Speaker, you and I know that we have had conservative governments in the past, but the Howard government is the most divisive, confrontationist, incompetent and dishonest in living memory. This government cultivates the politics of envy by listing the workers' gross incomes and deleting any reference to working conditions, hours worked, risks entailed or disruption to family life. They say all this whilst they ignore the incompetence of senior managements.

They ignore the obscene and totally unjustified amounts paid to mining executives, and company executives generally. Business executives are being rewarded for abolishing jobs, so increasing unemployment. These executives preach parsimony to workers whilst shovelling cash, pensions and share options into their treasure chests. Let me cite Rio Tinto as an example. The most recent news on its Internet site concerning Rio Tinto's Hunter Valley No. 1 mine says that it is now one of the least productive mines in the Hunter Valley and last year made a profit of $1 per tonne. It ignores the revenue squandered by management of this global multinational in demurrage payments which cost $2 to $3 per tonne. They knowingly sell coal for delivery at a rate that cannot be achieved, resulting in late delivery penalties or demurrage payments.

It refers to the average length of service of a Rio Tinto employee at Hunter Valley No. 1 mine as being 12½ years. On Rio Tinto's Internet site, they discuss `The best person for the job based on their skills and performance, not just their length of service. An end to the seniority system'. That may be a subject for discussion, but clearly this does not apply to the directors. The average length of service of the Australian directors, Messrs Clifford, Davis and O'Leary, is 37 years. Of all the directors on the board, the average length of service is 24 years. So much for seniority; so much for new thinking, currency in ideas and new ideas in personnel and management.

Let us turn to salaries. The Internet site shows the average salary for an employee. For example, a truck driver at the Hunter Valley No. 1 mine earns between $73,000 to $83,000 per annum for a 42½ hour week and up to $97,000 with overtime and other benefits—like many others in society. Compare this with the exorbitant and obscene salaries of top executives and directors of Rio Tinto: Lee Clifford, mining director of Rio Tinto, was entitled to a lump sum pension at the end of 1996 of $2,759,000, an increase of $1,343,000 over 1995. He received a total salary in 1996 of $1,243,000 before tax, an increase of $284,000 from the previous year—an increase of almost 30 per cent. Leon Davis, chief executive, entitled to a lump sum pension of $6,600,000 at the end of 1996, an increase of $1,148,000 over 1995. His total salary was $1,815,000 before tax, an increase of $803,000 on the previous year. Michael O'Leary, director, was entitled to a lump sum pension of $4,025,000 at the end of 1996. His total salary in 1996 was $853,000 before tax, an increase of $293,000 from 1995.

Little wonder that workers and their families rebel at the arrogant and intimidating activities of managements of companies like Rio Tinto. In all my parliamentary experience covering transport and industrial relations, I have never seen a firm that got best performance for shareholders, employees and customers by confronting, intimidating and vilifying their employees. But this is the kind of behaviour that is aided and abetted by this H.R. Nicholls Society led government supporting the actions of foreign multinationals like Rio Tinto whose only commitment is to themselves and their foreign shareholders. Any benefit to Australia is incidental. This government refuses financial assistance to workers who have been robbed of their termination entitlements. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, in rising tonight I would like to congratulate you on your elevation to your present high office. That is certainly a custom of the Legislative Council whence we both came, but I am not sure that it is a custom of this place.
—Many good things come from that place.

—Certainly. The Federal Court of Australia last week made a landmark ruling in a case involving my local constituent and justice fighter Maree Whitaker. Mrs Whitaker is blind as a result of an operation some years ago that went wrong and where she developed the condition `sympathetic ophthalmia'. With this condition an operation on one eye can detrimentally affect the other good eye. The surgeon involved was found to be liable in contract and in negligence, and Mrs Whittaker was awarded a substantial amount of damages in the Supreme Court of New South Wales. The surgeon's appeal to the Court of Appeal was dismissed. A further appeal by special leave to the High Court was also dismissed.

speech.para: At question in the case decided by the Federal Court last week was whether Mrs Whitaker was liable to pay tax on the pre-judgment interest, that is, the amount paid to compensate her for the loss of compensation moneys between the time of the operation and the Supreme Court judgment and the post-judgment interest, the loss of the use of compensation moneys between the date of the Supreme Court judgment and the date of termination by the High Court. This was an extremely important test case for people who have received compensation moneys for personal injuries sustained through the negligence of others and upon which many incapacitated people must rely for their income for the rest of their life.

The matter is long running. In 1996, I wrote to the Treasurer (Mr Costello) to ensure that legal costs for Mrs Whitaker's appeal were funded by the Australian Taxation Office. It is an indication of the importance of the case that the Australian Taxation Office agreed to pay these costs, regardless of the outcome.

Before the Federal Court, solicitors Warren McKean Dixon of Miranda argued that pre-judgment interest compensates a victim for deprivation of the use of a compensation sum pending final resolution of the case, not because an investment opportunity has been forgone. This argument prevailed with respect to pre-judgment interest. However, post-judgment interest, due to the interpretation of section 95 of the Supreme Court act as compared to section 94, is taxed.

It seems to me that, from the point of view of a personal injuries compensation victim, the legal distinction is semantic. The trial judge is unable to calculate into a damages award the possibility of appeal so as to ultimately compensate the victim for the exigencies of the legal process. Therefore, I ask that the Treasurer, in view of the review of the taxation system now in progress, look at the position of compensation victims and consider, in the case of such victims, treating so-called interest payments—both pre- and post-judgment—as forming part of the compensation payment. I ask that it be considered to be compensation for added pain and suffering for delay in resolution and for keeping the victim from use of the money. The money may not have been invested at all, but might have been needed immediately for the assistance and comfort of the injured party.

I hope this matter will be considered by the government's tax consultative task force in the interests of those people whose lives have, in many cases, been made very difficult because of the injuries they have sustained and who have to rely upon their own devices and the compensation moneys to look after themselves so as not to be a burden upon the state.

talk.start.para: —Last week I was pleased to attend the Greek National Day celebrations in Sydney and the Greek embassy's function for Greek National Day on 25 March this year. The Greek National Day is celebrated very extensively in Sydney with a number of large functions, some supported by various Greek organisations and a very large celebration supported by the Greek Orthodox Church. As usual, the meeting in Sydney last Sunday fortnight was very well attended by politicians as well as by leading figures in the Greek community. This month the Greek Festival of Sydney is running, and the highlight of that will be a function at the Greek Club in Lakemba in my electorate.

speech.para: I think the Greek community in Sydney is what helps to make Sydney a very Mediterra nean city. In my electorate there is a particularly large Greek community. The outward looking approach of the Greek community melds exceptionally well, I think, with the Australian approach. We have there an excellent example of the way multiculturalism in this country works.

As is usually the case at these gatherings, one of the focuses was the situation in Cyprus. If there is one matter that draws those who are of Greek origin and those who have a supportive nature together it is the continuing division of Cyprus. Many of us thought that the beginning of the talks about the accession of Cyprus to the European Union meant that the Turkish government would see some sense, that there would be closer ties built between the Turkish Cypriots and the Greek Cypriots and that there would be a withdrawal of the Turkish troops from Northern Cyprus. One good thing about the accession of Cyprus to the European Union would have been that we would have seen the borders between the rest of Europe and Cyprus become more transparent, which should also have made the green line that runs through the northern part of Cyprus disappear.

It is unfortunate that the Turkish government seems to have taken a very strong line against Cyprus's accession to the European Union, and it was most unfortunate that the Turkish Cypriot representatives did not participate in the accession talk. It is very interesting that Robin Cook, the British Foreign Minister who has the presidency of the EU at present, noted and welcomed the offers by the Cyprus government to include Turkish Cypriot representatives in the team negotiating the terms of Cyprus's accession to the European Union. Cook said:
The European Union regrets that the Turkish Cypriot community have so far responded negatively to this offer. It reiterates the importance that it attaches—
that is, the union—

to associating the Turkish Cypriots with the accession process, in accordance with the conclusions of the Luxembourg European Council. The Presidency and the Commission will pursue the necessary contacts.

I think that that is what should happen. The Denktash regime in the north should not be trying to use this as an excuse to partition the island. The Turkish Cypriot junta in the north should join in the accession process so that Cyprus can once again become a united country and Turkish Cypriots and Greek Cypriots can live as one in an undivided homeland. As part of Europe, that would promote a lot more economic benefits for all Cypriots and will certainly allow Cypriots from both parts of the island to visit each other and get on with their lives, which is what most of the ordinary Cypriots want, unlike what many of the Turkish Cypriot politicians want. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Before I call on the next member, on behalf of the parliament I thank the honourable member for Watson for the job he does representing this parliament on the Committee for Cyprus of the Interparliamentary Union, which is a very important function on behalf of all Australians.

—I wish to make some comments tonight in light of the comments on child care on 30 March by the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio). She continues to spread Labor misinformation which even the Australian Centre-Based Child Care association, which represents 1,100 child-care centres, says is completely unfounded. In a press release of 22 February, the President of the Australian Confederation of Childcare said:

speech.para: We want to completely refute recent comments about Child Care which appear to be politically motivated, which suggest there have been substantial fee increases. This politically motivated campaign only serves to do long term damage to the Child Care Industry as a whole. This campaign is trying to blame the current Federal Government for reductions in attendance at Child Care Centres. Nothing could be further from the truth.

The current Federal Minister, Warwick Smith, has in a short space of time, shown more understanding and leadership in Child Care than any previous Minister in recent times. This Government has, for the first time, put in place a planning system for Child Care, it has removed inequitable funding practices such as operational subsidies, it has introduced a hotline for information about Child Care and it has recently announced a retention of the current system of allocation of Child Care assistance to families which will avoid complex and intrusive procedures for families. Without doubt, children and families are the big winners under The Howard Government's Child Care Policies.

The Penrith City Council continues to rail against the reduction in operational subsidies. The operational subsidies effectively prevented some 51,000 families in outside school hours care from receiving any sort of child-care assistance. We have put the equity back into that. We have taken the $20 benefit from 70,000 families which was denied to 200,000 Australian families using private centres—and that $20 a week benefit basically went to fund community based centres—and we have spread that money over the entire child-care system. And it is not just long day care centres which the Penrith council is concerned about, considering that it runs 17 of them. We have spread it out over family day care centres, occasional care, outside school hours care services, vacation care services, playgroups, multifunctional children's services, multifunctional Aboriginal children's services, mobile children's services and toy libraries. we have really covered this entire area.

Yes, Penrith City Council is upset. Its 17 child-care centres have lost substantial amounts of federal money, which has gone to fund other child-care places, and they have to make up that deficit. But in addition to what the Commonwealth government was funding them, something like $2 million of the ratepayers of Lindsay's money was being spent by council on child care. This is to compete for places in an area which is oversupplied with child-care places. It is to compete against private centres in Lindsay, of which there are a number which have not put up their fees and are in fact cheaper than those run by council. These centres are still available, and here we are with Penrith City Council using federal money and local government money to compete against private centres which are providing an adequate service, given that all centres must comply with the state regulations in order to qualify for the child-care assistance and the child-care rebate.

These sorts of fees work together in a way that sees an equitable distribution of money between low income families, and they provide an extra 83,000 places over the next four years. By the end of next year, 83,000 more child-care places will be available in the community, including in my area, to the people of Australia than were available under the previous government. An extra $4.9 billion has been allocated over four years. So I completely refute any suggestion, any politically motivated innuendo, from the opposition that people of my electorate are in any way disadvantaged in terms of child care. Whatever it takes, this government is going to do it. We are providing more child-care places and more assistance. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I take this opportunity in tonight's adjournment debate to pay tribute to the role played by community volunteers in my electorate—those who belong to organisations and also those who act individually. Because of the time constraints, I will refer to only one organisation and one individual.

speech.para: Ever since my election to the New South Wales state parliament in 1984 I have been aware of the highly dedicated and motivated Concord Hospital Service Auxiliary who are now into their 30th year, having commenced their work in 1969 when Concord Hospital was then known as the Veterans Hospital 113 A.G.H. Repatriation and was widely respected as one of the finest teaching hospitals in Australia. In June 1993 the hospital was integrated into the state system and is now known as Concord Repatriation General Hospital.

The volunteers did not miss a beat. They became incorporated and now number 120 men and women who continue to go from strength to strength. To raise funds, they operate a gift shop and candy cart, and run market days and raffles. In more recent times they have expanded their operations to include functions such as Christmas and July dinners, this year being their third dinner, all of which my wife, Rita, and I have attended. They have also organised race days at Randwick and Rosehill Gardens and dinner dances. They also organise one major fete day in the hospital grounds and/or at a local park. A wine auction dinner dance was held last Friday, which my wife and I also attended. It proved to be highly enjoyable and raised a very substantial sum of money under the highly experienced hammer wielded by the guest of honour, Len Evans.

Additionally, the volunteers work in many departments and wards in the hospital, tidying and refreshing flowers, as well as undertaking many other tasks, including laminating, dynomaking, stamping various envelopes, rolling bandages, repairing equipment, filing and other clerical work, and assisting patients when required. I take this opportunity to pay tribute to the livewire president of the volunteers, Ruth Ellis, who has proven to be a very great asset to the hospital and to our community in general.

I will now list some of their very impressive financial donations to the hospital just in the past 2½ years. For the ophthalmology department, a Yag laser for the early detection of glaucoma, $17,000. For the radiology department, a mammography machine, $70,000. For the sports medicine department, a Bobath couch, $2,500. For the blood donors department, four lazy-boy chairs for the taking of blood, $3,500. In the chapel, the restoration of the original altar of the hospital, $500. For the burns unit, three TVs and videos for the comfort of long-stay patients, $4,000. For the medical oncology day-care unit, mattress covers to provide relief for very ill patients, $4,000 in various wards. For the ENT department, a Kay's rhino-laryngeal stroboscope, $16,500.

For the new transit room, two bezique standard back armchairs, $600; two bezique high back armchairs, $660; two pastor standard back armchairs, $220; one upright refrigerator, $850; and one TV, NEC brand, $740; a total of $3,070. In addition, for the orthopaedics department, audiovisual equipment to educate patients and staff, $600. For the Anzac Health and Medical Research Foundation, $50,000. For the Kokoda Track Walkway Ltd, $4,102. Various departments require assistance with water coolers, ice making machines, curtains and tablecloths. For the cardiac department, two monitoring machines worth $7,000. I say: well done, Ruth Ellis and the Concord Hospital volunteers.

While on the topic of volunteers, I also pay tribute to a most delightful and energetic 90-year-old lady who, when asked about her age, said simply that she had reached a significant age—Mrs Dorothy Pemberton from Concord West in my electorate who, together with another 13 volunteers, many from the Concord Uniting Church, has been giving assistance at Homebush Boys High School over a very long period of time. Mrs Pemberton has been helping students to improve their reading and literacy skills and, as a former teacher, she has an excellent rapport with the students, who speak highly of her patience, knowledge, teaching skills and positive attitude. She has been attending Homebush Boys High School since 1991. She is a really great lady. On my behalf, and on behalf of my constituents, I wish Dorothy Pemberton a happy retirement and continued good health.

talk.start.para: —Last night I made a few comments about the needs of the Great Western Highway, until the clock rather cruelly brought my run to an end, although perhaps to the relief of some others present. I made some comments about the importance of the Great Western Highway for a number of reasons—as a link between the central west and the ports and markets of Sydney, because of the needs of a growing tourism market in the mountains, and the need for access for emergency vehicles. The same comments apply also to the Bells Line of Road, an important alternative route across the Blue Mountains.

speech.para: I finished by talking about safety issues relating to the Great Western Highway compared to roads throughout the rest of the state. I made the comment that, throughout the state of New South Wales, on average, three per cent of accidents lead to casualties, whereas on the Great Western Highway nine per cent of accidents lead to casualties. Across the state generally, one per cent of accidents lead to fatalities, but on the Great Western Highway three per cent of accidents lead to fatalities. So the Great Western Highway is a road of significant importance but one that needs considerable attention. It needs funding.

In the last two years, the federal government has increased funding for roads to the state government of New South Wales. In 1995-96, the last year of the Labor government, $311 million was allocated for road funding to the New South Wales government. In the first year of this government, 1996-97, we increased it to $321 million, an increase of 3.1 per cent. In this year's budget, 1997-98, we increased it to $337 million, an increase of 5.2 per cent. Therefore, there really is no excuse on the part of the state government not to increase funding for the Great Western Highway.

Having said that, there is still a strong case for increased federal funding for the Great Western Highway. Sadly, in 1992, the former Labor government excluded the Great Western Highway from its national highway funding program, therefore leaving it solely dependent upon the resources of the state government.

It is very pleasing to note, however, that this government has restored the roads of national importance program—in addition, I might say, to the black spots program. The RONI program does give some strong hope of increased funding for the Great Western Highway. It is for this reason that I urge the federal government to seriously consider upgrading the Great Western Highway to a road of national importance. It is, on all accounts, a road of national importance, for the reasons that I said. It is a very vital link between western New South Wales, central New South Wales and the markets and ports of Sydney. It is, in essence, a road of national importance and does need to be funded appropriately.

I look forward, therefore, to increased federal government attention to the Great Western Highway and the improvements that will bring. It is important that we do improve the traffic flow, that we do improve the development and employment opportunities for people in the mountains and central and western New South Wales. It is important that we assist the burgeoning tourist industry in the Blue Mountains. It is important, while doing all of this, that we consider the needs of local residents and it is important, most of all, that we improve the highway in order to reduce casualties and to save lives.

talk.start.para: —It being almost 8.00 p.m., the debate is interrupted.
—Mr Speaker, I require that the debate be extended, to allow me to respond to the contribution made tonight by the member for Watson.
—The debate may continue until 8.10 p.m.

—I acknowledge the commitment of the member for Watson (Mr Leo McLeay) to a just solution to the Cyprus problem and again place on the parliamentary record my own commitment to exactly the same solution. I am, in fact, the patron of the Justice for Cyprus Coordinating Committee in South Australia. I took a special interest in this subject because of the constituents I represent in my electorate. In fact, I travelled with the member for Watson and others to Cyprus and Greece roughly 18 months ago.

speech.para: To speak to one's constituents and feel committed to what they are committed to is one thing, but to visit Cyprus and see the division there, to see our peacekeeping force in action, to see the green line, to see the flag pole where Solomos Solomou was shot down, to look through binoculars over Famagusta where people in my electorate lived and to know that the only way they can see the city that they lived in is through binoculars because of the division there is to bring home the lack of human rights that people there are still experiencing and, of course, to acknowledge how fortunate we are in our own country to not have those divisions.

In South Australia, the Cyprus Community of South Australia Inc. has just celebrated its 50th anniversary. I was pleased to help celebrate with them at a debutante ball and assist in cutting their very splendid cake. They are very good citizens of our country, many of them coming here as refugees, many of them from one particular village which is still in that northern occupied part of Cyprus.

I am sure that all of my colleagues here would welcome any progress on solving the Cyprus problem. I have noted that the European Union yesterday welcomed the Republic of Cyprus to the accession process and also expressed regret over the continued Turkish occupation of part of Cyprus. On behalf of the EU, Council President Robin Cook said:

I am delighted that today we are meeting to open accession negotiations. The Union has shown it can respond decisively and effectively to the transformation of Europe's political landscape and use the opportunities this offers to end the divisions of the past. These efforts are being matched by Cyprus which has made great strides on the path to accession.
The EU regrets that it has not been possible to achieve a political solution to the continuing division of Cyprus in time for the accession negotiations on which we embark today.

The Union believes that Cyprus' accession to the EU should benefit all communities, including the Turkish Cypriot community, and help to bring about civil peace and reconciliation on the island. In that context, our objective remains a bi-communal, bi-zonal federation on the basis of a comprehensive political settlement in accordance with UN Security Council Resolutions. A political settlement would allow the provisions of the Accession Treaty to be implemented throughout the island.
Mr Cook also noted that the EU welcomes the offer by the Cyprus government to include Turkish Cypriot representatives in the team for negotiating the terms of the Cyprus accession to the EU. He said:
The European Union regrets that the Turkish Cypriot community has so far responded negatively to this offer.

I would have to reiterate my own disappointment and I know that of those in my own electorate who are so interested in this just solution. In fact, in Adelaide the community have made sure that they have made contact with Turkish Cypriots who are also living in Australia. They are recognising what they share in common and how important that reconciliation, which has been spoken of in the EU yesterday, is to them.

I would hope the member for Watson, and I am sure all people in this place—I know you also have a special interest in this issue, Mr Speaker—would join me in hoping for a just solution in the not too distant future.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 27 November 1997, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —Perhaps a good starting point in commenting on the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 is to revisit some of the principles which underpin the tax law improvement project, also known as TLIP. When the former Labor government established TLIP on 1 July 1994, it empowered it with the authority to simplify income tax law by restructuring and rewriting the 1936 Income Tax Assessment Act to make it easier to comprehend. I remind members of this mandate because, when one looks through the many hundreds of pages of submissions made to the TLIP team on this bill by those who actively have to work with the tax act on a daily basis, one could be forgiven for forgetting that the rewrite is supposed to facilitate simplification.

speech.para: It is hard to imagine how, in this instance, the consultation process could have been better frustrated or the drafting more poorly executed. The fact that the government produced a 79-page supplementary explanatory memorandum filled to the brim with amendments only 36 hours before the bill was first scheduled for debate is indicative of the chaotic manner in which it has been handled.

The consensus in the tax industry seems to be that the structural changes that the rewrite will bring about are to be welcomed. Further, the concept of the capital tax event, so-called, has garnered a reasonable level of support amongst legal and financial advisers. However, the two leading concerns of tax professionals about this bill are very significant. They are focused both on the failure of the legislation to adequately deal with known technical errors and on the pruning back of the time available for the completion and review of the rewrite. These matters give rise to a series of related consequences, including a continuation of the lack of certainty in the tax acts and an increase in the number of interpretations which clearly favour the revenue at the expense of the taxpayer. I intend to comment on each of these in some detail.

In their combined submission to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in 1996, the Taxation Institute of Australia (TIA), the Institute of Chartered Accountants in Australia (ICAA), and the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants (ASCPA), who will be referred to hereon in as `the bodies', proposed more than 230 separate recommendations for the correction of technical defects in the current law.

TLIP may never have intended to address big `P' policy issues in the rewrite, but its brief certainly extended to addressing the known practical problems in the original act. In isolation, these technical defects are a source of irritation to taxpayers and their advisers. When combined, they give rise to taxation on unrealised gains and dissuade business investment and development.

In speaking on the second instalment of legislation to result from the tax law improvement project, I said that it was necessary that the terms of reference of TLIP should be extended to include a review of policy. My stated position then was that there should be no easing of pressure on this parliament to implement substantive changes to the policy and administration of tax legislation, and I remain committed to that position.

As one submission to the rewrite project made clear, despite government comment to the contrary, there are many examples of policy changes contained within the capital gains tax rewrite. These appear to be selective and confirm that the government and the TLIP team `cannot seek to hide behind the cloak of the TLIP's limited terms of reference to pretend that it was unable to make small `p' or even large `P' policy changes to the current law'.

The fact that neither the TLIP team nor the government, both of which received a copy of the bodies' submission, has bothered to give a considered response to the authors by January 1998 is an absolute disgrace. It is also lamentable that the government has failed to address in its amendments the JCPAA recommendation that the TLIP team should respond formally to any submissions from stakeholders by the time future instalments of the rewrite are tabled in parliament.

That said, it is pleasing to note that the coalition has finally come to its senses in a small way by choosing to adopt all of the JCPAA's recommendations on technical correction to the capital gains tax regime in its amendments to the bill. However, it should not be forgotten that the government and the Australian Taxation Office, the ATO, had full knowledge of these deficiencies but failed to act on them until the dying hours before this debate was to take place.

Before its about-face, the TLIP team, which not coincidentally is dominated by representatives from the ATO, were all too prepared to ignore their own summary of identifiable technical deficiencies. The summary comprised some 157 issues relating specifically to the CGT.

As the bodies made clear in their submission to TLIP, the process of identifying and agreeing to unintended consequences is a long and tiresome one. If the outcome of this process fails to produce improved law, then it is for naught. Also, as I understand it, the government's amendments do not address the full range of concerns of the peak taxation bodies.

Before issuing the supplementary explanatory memorandum, the combined government and TLIP forces had incorporated in the rewrite only 10 per cent of the recommendations by the bodies. Clearly, their amendments will improve on that figure, but they do not go far enough.

To read that our leading tax experts regard this rewrite as a lost opportunity in which bad law is simply re-expressed should be of concern to all in this place and elsewhere. The government's 11th hour backdown on some of these technical amendments goes only part of the way to making the most of the opportunity presented by the rewrite. That these concerned experts perceived this bill to be the benchmark, or litmus test, against which the remainder of the rewrite will be judged must have left them feeling rather ambivalent about the worthiness of TLIP.

This bill was introduced into the parliament on 22 November 1997 in an incomplete state, owing to the absence of technical corrections and to transitional and consequential provisions. It was not until some five weeks later, on 8 January 1998, that interested parties received information on these latter provisions. But that did not mark the end of the waiting game, because it was only last week—or perhaps the week before—that the government produced its own amendments to the bill, a tentative sign that it is perhaps finally taking some of the advice offered to it by the stakeholders.

At best the staggered release of information makes it difficult to give a considered response to the rewritten legislation; at worst it subverts the whole consultation process. As Mr Robert Bryant, Executive Director of the Corporate Tax Association, suggested:

It is grossly inadequate to have delivered to us flawed and incomplete legislation that has the potential to produce disadvantageous outcomes or not be a faithful replication of what has been there before.

The big losers in all of this are the corporate and PAYE taxpayers. Clearly it is not just a lack of wanting, on the part of the TLIP team, to address the technical defects in the capital gains tax regime. The lack of time made available to it for the completion and review of the legislation helped ensure that the rewrite was riddled with written errors. Countless examples of technical errors which are present in the 1936 act and which have been faithfully replicated in the TLIP rewrite have been revealed by representatives of the tax community.

In addition to these are instances where the signposting in the rewritten legislation is clearly substandard, where there are gaps in the new alphanumeric system and where misprints have been detected. As I have noted elsewhere, if these anomalies are not immediately corrected we can all expect to spend valuable parliamentary time debating a future technical amendments bill to overcome avoidable shortcomings in what is supposed to be a new and improved act.

In commenting on the last instalment of the TLIP rewrite, the then Joint Committee of Public Accounts stated that the process `may be suffering in the rush to have legislation introduced into the parliament'. The chairman of that former committee, the honourable member for Fairfax (Mr Somlyay), went on to note that `the committee had not had the time to review the bill as comprehensively as it would have liked' and recommended that the government should `schedule sufficient time for . . . review of the next tranche of legislation'. This is the next tranche.

That report was tabled in parliament in March 1997. In the foreword to report No. 356 of March 1998, the present chairman of the JCPAA, the honourable member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), outlined his concern that neither the committee nor the tax professionals had confidence in their ability to review the bill because:
The time allowed . . . to respond to exposure drafts of the legislation has been truncated . . .
A familiar story. The chairman also cautioned that there was `evidence of undue haste in preparing the bill because it was incomplete when introduced'.

Here we are some 12 months and another TLIP instalment later, and there appears to have been no change in the management of either the rewrite or the review process. Worse still is the fact that the recommendation by the JCPAA which dealt specifically with this aspect of timing has not been picked up by the government in its subsequent amendments to the bill before us.

Recommendation 4 of report No. 356 outlined the committee's position that all of the proposed TLIP legislation and associated consequential and transitional provisions should be introduced into the parliament together, and the committee given adequate time for a thorough review. The failure of the government to address this issue, which has been raised not only by the stakeholders but also by its own committee, is lamentable.

It is with real trepidation that I note the perception of many in the tax community that the rewrite has ensured that the ATO's authority has been consolidated in the new rules at the expense of the taxpayer. Mr Duncan Baxter, partner with Deloitte Touche Tohmatsu, noted in evidence to the JCPAA on 29 January this year:
The current legislation—
that is, the 1936 tax act—

contains a number of areas in which the law is unclear and on which the ATO has formed a particular view which is generally favourable to the revenue and on which taxpayers and our advisers have formed a different view. . . . We certainly see examples of the ATO view being legislated into the new rules.
Mr William Glass, president of the Corporate Tax Association, also lent his weight to this argument when he gave evidence that:
Either wittingly or unwittingly, there has been seen to be a certain Taxation Office bias in some of the decision making on certain key issues.

The suggestion that the rewrite has failed to clarify those areas of current CGT law which are subject to legal challenge is also shared by the TIA, the ASCPA and the ICCA. In their joint submission, they state their belief that:
The TLIP team has indicated that it will take a neutral stance to these issues. The evidence is otherwise. The TLIP team has favoured in a number of instances the ATO position.

One example used by the bodies to illustrate that is the failure of the TLIP team to deal with the issue of double taxation in circumstances where damages may be recovered in relation to the injury to or loss of property.

While limited change has been sought in this bill, the bodies argue that further amendments are necessary to settle, once and for all, the issue of this double tax effect. It is their stated opinion that:
The rewrite does not seek to make clear by explicit provision that double tax cannot arise in relation to essentially the one event that occurs in relation to the same asset.

As I noted earlier, unlike those responsible for the drafting of the new legislation, these people are responsible for offering advice on tax law on a daily basis. They are telling anyone in this place who cares to listen that this bill is not to be as effective as it could be.

Apparently, as at 1 July, 1997, the ATO had identified around 900 rulings and determinations which required amendment as a direct consequence of the rewrite of the 1936 tax act. Instead of making the necessary corrections—which, admittedly, would be a formidable task—the ATO has opted to issue a new ruling, a final ruling, which has never been released in draft form and which seeks to ratify existing rulings and determinations affected by the rewrite but where there is no intended change in the law. So there is just one ruling, the wording of which is still unknown. As the bodies make very clear:

The problem with this approach is that it will leave taxpayers at large, as time goes by, not knowing whether the ATO has in fact made a public statement about the relevant public or private ruling affecting them.

The decision to issue this final ruling tips the scales further in favour of the ATO, because the burden that will be imposed on a taxpayer trying to ascertain whether a statement disputing a particular ruling has been made will be considerable.
If a taxpayer fails to apply for a new ruling to clarify the existing ruling, the bodies say:
There is the very real possibility that taxpayers' private rulings may be overtaken at some stage in the future without them being aware of the fact.
In one of the most damning remarks in their entire 200-page submission, the bodies suggest that this is tantamount to:
The ATO . . . encroaching on the legislative power of parliament in stating that its view creates law.

I have recently commented in this place that parliament should be loath to bolster the powers of the tax commissioner, and the treatment of rulings and determinations in this instance confirms my position on that particular point. I challenge the government to try to explain how it is that the concept of this final ruling, which will lead to greater unpredictability in the tax acts, is consistent with the simplification process.

Another irony of the rewrite is that it is actually increasing the complexity of the tax act, because professionals are now obliged to refer to both the 1936 act—the original act—as well as the rewritten 1997 act in order to meet the needs of their clients.

On page 9 of the coalition's explanatory memorandum, it states that the accumulated impact of the many small improvements in the bill will bring about a noticeable reduction in compliance costs for those using CGT law. But the evidence suggests otherwise. In his brief to the JCPAA, Mr William Glass noted that the cost of researching TLIP affected issues and swapping between the two tax acts has steadily increased by around 30 per cent since the commencement of TLIP. He also expressed the frustration at the valuable time that has been swallowed up in the process, indicating that it was becoming increasingly difficult to provide an immediate response on an issue. Surely, even the government would concede that this establishes a good case for warehousing of this and earlier instalments, until the rewrite is complete.

In closing, I remind the House that my support for the efforts being made by the TLIP team has always been qualified. I see little in either the management, or the rewrite, of this bill that persuades me to change my mind. If the rewrite is to amount to anything of substance, the government and the TLIP team must commit themselves to a more rapid, but considered, review of tax legislation.

talk.start.para: —The Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 highlights what is an obvious fact and that is that the tax laws in this country have long since passed their use-by date. When we have a tax law improvement bill of 600 pages and an explanatory memorandum accompanying it of substantial proportions—
—What about the explanatory memorandum for the amendments to it?

—And the explanatory memorandum for the amendments, as the member for Curtin indicates, it is obvious to all of us, and should be obvious to everybody who is in a position to take notice, that the system is simply not working.

speech.para: I am very attracted to a proposal that has been floated by Mr John McRobert called the easytax two per cent tax. Easytax is a flat tax on every exchange of ownership of goods and/or services involving monetary considerations. It is a simple, visible and predictable charge for the use of money and facilitating trade and commerce for the exchange of goods and services. It does not apply to money deposited or withdrawn from a bank. This falls outside the definition.

The two per cent tax of the gross monetary value of the exchange of ownership of goods, services and labour would replace personal and company income tax, wholesale sales tax, payroll tax, fringe benefits tax, capital gains tax, withholding tax and provisional taxes. In so doing, it would restore full employment and create a prosperous nation, paving the way for future reforms in relation to tariff and excise matters.

The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), in his as yet unreleased book, has shown some realism in relation to the tax system with his leaning towards a replacement of the income tax system by a tax on consumption, a tax that would basically move towards taxing those who consume most. Those who consume most, generally speaking, are those who are better able to pay tax, and frequently they are those who are not paying tax at the present time because of the tax arrangements they have made.

There is a massive industry out there devoted to avoiding tax. There is a massive industry out there which is, reluctantly, subsidised by decent and honourable taxpayers who have to cope with the nightmare of the Income Tax Assessment Act and all of its amendments. The current taxation system is far too complex. The cost of compliance is a massive waste of Australian resources and an unnecessary burden on all taxpayers, and in particular, small businesses.

No-one can fully understand the taxation laws; they are too confusing. In my electorate I constantly have members of the accounting profession contact me when a further amendment is made to the tax act. They find that the current tax act is already virtually unmanageable and they simply do not understand it. If they do not understand it, how are they going to explain it to their clients?

Of course, added to that is the fact that they do have to somehow understand it; they do have to somehow struggle with it. That leads to the fact that the extra cost to their clients, and ultimately to the community as a whole, will often defeat the purpose of the tax itself. It is just one burden piled on another.

In my view, complex and punitive taxation is a major obstacle for all businesses, small and large, and it does cause attention to be diverted from good, sound management. How can you tax profit when you do not have a definition of what profit is? That is the whole problem with this area. How can you insist on an income tax system continuing on as it has been since about 1915? At that time, ordinary workers would not be paying that level of tax because of their income, but they are now suffering from bracket creep.

I recall that, when I was working as an apprentice at the Evans Deakin shipyard, if I worked overtime I was immediately pushed into a higher tax bracket. That was a great disincentive to work longer. That has not changed under the current system. In fact, it has got worse.

A small businessman in my electorate said to me recently that his 1998 take-home pay was no different from what it was in the mid-1980s. When people in small business say that to me, there is a real problem. It is a problem that we must recognise. We can be lulled into thinking that because certain areas in the business sector are doing well other business sectors are doing well also. There are some sectors in business that are doing well and have improved considerably—and let us hope that continues—but there are other sectors that are being left behind.

The small businessman who came to see me last Friday was a motor vehicle repairer. He had 14 people working for him in the mid-1980s but he now has two, including one of his sons. As I said before, his take-home pay has not changed. In fact, it has gone backwards in real terms because of the cost of living increases over that period. He is working 60 and 70 hours a week. The anguish was etched all over his face, and we cannot ignore that.

These people are the real battlers out there. What he is saying to me in relation to the tax system and other matters is that those people in the middle group in society are not really being helped by the taxation system.
