He is saying that the system is crushing them. Therefore, we have to look for innovative ways to deal with what has become a major problem, a modern problem. We cannot keep applying the old system to a modern problem.

I think we all accept that the taxation system must be looked at in a serious way, must be dealt with. This measure attempts to improve the understanding of the system but, in my view, the system itself is beyond understanding. As I said, it speaks for itself with the volume of the material that we have to consider. Australia is in a serious situation; a simpler tax system will allow our businesses to be more efficient and productive, and will provide an equal tax charge for goods and services traded over the Internet, for example, as for those traded over the counter.

The flat tax of two per cent of receipts of income and sales could be phased in over a three-year period. Obviously there will be transitional problems in some areas, but those always happen when one is moving to a new system. This is a reality of life; we cannot change the tax system overnight and expect everything to just fit straight into place. Over a three-year period, using a tax pool arrangement to install new gross wages equal to take home pay plus two per cent would effectively slash the cost of employment, while increasing the purchasing power of the after tax dollar. I emphasise that slashing the cost of employment will increase the ability of employers to employ more people, and that is what we need to do.

Easytax is quite different from a VAT or a GST. It is simpler. In the fully implemented system, there are no deductions, no thresholds, no demarcations, no deeming, no accruals, no pre-payments, no repayments, no exemptions and no nonsense. The net effect is to lower the taxes on employment, drop the cost of employment and increase the demand for employment. Australia has 13 million employable people with only eight million deemed to be employed. So the unemployment statistics just do not add up. After the implementation of a two per cent easytax, it is obvious that over time other taxes will be discarded as the economy improves.

The two per cent tax has the advantage of being visible. This is one of the things that, I think, we struggle with in the community now—certainly, the people of Australia struggle with the fact that so many of these taxes are hidden. People say, `We don't have a GST now' when in fact we do in so many areas. This particular idea, in terms of reforming the tax system, will mean there is a visible tax which will show on the sales of goods, services and property—that is, every receipt will show a two per cent surcharge on the listed selling price. It will be a constant reminder of the cost of government, and people need to be reminded of those sorts of things. I think it is part of the accountability of government to the people. The simplification will activate a strong motivational multiplier effect in our economy and this will drive job creation.

For small transactions, such as those less than $100, the tax may be added to or deducted from the sale price at the seller's option. The tax on receipts will be due for payment by the end of the month following the month in which the taxable transaction takes place. Annual financial statements will be lodged within six months after the close of the financial year, together with a statement of cash flow and reconciliation to the annual financial statements.

Importers will be responsible for payment of the receipts tax on imported goods and services, those being taxed at two per cent of the purchase value. Internal sales of these imported goods and services will again be taxed at two per cent on sale. Exports will attract the two per cent tax on sale under the normal terms. There will be legal definitions and ATO rulings for different types of taxable transactions but these will be simple.

Payment of interest and dividends will be taxed at two per cent for both Australians and foreign investors, with taxation at source for overseas remittances. Deposits and withdrawals from bank accounts will not be taxed, as they are not sales. A delay in the payment of the two per cent tax by the party responsible will incur a penalty tax at the rate of two per cent per month on the tax outstanding but with increasing penalty rates after six months after the end of the financial year. There may be extenuating circumstances but those sorts of details would need to be worked out over time and, frequently, on a case by case basis.

The quality of life for the citizens of Australia, in my view, would be improved by this proposal. There would be a massive increase in job opportunities, better job satisfaction and an incentive to work harder. There would be a great influx of people with the entrepreneurial infusion, if you like, of wanting to work harder and get on with their dreams of achieving a reasonable standard of living and, at the same time, being rewarded for effort and not taxed out of existence. Prompted by the concept, I am advised that a unique and powerful computer model of the Australian economy has been developed by Unisearch Research Pty Ltd, at the Queensland University of Technology, to show the relevant impact of all types of taxation on all sectors of commerce and industry. The model was based on 1988 to 1991 figures and reconciled on the national accounts. It was then upgraded to cover the period 1992 to 1995 using the latest complete set of ABS statistics. Indications are that a low rate of tax on receipts has predictable stability and would be difficult to increase once entrenched.

In summary, as I have indicated, this particular system of taxation would be simple, and would be much easier to enforce. Indeed, effectively, instead of the complex tax returns that we are now filling out, this would be a one-page tax return. It would be simple and efficient. It would encourage accountants to get into development planning and estimate planning instead of being bogged down on the negative side of taxation—the finding of one's way through and wading one's way through the hopelessly complex taxation legislation, the Income Tax Assessment Act and related acts.

I think, in the circumstances, we have to consider a new way of viewing these things. We have to look very far-sightedly because we have been wrapped up and tied up in knots by a system which is doing everything to discourage people from investing, working hard and providing more employment. Really, we cannot have a situation where we have five million people basically twiddling their thumbs, because they could be capably and adequately employed with a system that would encourage employment.

In the particular circumstances of this measure, without saying anything other than that the system we have is fracturing and has fractured, I do encourage those in a position to do something about it to look at these measures and to speak with people like the tax reform group in Queensland headed by John McRobert. Let us hear an argument about it. Let us hear someone say, `That would not work because . . . .' I am yet to hear any significant argument against but, obviously, there are areas that have to be considered. Let us look at these things because, at the end of the day, the system will eventually crack under the strain of the weighty legislation with which we are dealing.

talk.start.para: —The member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) referred, in his discussion of taxation issues, to the problem of the taxation treatment of overtime. I have to say, from a personal point of view, that I think it would be much better if employers, rather than encouraging workers to work overtime, in fact took on new employees. My own view is that a situation where some workers, as in the example he gave, are working 60 or 70 hours a week, while others are completely without work and unemployed, is not in fact a good piece of social policy. That would be my own view of that matter.

speech.para: The member for Dickson did ask for discussion and debate about his alternative tax model. I guess it will be interesting to see if the Treasurer (Mr Costello) affords him the same courtesy as he affords, for example, the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham) when he comes up with policy proposals. I guess time will tell in relation to that.

The Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 continues the tax law improvement project process of rewriting the income tax legislation. This TLIP process was instituted by Labor to address the constant and reasonable criticism that the income tax legislation had become too long and too complex.

It is important to realise the underlying reason for the constant increase in the complexity of income tax legislation. It is quite simply a function of the increasing complexity of business and the constant practice of tax avoidance. The law has been constantly updated to attempt to ensure that all taxpayers can continue to contribute a fair share of income tax. Unfortunately, no matter how many loopholes are identified and closed, there are always new avenues being developed and new anomalies which need to be addressed.

The TLIP process is one method by which this issue is being addressed. Due to the sheer scale of the task—as others have pointed out, the legislation covers many thousands of pages—it is not feasible to rewrite the 1936 legislation in its entirety in one fell swoop. Accordingly, the TLIP process has proceeded on the basis of redrafting discrete portions of the legislation. This, in itself, does raise problems. However, as it is not possible to achieve the task in one package, there is really no option but to continue on a staged basis.

The bill is the third instalment of the rewrite legislation. The major areas covered in the rewrite are capital gains tax, company bad debts, intellectual property, and environmental expenditure, including environmental impact statements. These are all important areas of business taxation and, hopefully, the redrafted provisions will improve the ease with which business interprets, and complies with, these areas of the law.

As well as rewriting the law, the legislation takes the opportunity to effect minor policy changes to make the law clearer and simpler. This is not an attempt to significantly change the policy governing these areas; rather, the objective is limited to replacing impractical rules with ones that are easier to comply with, simplifying the rules that are retained, deleting the unnecessary ones, removing anomalies and clarifying ambiguities as much as possible. Without commenting on any particular examples, this approach seems reasonable to the opposition, and we are not opposed to this general course of action.

Consistent with the practice of the prior TLIP bills, the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit has examined the bill and reported earlier this month, in Report No. 356. The report canvasses the usual range of concerns raised in the TLIP process, such as that there has been inadequate time for proper consideration by industry of the ramifications of the new wording; that the commencement date for the new provisions should be delayed beyond the 1 July proposal; and that therefore there should be a no detriment rule introduced, so that taxpayers can choose either the existing law or the new law.

While there is some substance to these concerns, the problem is that, if the parliament were to agree to the no detriment rules, the whole rewriting process would be effectively rendered worthless. There would be the impossible situation of two parallel sets of income tax law operating, with taxpayers being able to choose the particular wording from either the old legislation or the new legislation—whichever suits them. Obviously that would encourage aggressive tax planning activity, especially by those with considerable means, and that would inevitably result in lower revenue collections than would otherwise be the case. Clearly, that would be an undesirable and an unfair outcome, and, accordingly, Labor will not support such a proposition.

That said, we are concerned about a number of the specific issues that were brought to the attention of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit by various witnesses. There are various situations where the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit is concerned about the potential for double taxation, including those provisions mentioned in recommendations 6 and 9 of the report. In addition, recommendation 8 touches on the very complex issue of the taxation of compensation payments received where an asset is destroyed.

The joint committee makes the sensible point that, if a ruling on the operation of the provisions is 355 paragraphs long, then there must be a great deal of uncertainty surrounding the operation of the provisions, and this uncertainty should be addressed. There were many other technical issues highlighted by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit report, and I indicate now that the opposition will support the government amendments that will be moved later in the debate to address the issues raised in the report.

Simplification of tax law is clearly no easy matter. We have thousands of pages of tax law. We endeavour to condense them to fewer thousands of pages of tax law. The problem is of course that some bright sparks—and there are certainly plenty in the taxation advice industry—will want to say that these words now mean different things from what the previous words meant. We can expect some new litigation and testing of the meaning of the words that are passed by the parliament.

It is a difficult area in which to achieve simplicity. That leads some people to say that we could achieve greater simplicity of the taxation system, for example, through the introduction of a goods and services tax. If you believe that, you will believe anything. The present situation for small businesses, for example, is that some 75,000 of them are collectors for the wholesale sales tax system. If a goods and services tax were to be introduced, more like one million small businesses would become collectors of the goods and services tax. That comes to us from the government, which proposes that red tape for small business ought to be reduced by 50 per cent.

We have a situation where we could be looking forward to new computer systems, new cash registers, calculations being required which previously were not required and a whole series of transactions, particularly in the services field, which were not previously subject to or part of the taxation net, becoming part of the taxation net. This would mean all kinds of services—visits to the theatre, visits to the footy, haircuts, all sorts of things—becoming part of the taxation net, and the system accordingly would become more complex. Certainly, from the opposition point of view, we reject the notion that that would provide for a simpler taxation system.
As I indicated at the outset, we are supporting the government's bill and believe that this is part of an appropriate process of taxation law improvement. We look forward to its continuation.

talk.start.para: —I thank the honourable member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) for most, if not all, of his comments on the Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 . I had the privilege of participating in the 2½ days of public hearings in a round table format with some of Australia's top tax accountants and tax lawyers, together with the officials from the department, the TLIP group—including the three private sector consultants on the TLIP group—and the private sector consultative committee. It was for me a real learning experience.

speech.para: I went to the first day of those hearings expecting, quite frankly, to be bored out of my mind. In fact, I found the whole process invigorating. I enjoyed it. The debate was not acrimonious; it was harmonious, but people put their points of view strongly. By the time we had finished the 2½ days, the committee was satisfied that it had a grasp of the major issues and some specific policy changes requested by the private sector, and that it had a grasp of the overall importance of the legislation and of the processes that had been followed. Accordingly, the committee made its report.

As noted by the Parliamentary Secretary (Cabinet) to the Prime Minister (Mr Miles) in his second reading speech, this bill is the third instalment in a total rewrite of the 1936 tax act as amended from time to time. I have no difficulty in remembering that year, as I joined this earth at that time. I do not know what that has to do with the bill; I just thought I would throw it in.

talk.start.para: —You may have been here before.
—That is absolutely true: I may have been here before, but I do not recall it.

speech.para: The new look tax act is in plain English and is intended to be more easily understood by those who use it regularly—taxation accountants and lawyers. The government is to be congratulated on undertaking this mammoth task of simplifying and restructuring the tax act to make it clearer for the practitioners required to use it in their daily business. I also acknowledge the excellent work done by the TLIP group, and the private sector representatives advising them, in producing this legislation. The key aim of this simpler and clearer format is to reduce compliance costs to taxpayers. That has to be a primary objective.

The Tax Law Improvement Bill (No. 2) 1997 is of particular interest to small business because it contains the rewritten rules about capital gains and losses and their treatment by the tax office with regard to capital gains tax. I am delighted the government has amended the original bill as a direct result of the recommendations made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit in its report No. 356, tabled in parliament on 12 March 1998.

The government has accepted all of the committee's recommendations for technical changes. The government has also made changes to the explanatory memorandum along the lines recommended by the committee. Of some continued concern, however, is the fact that the number of issues to be discussed remains limited to about 12 a year. I am particularly pleased to note the government's adoption of recommendation 3—to delay introduction of proposed subdivision 118-F and divisions 123 and 138 pending review by the JCPAA. That was a particular part of our recommendations.

The member for Wills talked about the private sector asking for either a no-detriment clause to be put into the bill for a period of some two years or both the 1936 act and the rewritten act to operate in parallel for some period of time. The committee, on balance, while it understood the private sector concerns—as the member for Wills has rightly pointed out—came down on the side of workability for tax agents and tax lawyers in the field in view of the difficulty that we would impose on them by having two parallel acts running at the same time and them having to go through both acts on a particular issue, pick the one that they thought suited them best and then try to use that as their justification for their approach with their client to the tax office. We thought, on balance, that that would lead to an impossible situation.

We are pleased that the government has accepted our recommendation, that the bill will go ahead as amended and that further amendments will be made in order to pick up subdivision 118-F and divisions 123 and 138 after the JCPAA has had the opportunity to review those sections both with TLIP and with the private sector consultant.
The bill describes division 138—`Dealings between companies under common ownership'—as being:
. . . designed to overcome timing advantages that bring forward capital losses and defer capital gains that can arise when value is shifted between companies under common ownership.
It says:
Value shifts can occur when one company (the originating company):
. transfers a CGT asset to another company (the recipient); or
. creates a CGT asset in the recipient (for example, by creating contractual rights or granting an option);
for less than its market value.
This will reduce the market value of the shares in the originating company and increase the market value of shares in the recipient company.

These issues are of vital importance to business and it is essential that proper consideration of the full implications of the rewrite be undertaken by JCPAA. At this stage it has not been possible to scrutinise this division at committee level.

Proposed division 123 deals with rollover relief on the disposal of assets of small businesses and proposed subdivision 118-F with exemption for disposals of small business retirements assets. Both these issues were the fulfilment of election promises to the small business community. Both of these rewrites will be subject to further review by the joint committee to ensure proper scrutiny and the identification of any unintended consequences that may arise.
The bill includes some enhancements in the rewritten rules to clarify previously complicated, uncertain or ambiguous convoluted terminology. For example:
Division 104 lists all the events that may result in a capital gain or capital loss. It also specifies for each kind of event:
. how to calculate the amount of any gain or loss;
. the time of the event, which in turn determines when the gain or loss is made; and
. cases in which gains are losses or disregarded for CGT purposes.

The term `CGT event' is a new term that spells out in plain English when a capital gain or loss occurs. This area has been particularly complex in the past, with no clear definition about the timing of a capital gain or a capital loss. It also includes the important issue of deeming whether or not a gain or loss has occurred. If for no reason other than this, it is important for the bill to pass into legislation so that it can be enacted before 1 July 1998.

The new division 108 covers the three categories of assets that may be liable to capital gains and losses. They are: capital gains tax assets, collectables and personal use assets. The bill clarifies the circumstances under which a CGT liability arises.

The definitions of what comprise these categories are clear and concise and should make it easier for taxpayers to determine their CGT accessible property. A change of significant value to some home owners is the new provision that allows a person to continue to apply the main residence exemption to the disposal of vacant land where the dwelling that was on it is accidentally destroyed.

The old act denied an individual a CGT exemption on the sale of vacant land if the main residence was destroyed by, say, a bushfire. For a range of reasons, the people who lose their homes through fire may not wish to rebuild on the same site. Under the new law, section 118-160, they will be able to apply the main residence exemption rules to the disposal of the vacated land as if the residence was not destroyed. This is a genuine benefit for those whose homes are devastated in a bushfire and who cannot face the prospect of rebuilding or living in the same spot again.

This is good legislation. It is good because it simplifies very complex law to make it easier for practitioners on the ground to advise their clients. It is not intended that a layman be able to read every section of the new act and necessarily come to grips with it or understand it. It is, however, intended to put in plain concise English all those tax laws which will enable the professional to treat them properly.

talk.start.para: —That's a bit of a contradiction, isn't it?

—In a way. The member for Port Adelaide interjects. Yes, that is true but capital gains tax is very complicated. I must admit that I have a personal view that, if we could simplify capital gains tax, and if we could reduce the rates of capital gains tax, I would be pleased. It would be good for business, for jobs and for the country. It is a very difficult issue. I am sure we will come to grips with it as we further address the important issue of taxation reform. I move:

interjection.para: That further proceedings on this bill be conducted in the House.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 12 March, on motion by Mr Miles:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 is the government's substantive response to the recommendations of the inquiry of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues into the child support scheme. It proposes a number of changes. It proposes, firstly, to introduce a minimum child support liability for all non-custodial parents of $260 per annum, and secondly, to include net rental property losses—that is, negative gearing types of losses and exempt foreign income—in the taxable income for child support purposes.

speech.para: It proposes to introduce case management to assist parents at risk of family violence, to end the collection of child support or, indeed, to recommence the collection of child support as appropriate. It proposes to increase the exempt income of the child support payers by 10 per cent. For 1997-98, the exempt amount would be $9,907 for single payers and $16,525 plus additional amounts for each child for payers with natural or adopted children in their care.

It also proposes to lower what is referred to as the `payee's disregarded income' from $37,424 to $29,598 by using a figure known as the `all employees average total weekly earnings' rather than full-time adult weekly earnings. It needs to be pointed out at once that this reduction will be offset by the halving of the rate at which child support is reduced from the present dollar for dollar reduction in child support once you are over that income limit to 50c in the dollar. So that will offset the lowering of the payee's disregarded income. Payees may seek reassessment if they incur high child-care costs exceeding five per cent of their income.

The bill also seeks to revise the child support scheme objectives to recognise that both parents are responsible for the support of their children. It seeks to allow parents, by agreement, to undertake private collection of child support at any time, and it talks about using the most current taxable income information available in the child support assessment. However, I would want to suggest to the committee that simply using the previous tax year, rather than the one before, does not really resolve the problems that we have where people are required to make estimates of their income, or are subjected to the indexation factors, and if it turns out that their income is less than they have estimated, but that estimate is less than 15 per cent, in fact, they cannot recover the amounts that they pay in child support.

It also seeks to introduce an internal review mechanism for objection to decisions made by the Child Support Agency. It proposes to deem a stepchild to be a relevant dependent child where the court has made a relevant order under the Family Law Act. It also proposes to continue child support liability until the end of the school year when you have got a child who is undergoing full-time secondary education and that person turns 18 during that school year. The proposal is that the liability would continue to the end of the school year. It makes a series of other administrative changes which are, I think, of less significance.

It has to be said that the child support legislation has been controversial and was the subject of an extensive inquiry by a committee of the parliament, the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. I have a copy of their report which goes to approximately 700 pages. That committee received 6,197 submissions which, I understand, is the largest number ever received by any parliamentary committee, and a hotline organised by the joint select committee generated 150,000 calls in some two days of operation. So there is a very substantial degree of community interest and community concern in relation to this issue.

This is also borne out by the fact that the 1995-96 Commonwealth Ombudsman's report notes that the Child Support Agency accounted for some 16 per cent of all the complaints to the Ombudsman's office. I understand that the Child Support Agency receives in excess of 4,000 letters a day and, in terms of more recent information which I obtained from the Child Support Agency, from 1 July 1997 to 30 November 1997 it received 17,516 applications for departure from the standard formula. So there is no doubt that the Child Support Agency has generated a lot of community comment and, indeed, community concern.

When the child support review was conducted by the joint select committee, it concluded that the development of the child support scheme was a qualified success. It pointed out that it had been successful in sheeting home to parents responsibility for looking after their children, and making it clear that it was not acceptable to have children and then to walk away from that responsibility to look after them until they attained the age of majority.

It ought to be said that some members of the government have been highly critical of the child support scheme. Indeed, I think that it is fair to say that it was used in some places as a campaigning weapon against Labor. But, if we look at the legislation before us, the government has essentially acknowledged the success of the child support scheme by only tinkering at the margins. I have made a few calculations about the impact of the child support scheme changes being proposed by this bill and I think that you will find they indicate that the changes are very small indeed, and very much at the margin.

For example, if we look at a non-custodial parent who has a child support liability or obligation for two children, if their income is presently $80,000 or more, they pay 24 per cent of that income in child support to look after those two children. Under the government's changes, allowing for rounding, they will still pay 24 per cent of their income in looking after those two children.

If we move to $70,000 per year, they presently pay 24 per cent of their income in looking after two children. Under the government's model, that will move to 23 per cent, and so on down the line. If your income is presently $60,000 you have to pay 23 per cent of your income in child support. If you have two children to look after, you will still have to pay 23 per cent of your income. If your income is $50,000, the amount you have to pay will remain at 22 per cent under the government's model. If your income is $40,000, current payments of 21 per cent will move to 20 per cent, allowing for rounding in these matters. The same sorts of situations apply if you factor in looking after one child, looking after five children, and so on.

The impact of increasing the exempt income amount by 10 per cent to 110 per cent of the pension rate will be very much at the margin. Indeed, if you look at the government's examples as set out in the explanatory memorandum, this point is made clear as well. On page 14 of the explanatory memorandum there are calculations for a hypothetical couple, Peter and Francine, who have three children and have separated.

In this hypothetical example, Peter's taxable income is $42,000 and Francine's taxable income is $14,000. The current child support annual rate is $11,163, but under the government's proposed change it will be $10,795, a very small change indeed and even smaller if you look more closely at the calculations and see that there are different inflation factors from one year to the next.

Similarly, the government's proposed changes regarding a carer's disregarded income amount will also have a negligible effect. In the government's example concerning the impact of reducing the disregarded income amount, but offsetting that with a move from dollar for dollar reduction to 50c in the dollar reduction, they give the hypothetical example of Peter with $42,000 and Francine, on this occasion, with $48,000. Under the present arrangements, Peter has to pay Francine $7,686. However, under the changed arrangements brought in by the government's legislation, Peter will have to pay Francine $7,663, which is $23 per annum less. I do not think that will cause Peter to be breaking out the champagne, quite frankly.

Indeed, that is the pattern of the changes. They are differences absolutely at the margin. That is one reason why they have not attracted a great deal of public comment, either concern from custodial parents or support and applause from non-custodial parents. I guess this amounts to inherent recognition from the government of the scheme's value.

We now have a situation where the government has fallen in behind the child support scheme, leaving those who have been critical of it in an interesting position. I note on the speakers list there are a number of government speakers who I recall have been quite critical in the past of the child support scheme, so I will be interested to see what their approach is in the debate in relation to this issue.

The opposition has a number of amendments which we propose to move during the committee stage of this debate. I hope that the government will see its way clear to support these amendments, or at the very least provide us with an appropriate explanation as to why it would not be prepared to support those amendments. Indeed, if the government is not prepared to support those amendments then I hope that some of those government MPs who have taken an interest in child support issues will see their way clear to support them themselves.

For our part, good public policy is always an unfinished business. Just because the child support scheme is a pioneering, trailblazing scheme it does not mean that it is perfect and does not mean that it will not require tinkering or adjustment in the future. On the contrary, it is all the more probable that pioneering and trailblazing legislation will require tinkering and adjustment in the future. We are happy that the government has examined this issue and happy that it has come forward with a number of changes for the parliament to consider.

As I said, we have put forward a number of amendments which we believe pick up issues arising out of the report from the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues that have not been appropriately dealt with so far. Those proposed amendments concern, firstly, direct payments in the child's interest. They follow recommendations 67 and 68 of the joint select committee and would allow the Child Support Registrar the discretion to credit certain non-agency payments as child support when in the registrar's opinion—let me emphasise that—these payments are in the interests of the child, subject to a 25 per cent limit on the amount of child support which the payer is obliged to pay before the custodial parent's consent is required.

As those who have followed this debate and have seen the recommendations of the joint select committee will be aware, this is designed to give non-custodial parents a more realistic opportunity of participating in the raising of their children. I think that is an important and worthwhile objective and always to be seen as part of this scheme; we want to have non-custodial parents involved in the raising of their children. It also endeavours to address, in part, the concerns of non-custodial parents about the lack of accountability for how child support is spent. Some of the evidence that the joint select committee received from payers in this area is somewhat hysterical; some of it proposing that there ought to be accountability for every single dollar. That is not something which, as a matter of public policy, ought to be supported. It would be extremely intrusive into the life of the custodial parent and it would also be very costly and cumbersome to administer. In coming up with the recommendation, I think the joint select committee did go some way towards addressing those concerns. We are, therefore, proposing to move this as an amendment.

We are also looking at trying to ensure that changes in income are properly reflected in child support liabilities. At present, the non-custodial parents who suffer a reduction in their income cannot recover any payments that they make unless that reduction exceeds 15 per cent. Recommendations 125 to 127 of the joint select committee provide for a much more up-to-date assessment of income and thereby largely address this problem. The government has made some changes, both in this legislation and previously, which are intended to help address this problem but, as far as we can tell, it still remains a serious issue for people making estimates of their income. Let us say that a person is employed as a part-time cleaner; that they have a part-time cleaning contract. If the contract comes up for renewal and they miss out on the contract, their income is therefore reduced but their child support is paid on that earlier basis and they are not entitled to recover the overpayments.

This strikes us as a problem that could be better addressed. Therefore, we are proposing that recommendations 125 to 127 of the joint select committee be put forward to address this. We think there ought to be a financial penalty on anyone who deliberately or recklessly provides false or misleading information. We do not want to encourage dishonesty in this area and this is something that the joint select committee also recommended at 128 and 129.

We also propose to put forward some amendments which will attack child support avoidance which continues to be a problem. Joint select committee recommendation 142 is designed to help repair the child support income base by identifying parents who receive business or investment income and the extent to which those parents minimise their child support liabilities in that way. Joint select committee recommendations 143 and 144 propose that fringe benefits should be added to the existing child support income base for both parents and we should require both parents to provide full details of all fringe benefits received from an employer.

We also put forward proposals for changes to the modelling of the scheme. Joint select committee recommendation 162 proposes that we include the impact of the relative disposable income of custodial parents and non-custodial parents of the value of fringe benefits provided by all levels of governments to parents who are social security recipients. We also propose that that assessment be conducted by a body independent of the Department of Social Security.

Finally, we will be putting forward an amendment concerning the issue of subsequent family repartnering following joint select committee proposal 139 that a non-custodial parent's subsequent family formula self-support component be increased so that the relativity between the single and married rate of pension is reflected in the basic and subsequent self-support component.

These are things that I propose to speak to in more detail during the committee debate, but I do believe that this amendment would go some way towards addressing what is an increasing concern that the children of subsequent relationships are being treated as less valuable than the children of a first relationship.

As I said before, the child support legislation is pioneering legislation and its impact is beginning to be measured and understood. I obtained recently from the Child Support Agency a very interesting paper from Allan Shephard of the Child Support Agency's Research and Policy Unit. The paper was prepared in September 1997 and compares Australia's with other child support schemes. It ought to be noted that there are very few legislatively based child support schemes around the world and this comparison focuses on Australia, the United States, New Zealand and the United Kingdom. Canada has recently introduced a child support scheme with legislative backing, but it is too recent for there to be relevant data available. It is interesting to note that if you look at the collection as compared with case load and convert it to Australian dollars as the researcher has done, you see that in the United States the average Australian dollar collection per case is $816; in New Zealand it is $1,111; in the United Kingdom it is $1,302 per annum; in Australia it is $2,368 per annum. In terms of where we are in Australia, we are a long way ahead of the world and there is no question that this is the best place in the world by far to be a custodial parent and nothing in the government's legislation in my view will change any of that, with the changes being very much at the margin.

I do want to make some comments about the issue of the relationship between child support and matrimonial property which is an area of some concern which was identified by the joint select committee in its report. Indeed it devotes a whole chapter to the issue of the relationship between child support payments and matrimonial property and expresses some concern in the report that a non-custodial parent might agree to a property settlement which includes provision for the custodial parent and children to remain in the family home and then discover at a later date that the non-custodial parent is responsible for a substantial child support liability which arguably includes a component for housing. The committee received submissions to it which referred to this phenomenon as double-dipping.

It is interesting to note that the Family Court's submission stated that anecdotal reports from the legal profession indicated that the child support formula and the scheme in general have had little, if any, impact on levels of property adjustment. Michael Watt, from the Law Council, stated:
. . . there is undoubtedly a lag in the recognition by the judicial and legal culture of the structural change which the Child Support Assessment Act has brought into the whole process.
The Chief Justice of the Family Court stated:
I do not think that there is any discernible effect on the level of property settlements as a result of this legislation.

This is an issue which I took up with one of the judges of the Family Court, Justice Mushin, when I was a member of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. In terms of property settlements, he stated that, in his view, child support is a maintenance thing, that the need to house children—those capital sorts of things—are not part of what child support is about.

It is certainly my understanding—and if you talk to those responsible for the child support scheme about the formula, the 18 per cent, 27 per cent, 32 per cent and so on, it is also their understanding—that child support is intended to cover accommodation for children. So it seems to me that we do have a problem in relation to double-dipping. I suggest, however, that the way in which property settlements are conducted is most properly addressed back at the Family Court. Rather than being an appropriate topic for review in this legislation, they are something which the child support scheme itself should be able to address.

Child support arouses very strong passions, and it is seen as evidence that there is a gender war taking place in our society. The member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), who has spoken on this issue before, was absolutely right when, in previous debate in this place concerning child support, he called for us to stop looking at this issue through the prism of gender.

We find this exhortation very hard because at present, in over 90 per cent of cases of separation or divorce, it is the woman who ends up with the children and becomes the custodial parent, and therefore in over 90 per cent of cases it is the man who is the non-custodial parent and liable to pay child support. I personally think that, in the long run, the best way to get the heat out of this area and to lower its emotional temperature would be for us to move to a situation where fathers have custody of children in something approaching 50 per cent of cases rather than in the less than 10 per cent at present.

Whether the reason why they do not have custody in 50 per cent of cases at present is that they do not seek it or that the Family Court tends to award custody to mothers is something that I do not know a great deal about. In any event, it is well beyond the scope of the legislation which we are considering to attempt to address such an issue.

But if, as a society, we did move towards a situation where post separation a lot more fathers were directly responsible for the care of their children, then I think we would have a calmer public debate. We might see the calls for change to the formula subside or, if they continued, we might be in a better situation to be able to deal with them.

One of the things that troubles me about the present operation of child support is that it does not make any practical distinction between cases where men are happy to father children and then move on, taking no responsibility for the welfare of those children—those whom President Clinton has rightly condemned as `deadbeat dads'—and the cases where a father is only too happy to continue raising the children, often cases where he did not initiate the marital split in the first place but is prevented from raising the children by a Family Court decision. In these cases of unsuccessful attempts to win custody, the child support scheme seems to the father concerned to add insult to injury.

I hope that in the future we will be able to move forward to a situation where there is less hardship and misery all round. There is no question in my mind that the breakdown of a marriage, or of any relationship involving children, is a terrible thing. It leaves emotional scars on both parents and on the children. We try, as a parliament, to do justice in each of these situations as best we can to each of the parties and to help them through these difficult circumstances.

I hope that the government's bill represents a further step in the development of a fair and just social policy. As I indicated at the outset, we will be supporting it. We will also be moving amendments on which we will have a debate in the committee stage and taking up issues there which we hope will improve it further.

talk.start.para: —This legislation has certainly been widely welcomed in Townsville and is a small step in the right direction. I am also interested to hear of the amendments that the opposition have proposed.
—It is really nice to see them.

—I was going to make that point, Mr Billson. It is perhaps a bit late in the day, but certainly some of them seem attractive. I am surprised, and perhaps many of the members here today would be too, that perhaps the legislative changes need to go significantly further down the track in order to address some of the root and core problems of the Child Support Agency. I think many members feel very deeply about this. Certainly in our electorate offices there is widespread contact with both sides of the equation indicating the kinds of issues that are continually there.

speech.para: Child support is a difficult issue. It is a dreadfully complex and terribly emotional issue and, by the very nature of family breakdown, is often quite adversarial. The fundamental problems of the Child Support Agency are felt right throughout Australian society: rich or poor, black or white, north or south. You name a section of the community and somewhere you will find family breakdown and people with problems associated with child support.

We all have our own horror stories to tell about constituents who have been dragged through the Family Court and the child support system. They may be mothers living on the edge of poverty because the father has done a runner and is refusing to contribute financially to support the child. They may be fathers who have not seen their sons or daughters for months, if not years, because they have shifted towns or states.

Laurie Chalker was something of a regular in my electorate office, discussing the need for fundamental family law reform and Child Support Agency reform, up until the beginning of this year. Sadly, his problems overwhelmed him, driving him, like many others, to take his own life. All of my staff in my electorate office were touched personally by his passing.

We never really got to know Laurie personally. By that I mean we did not know what sort of a family man he was, where he grew up and so on. What we did get to find out was that he was passionate about reforming the system and the sorts of things we have in this legislation today, which in his eyes and in the eyes of many thousands of other people throughout Queensland and Australia seem far from fair and equitable. He was passionate about reform and what it meant specifically for non-custodial fathers. It was not difficult to understand from where his frustration developed over time.

Shortly before he died, Laurie Chalker had a visiting schedule determined by the Family Court so that he could see his child. Laurie was in Townsville but his child was in Cloncurry, some 700 kilometres west of Townsville. Laurie had to arrange for and pay, without assistance from anyone, transport to and from Cloncurry, accommodation, meals and so on. When he was there, he had to arrange and pay for qualified and approved supervision on all of the visits. To his frustration, often that may not have been available on the weekend when he was able to go. Each of his visits was for a certain day of the month and, if the supervisor was not available, well then it was a case of bad luck. I am sure Laurie knew many more sole mums and dads much worse off than he was.

I support this bill as it is a step in the right direction. But, in the overall scheme of things, it is only a small step and we certainly need to try harder and harder. The fundamental principle behind these reforms, as the second reading speech of this bill states, is:
. . . parents are primarily responsible for the financial support of their children.

I certainly support that. I have no doubt that reform of the Child Support Agency must go further. I am pleased that the government has recognised this and I look forward to participating and contributing to those necessary further changes.

talk.start.para: —In the debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill, I certainly support the view that reform needs to go further. I have already spoken in this place about the failure of the Labor government to pick up the recommendations of the report, so I do not want to traverse that again. If this is a small step, there are many people that are going to feel completely let down by these changes. They are wimpy. They do not go far enough. They certainly are not fair or equitable. The thing that I find the most difficult to comprehend is that in the committee it was not just my view—in fact, I credit the President of the Senate, Senator Reid, with saying this—that we have brought down a balanced package of recommendations and that government should not cherry-pick their way through it. But successive governments have attempted to do just that.

speech.para: I almost feel, 3½ years after bringing down the report, and now seeing this passage of measures going through, that we ought to consign the report to history. It will always stand a good test of time, in terms of a base document. But I really feel that we now probably need to move on and take a more different approach. I notice that the government, having set up one backbench committee on child support, has this week announced the formation of a second backbench committee on child support. However, the chairman, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Anthony), will not be participating in this debate. It does not augur well.

The first thing I want to say is regarding the modelling of changes. The committee developed a package of changes to the formula. Before we agreed on that, we asked the Department of Social Security to model these and proposed other changes. That took six months and a technical upgrade of their computer. I say to government members that, if you are so proud of the changes that you have made, where is the modelling information? We have the explanatory memorandum to the bill. There is in it absolutely no modelling of these changes. There are examples of the impact, but no modelling. Why is there none?

One of our amendments picks up the recommendation that DSS should not have a monopoly on the modelling. Why, I ask government members, have you picked 10 per cent? Why not 15 per cent? Why not 7.5 per cent, for that matter? What is your argument for picking 10 per cent? There is no argument. It is like this: `We have got 10 per cent. Thou shalt have 10 per cent.' I am not saying 20 per cent is immutable. I am not saying that lowering the disregarded income level that we recommended is immutable. We picked the pension cut-off point to avoid double whammies of poverty traps.

There was another argument. For example, the Family Court did not say that it should go down to the $29,598 that you are recommending. The Family Court said to us, `In the interests of fairness in terms of parents' capacity to pay, it should go down to $15,000.' We did not agree with that. We set the pension cut-off point—recognising that, in the formula of changes proposed by the committee 3½ years ago, that was seen as the minimum necessary to restore some equity and fairness. What is it about this new level that has prompted you to change it? Please tell us. I may agree with you or I may disagree with you, but there is absolutely nothing of it in the explanatory memorandum.

If there are people who really do think that this is a wonderful bill, that we are at last seeing some changes—I could use an expletive but you are in the chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, and I would not. This is nothing more than a revenue raising measure. Do government members know how much money this is going to raise? Between $47.2 million and $26.2 million—straight into consolidated revenue.

talk.start.para: —Rubbish!
—Read your own explanatory memorandum. Do the maths. It is in the first section of the explanatory memorandum.
—It is when the partners, though—

—I am sorry, it is all accounted for. I am just making the point that if this bill goes through it is expected, depending on which figure you use—and I agree that there are two figures in the explanatory memorandum—that consolidated revenue is going to be better off by between $47.297 million and $26.2 million.

speech.para: My simple point to government members would be: would this not be better being applied to families or applied to children? I am not particularly fussed what you choose, but would it not be better going to the families that are affected by this legislation rather than being pocketed by the government? That is partly why I am so disappointed.

I think people who have looked to this government to introduce reform are going to be surprised, even shocked, that the reform package nets the government money. I can tell honourable members how it is done. I know they are very upset about it all. It is done through a means that I fully support: by allowing the registrar to decide that good payers should not be part of the scheme. That is a principle in the report. No-one can afford to have the Child Support Agency growing and growing every year as it has since its existence.

I suppose I need to put forward the usual disclaimers. I am proud of the child support scheme. It was a good scheme. I do not think we have looked hard enough at it or tried to refine and reform it sufficiently. That is my only quibble about it. But am I in favour of abolishing the child support scheme? Certainly not. But this is one of the measures to try to contain the growth and to develop the principle that the best relationships are mutually arrived at between the two parties.

There is something not said in terms of shifting people out of the scheme, and I would be grateful to learn what is proposed here. I assume that the registrar is going to have to develop guidelines for traceable payments, so that, in the event that the arrangements break down, people can revert to the Child Support Agency.

I am probably saying something very unpopular amongst a lot of the people that meet me, when I say that I feel very sorry for the Child Support Agency. Why do I say that? I have always said that you can never refine the administration of the scheme to such a perfect point as to think you have solved the problem, until you tackle the hard policy areas. Again the Child Support Agency has been left with the burden of administering some flawed policy areas.

I do not think I have said exactly what increasing the exempted income means for the paying parent—this 10 per cent. Lest we rush away with the thought that this is going to have a fabulous impact on the living standards of these paying parents, let me say that, if a paying parent has one child, this 10 per cent is going to mean a difference of an extra 46c per day. Even the weekly amount of $3.25 per week is not going to pay for a packet of cigarettes—at best, half a packet of cigarettes.

For the parent who is paying for two children, this 10 per cent increase is going to mean that, in their disposable income, they are going to have $4.80 per week or 68c per day. It is true this is better than nothing—absolutely—and I support it on that basis. But let us not run around saying that we have addressed the concerns of the paying parent. I do not think we have. I reiterate that the 20 per cent in the report was seen as a minimum necessary, not a maximum. In fact, we had modelled up to an extra 60 per cent.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I told you that this nets revenue to the government. If they had gone to the 20 per cent that would have cost an extra $10 million. They could have well afforded it. It has, in additional family payments, impact on the caring parent, which I acknowledge. However, it would have cost, in additional family payments, an extra $10 million a year. It is pretty miserable to be pocketing this money and not looking to do more for those that are directly affected.

This bill imposes a minimum payment, something that I certainly support and that was part of the recommendation. But, again, this was predicated against a more balanced treatment of all the other recommendations. Perhaps the government members have not thought about this, but when you are giving 46c or 68c a day—for paying parents with one or two children—this minimum payment is going to affect 31 per cent of the Child Support Agency's clientele. Those are 3½-year-old figures.

What really disappoints me is the lack of explanation. It is very hard to have an argument when people do not offer you their reasoning. I regret that, in anything that I have read about these measures, no reasoning is offered for the approach. It is like: `Well, pick it out.' Is it still 31 per cent? I guess we have to leave it to the experts, but I was surprised at the $2 million that it was said it was going to cost to administer. Not that I thought that was an overstatement—I am not in a position to query it. But I was surprised that it was relatively so low, given the huge number of new assessments that we are going to be making.

With great respect to government members, I would want to feel very confident that this is a very meaningful package, with such large numbers of people now no longer having a nil assessment and having a minimum assessment. Please do not accuse me of duplicity on this—I want to make it very clear that I support the recommendation; I did in the committee, I do now—but I think it is the lack of balance in other measures that is going to leave you very vulnerable. If you are looking at the package as a whole, please do not say that this package errs on the side of the paying parent. It certainly does not. In fact, I think it is the other way around.

I have always been concerned about the fact that this is a scheme about ordinary citizens, ordinary PAYE citizens; that, in fact, it is not a universal scheme. Why is that so? Because it is basically based on the test of what is taxable income.

We all know that professionals, small businesses and people with family trusts have a legitimate way of minimising their income. There are 1.9 million taxpayers—perhaps there are later figures; I would be very grateful for those—who can legally minimise their incomes. Under this scheme, a worker or a battler in my electorate on PAYE taxation is not going to be able to evade or minimise it. But a small businessman—if he has a family trust like most of the cabinet—or a professional can legally avoid his responsibilities. Normally, you would say, `So what!' but this highlights the fact that there is a whole raft of people, predominantly women and children, who are getting nothing out of the scheme. They know that their former partner has assets—which may have been legally transferred—and income that he is living off. But their former partner is paying minimal child support.

This proposal picks up the issue of negatively geared property. I am not against that. We asked the registrar, Michael Carmody, to look at this situation and to do a study. This was one of our recommendations and I understand that the study has been done. I thank him for that. It is disappointing that there is nothing in here. Why haven't we published the study? Why haven't we had a statement about what the outcomes and the conclusions are? We are agreeing about the ramps involved in the taxation system. The government has said nothing about how it is being abused in relation to Australian children.

We recommended draconian measures in the report, and I apologise for harking back to it. Some people have been critical that we did this but it was done with a sense of trying to compel voluntary compliance—that is that group of people that I was talking about. We gave the registrar sufficient powers so that he could deem income and property not to be transferred. This was pretty draconian stuff; this is still not being picked up.

If you have a system like the child support scheme where some people can avoid their responsibilities legally and get away with it but others are, if you like, trapped or compelled into it, it undermines the whole credibility of the scheme.

I only have a couple minutes and I want to go through more of the changes. I agree that it is the first right of the registrar to alter an assessment, to fix up mistakes. I support his ability to vary an assessment on the belief of understatement.

I reiterate the point that I started with. We are now running out of steam with these recommendations for those people who have been seeking to refine and improve the child support scheme. Society moves on. I never thought it would take so long. Certainly, I do not believe that you can set things into cement with a scheme like this. After this bill goes through, we will have to forget whatever was recommended in terms of formula changes. It is a tired old argument and I think we are getting to the point where we need a fresh approach.

Last, but not least, I want to make the point again that the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) made: you cannot fix child support without looking at family law. You will make no headway with domestic violence if you do not look at child support and family law. We must try not to bite these off as separate packages, but to have them a basis for moving forward. More than anything else, avoiding courts and tribunals, and what have you, is a solution, not to cover up something, but on the basis of being able to be in there doing preventative things at the earliest possible time—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I concur with many of the closing remarks of the member for Chifley (Mr Price). He was far more genuine and gracious in his comments near the end and I would encourage him to continue to take a fairly positive and productive outlook in this very difficult area. I have to take exception with almost all he said before he became gracious near the end of his speech. It is a bit hard to hear the opposition members arguing about the lack of reasoning and modelling, and the like, making consideration of these things very difficult. At least you have got what is before us to be considered. We would love to see what your amendments say. We have not seen those at all. Let us have a little bit of consistency in all of this.

speech.para: The other thing that needs to be commented upon is the effort of the member for Chifley at having a go at the government about the lack of pace with which it has implemented the recommendations of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues. I need not remind him that he was singularly unsuccessful in persuading his own colleagues about the virtue of many of these changes. I know that has been difficult and I would certainly—

talk.start.para: —I have always acknowledged that.

—That is right, and I take the interjection that he does acknowledge that he was singularly unsuccessful in having a lot of these amendments and suggestions implemented. They are complicated, and we empathise with the difficulties that you faced—without putting too much of a fine point on it. We understand many of those.

speech.para: I am pleased to have been able to make a contribution to the child support subcommittee that the coalition government formed to bring forward a number of proposals. As has been said repeatedly, and particularly for the members opposite, a good number of us view these as instalments. I certainly do not think that this is the last word on the subject. There are many unresolved issues and a lot of work in progress, but this is, nonetheless, a constructive and positive step forward and we could all have a discussion about how big that step is.

I certainly welcome these proposed changes to the child support arrangements, based on a very simple and central recognition that both parents are responsible for supporting their children. I have had the good fortune of becoming a father in recent times and I think that helps to sharpen one's appreciation of the simple fact that both parents have a very considerable responsibility for the child—and I will talk about those issues as I go through my contribution.

There is no area in the federal government's responsibility that generates as much contact with my office. We see frustrated, angry and disenchanted people, both payers and payees. Even parents, cousins, nieces, nephews, brothers, sisters—and everybody else—come to talk to us about this particular area. People on both sides of the issues, if you could put it that way, come forward with concerns.

I must say though that I do not see the satisfied people. I do not know precisely what it is that makes those people satisfied, but there seems to be a good number of them who feel that the child support system is ably assisting them to fulfil their responsibilities to the child; and, as the other parent also has responsibilities, the system seems to work for them. So there is some good in the Child Support Agency arrangements because they appear to have a number of satisfied customers who, for whatever reason, do not beat a path to my door.

I think that people genuinely want to make a reasonable contribution to the raising of their children from earlier relationships as long as they feel that it is fair. I think that some of the discussion we will be having today, and certainly some of the issues contained in this package of measures, seek to make sure that people do appreciate that there is a genuine effort at fairness. That effort at fairness and an effort to have the system more responsive to the individual circumstances of the parents are things that we should encourage and welcome.

The changes aim to make the child support system fairer to ensure more regular financial support for the children. They recognise that the government should not intrude where the arrangements are working and—here is another common ground I think we share with the member for Chifley—if we can avoid having a government agency involved, that is an admirable objective. These changes go some way toward supporting that.

The introduction next July of a minimum assessment for child support payments of $5 per week sends a much needed and warranted signal that both parents have the primary responsibility for the care of their children. Let us think about what the options are. If the parents are not providing for the children, we all are: the taxpayer provides.

I have great affection for a great number of taxpayers in my electorate of Dunkley, but in terms of their family arrangements, I cannot take any responsibility for that. So, it is entirely appropriate that we do all we can to make sure that those parents who brought these little people into the world understand clearly that they have a responsibility to those children and that it is not satisfactory to simply abdicate that responsibility and pass it on to the taxpayer.

The minimum payment will be welcomed and will not cause low income parents to lose access to family payment income support. The income that is excluded from calculations of child support for paying parents to support themselves is to be increased by 10 per cent to just under $10,000 for single payers and $16,500 for payers caring for other children.

The amount of income the parent receiving child support can earn before payments reduce will drop in July from about $37,500 to $29,600. To ensure fairness, the rate at which child support payments reduce at a payee's level of income above this disregard level will halve, and a reassessment will be available where child-care costs are too high.

Paying parents with second families claiming family payment and child-care assistance will be allowed to deduct half of any child support payments paid from the household income figure used to assess eligibility for these benefits. This has been a major gripe for parents who enter into new relationships after separation or divorce. Allowing this concession will help take away some of the concerns of child support parents.

I welcome the government's encouragement of divorced and separated parents to make private arrangements to transfer child support payments, as 40 per cent of child support agency clients already do quite successfully.

The government also wants to ensure maximum privacy for Child Support Agency clients by introducing proposals such as dropping the names and dates of birth from assessment notices. There is a host of other administrative changes which I believe will simplify the arrangements, provide for much needed review mechanisms, improve privacy, and make the scheme more friendly to people's needs. As I said earlier, this is not the end of it. There is more work in progress.

I would like to pick up on some of the comments the member for Chifley made. I believe very strongly that there is a need to strengthen the appreciation of the interplay between the Family Court and the Child Support Agency. That is tentatively done in this bill where the Child Support Agency registrar can suspend payment where there is a question still to be resolved before the Family Court. But that is just the start of it; we need to go a whole lot further.

Section 79(4)(g) of the Family Law Act 1975 requires the courts to take account of child support payments when determining property settlements. But what we are looking for is an equally strong statement that the reverse should apply as well, where the Child Support Agency needs to take a fuller account of what the Family Court has been doing with its decisions and its judgments.

Payments that clearly benefit the child's upbringing, such as mortgage payments, vehicle payments, paying off credit cards and the like, which are done by the parent without the primary care responsibility, are often viewed as choices by the Child Support Agency. That is, the agency tells these people that, notwithstanding the fact that those payments are important, that they benefit the child, because they are not prescribed in the arrangements that we are working under, they represent a choice. Therefore, they are not taken into account when determining what level of child support liability needs to be met.

I would have thought that the Child Support Agency would be and should be encouraging these sorts of contributions. I will give you an example, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have a number of constituents in my electorate who through their feeling about the way their relationship dissolved and their deep love for their child have said, `Stay in the family home. I will keep paying the mortgage payments'. Why do they say this? They do that because the child can stay in a familiar environment. They can still be amongst their friends, they can go to the same schools, and they can basically have their life as uninterrupted as they possibly can, notwithstanding the difficulty that surrounds a marriage dissolution.

Having made all those decisions and having made all of those, I think, worthwhile contributions to the raising of the child, the Child Support Agency said, `No, that's a choice. You've made a choice to make those payments. On top of those payments, on top of those substantial contributions to the child's wellbeing and development, we want you to pay Child Support Agency payments.' I have had one case where one of my constituents has been left with not much more than about $40 a week in their pocket. That is a very difficult assignment to deal with. I am hopeful that the measures in here that are more accommodating of formula departure claims and reviews will be helpful. This is certainly an area that needs to be looked at. That leads me to the next point dealing with the packaging of property settlement and Child Support Agency decisions at the time a relationship is dissolved.

If we are going to the Family Court, and the Family Court to its credit has financial counsellors who try to work with both parties to come up with a property settlement that is responsive to their circumstances and the like, why can't we include the Child Support Agency in that discussion so that people know the full deal that they are signing up to? As it stands, these property settlements are negotiated often in isolation from the Child Support Agency formulas and responsibilities. So you get through that fairly difficult time and feel that you have come out with an arrangement that everybody can live with, only to find that there is another layer of assessment, another layer of contribution being expected of you from the Child Support Agency.

I have been to the Family Court a few times, out of curiosity and concern about what had been said to me by constituents; I thought it sounded funny so I decided that I would go and spend some time in the Family Court to see how things actually go. I have asked the Family Court why the child support arrangements were not included. The Family Court officer said that they worked to fulfil their obligations under the Family Law Act. That is fair enough. But, in terms of the client, in terms of the families involved, it is not enough. It might be legally quite accurate and quite responsible but it ignores such a large percentage of the picture.

I went to the Child Support Agency and said, `What can we do about this? Can we encourage the Family Court to take a more holistic view?' They said, `We've provided the software. They've got all the material they need to model these things but they just don't do it.' Surely we can get these things together. It is the same people that are involved, the same circumstances that are being considered but, above all, it is the same child or children, and it is their longer-term care and development needs that are at the heart of this whole issue.

The packaging question goes further. I know of a client of the Child Support Agency who has had to pay back money because of the Child Support Agency's interpretation of an incoherent order from the Family Court. No-one could make any sense of it. Everyone thought they knew what it meant but, when it was considered by the Child Support Agency, this constituent in the electorate of Dunkley had to pay back thousands of dollars because someone in the CSA had a different view of a Family Court order that no-one could follow in the first place. Surely, working closer together is the answer. Parenting arrangements, property settlement and child support, in my view, are three legs of the same stool: all need to function together in the interests of the child.

As I was saying, as a recent parent, Steven Biddulph's book is compulsory reading. Biddulph keeps saying that each parent has an important role at varying ages of the child's life and right throughout the child's development. Fine. However, if you are denied that opportunity as a parent, unreasonably, then one of the legs of the stool is compromised. I believe there is then a case to have a look at the other legs of the stool. Where there are consistent contraventions of parenting orders, without cause, perhaps we could look at the child support financial liability being discounted. Maybe the reverse should apply: if you are ignoring your financial responsibilities, perhaps the leg of the stool that says you have certain entitlements to access and contribute to your child's development and personal life should be wound back in some respects.

I am not on about forfeiting rights for people needlessly but somewhere along the line, if people are not fulfilling their responsibilities, some forfeiture should take place that reminds them that they are part of a three-legged contribution in the raising of the child. I am certainly not advocating state sanctioned impoverishment but in my view the development of new tools is essential to ensure that there is improved accountability of the parents and the fulfilment of all their obligations to the child.

The Australian Law Reform Commission in report No. 73 titled `For the sake of the kids' said that enforcement of orders, of contact orders in particular, is basically a criminal procedure. I raised this issue with a Family Court justice, whose name I will not mention, and the indignant reaction I got from that person was, `What do you want me to do—lock the parents up?' No. I do not. I am saying that we need to provide new tools. Just giving me an answer like that does not solve the problem. It does not go away.

The proposition I am hopeful we can consider more—certainly through government channels because we have got more work to do on this—is to look at new tools to make sure that those accountabilities are fulfilled. The accountability issues go further, though. For the payees, there has been some concern raised in a very few cases about the way the funding that is provided is applied.

The last thing I want to see is the Child Support Agency or the government policing parental roles, but where there is evidence of child support payments being consistently applied to purposes other than the raising of the child, whether it be gambling, alcohol or substance abuse, whatever the case may be, surely there is an argument to enable the payer to make direct payments, maybe not with the agreement of the other parent, for costs that go to the very heart of the care of the child. You could discount those payments and have that reflected in the child support liability.
