Surely that is a productive and constructive way of making sure that the child's interests are paramount in these arrangements.

There are also the payers themselves. I concur with some of the views of the member for Chifley about how easy it is to minimise your income. We are trying to do something about that through tax reform and the like so all are paying their fair share of taxes. But where you have got an income based formula and you have got opportunities for people to artificially lower that income, the kids miss out again.

Perhaps having a look at the actual means testing arrangements used for the Austudy youth allowance might be one way of determining a more realistic level of income. I am just putting that forward as a suggestion. I am encouraged again that in this package, the registrar has powers to vary assessments where they feel that the information they are getting just simply is not right.

But the accountability goes further; it goes to the Child Support Agency as well. Through my inquiries and a considerable amount of time put into this subject, it is clear to me that you can forum shop in the Child Support Agency. The discretions that are available within the Child Support Agency are exercised differently at different locations throughout the country. This is unsatisfactory and I would support the introduction of statements of principles or something like that that apply across the board in the Child Support Agency so that when these new discretions—and even the old discretions—are being used at least they are consistent. At least you will know that there will be consistent treatment of those issues before the Child Support Agency. But again, in this package, the strengthening of internal review options should help in some direction in a case by case basis.

Finally, Mr Deputy Speaker, I want to talk about what I call the `stuff it' option. That option is where people just say, `This is all too much. I'm off.' The kids miss out; everyone misses out. That option is too attractive to too many people in my view. I think if we looked at ways of considering the means available to both parents, then we would get a bit more of that fairness view in there that would make this `stuff it' option less attractive. If we had some way of encouraging payers to earn extra income in the interests not only of the child to a degree, but also to themselves and then make sure, if they are taking on second and third jobs, they actually get some benefit from it, then that again reduces the attractiveness of the `stuff it' option.

I also think there is an argument that the proposition contained in this package which allows people to take 50 per cent of their child support payments off their income for the purposes of calculating family payment and child care assistance eligibility for a second family should be extended more widely. I have people coming into my office who are making their child support payments which if deducted from their income would make them eligible for rent assistance, would make them eligible for concession cards and would make them eligible for a whole range of things. What is happening is they are denied those arrangements which are supposed to maintain a base standard of living purely because they are paying the Child Support Agency.

It is very hard to explain to somebody who hardly has money to rub together to pay their rent that their circumstances are not warranting rent assistance when someone whose disposable income is far greater can qualify for it. I am saying perhaps the child support payments should come out of that disposable income calculation for the purposes of looking at those areas.

In closing, I was troubled a little bit by many of the things the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) was saying, opening his contribution by saying we should not make these things political and then proceeding to talk for 15 minutes at a political level. It gives you an idea of where my frustration comes from.

This issue about a gender war troubles me greatly. This is my little guy in this photo. At the end of the day, this is what this is about. I will not table this photo because you will all be very envious of him. But this is about the little people. There is an argument that says this is all about the gender war. It is not for me. This is a war for the kids. We are all here for the kids, in my view.

Questioning proportions of residential care given to males and females and then arguing—as the member for Wills did—that that somehow points to an error in the system, ignores the fact that at certain stages in kids' lives they need each parent in a different way. Right now, I cannot provide for that child's needs as well as my wife can. When that child becomes a young man and is learning to deal with his maleness, my wife cannot provide what I can provide at that time. Kids need both of us. We need the system to support that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The previous speaker, the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Billson), is quite right: at the end of the day, this is about the little people. That is exactly the problem because this legislation was compiled by intellectual pygmies. The legislation is a disaster. If people get up in this place and say they support the legislation, it is a complete cop-out. Nobody, in my view, should be able to avoid paying for the upkeep of their children. In my experience, the great bulk of people want to contribute to the upkeep of their children. But what this Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 does is divide families and it makes the wives and children of second families second-class citizens in Australia.

speech.para: One of the great joys of being an independent is that the Labor Party and the Liberal Party have immediately conspired to keep me off committees, which for the most part are a waste of time; a way of keeping backbenchers occupied. However, this is one committee I would like to have been on because I think I could have made a contribution. This is a social evil in Australia. It is causing chaos particularly in my electorate and throughout Australia.

You see here—and I think the member for Chifley (Mr Price) made this comment—that you cannot consider this legislation without looking at family law in total. What is the reason for family law? The Family Law Court is the fastest growing, most corrupt court in Australia and it should be swept away if we are going to do anything constructive. It should be returned to the states to start with. It should be in the district court with appeals to the Supreme Court.

There is a case that the Child Support Agency could still function. I have heard people here say the Child Support Agency has its hands tied. It cannot take factors into consideration—for instance, if people put their assets in trust. That is not true. The Family Court has the power to assume an income—up to $97,000 a year, I believe it is—and they use this quite wantonly in cases.

I see this day by day in my electorate. The other day I had a 53-year-old man whose crime was to work all the overtime he could because he thought it was to the benefit of his family. He came home one day to find the family gone. His wife had never said to him,`I'd rather have you home; this is no life.' He was making money because he thought that they would be able to retire to the city. Now he is reduced to riding a bicycle in Tom Price at 53 years of age. What justice is that? We see in this child support allowance—and they say it to me all the time—`My hands are bound.' It is not true. There is a lot of discretion there and they do not use it.

In relation to zone allowances and people working in remote areas, often the custodial parent goes to remote areas because he can earn more money. Zone allowances are to take account of the high costs in those areas, yet we tax them. We say, `This is part of your income.' We say, `Second jobs.' A man is struggling. He has an income that was his income when he was married. He goes out and gets a second job because he is married again or living in another relationship, and we make that part of his income. Overtime is part of the income. There is simply no way forward for him.

talk.start.para: —He will never get ahead.

—He is locked in a downward spiral. This just devastates people. I have had people in my electorate simply take that too hard option and retire. They will go from $75,000 a year as a train driver on Hamersley Iron to the dole in Adelaide because they are better off on the dole. That is what the effect of this legislation is. It is a mess. It is a mess because, right from the start, it was introduced by people not with goodwill but a vehement hate of males.
—Oh, come on!
—I do not think there is any doubt about that. There is another explanation: it could be just stupidity. It could be that, and I am prepared to concede that.

speech.para: There is one group of women who do suffer as custodial parents: in my view and in my experience, this group is business women. I have a case that I am very involved with at the moment, where a woman brought all the money and all the assets to the marriage. She ended up with all the kids and the husband ended up with all the assets. Nine years later, she is being pursued for perjury in the Family Court, when she has nothing and he has all the assets. What a nonsense, using public money for this! In the Family Court, everybody lies. I have taken this up with the Chief Justice of the Family Court in Western Australia, Judge Michael Holden. He wrote me back a letter and told me off for my gratuitous insults: in his view, that did not happen. Where is this man living? Of course they lie! It is the adversarial nature of the cases that makes people lie in the Family Court.

talk.start.para: —Order! I do not want to interrupt the honourable member, but I am in a difficulty. You must be very careful when you are referring to the court, because there are standing orders about that. I am drawing that to your attention: we must be a little careful when we are referring to the Family Court or any other court.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I have a very strong view—
—I know; that is what I am worried about!

—that this parliament, the court of the people, is the highest court in the land. The judges are not beyond criticism, nor should they be. For them to hide behind that standing order is, in my view, long out of date.

speech.para: Let us take another example of the anomaly. A custodial parent can be earning $37,424 per year without contributing 1c to the upkeep of the child. That is far more than the non-custodial parent is left with. He will be left with—as the honourable member for Dunkley (Mr Billson) said—$40 per week. We are going to reduce that in this bill—big deal!—to $29,598 to take account of child-care arrangements. It was always in there to take account of child-care arrangements. It was always within its scope to take account of that, but it never was. If the parent has got child-care responsibilities, back it goes now to $37,424.

Of course, it may not be known to some of the honourable members and it may not be known to the Family Court, but there are two people who are responsible for the procreation of children. As a custodial parent, the mother has to accept some responsibility. I think it is absurd to give that very large exemption there. But is this addressed in this act? No; these amendments go simply nowhere. I can tell members that there is nothing, no other single issue, that generates as much angst and animosity in my electorate as this single one does. It constitutes a very large proportion of my office business. But are you addressing it? No, you are not addressing it. This bill goes nowhere.

If we had a tribunal situation to which we could actually refer people, without going to that confounded Family Court, we could keep the lawyers out of it and we might have a better chance. It is at least worth a try. But the fact is the Family Court is growing and growing. To what purpose? It is growing to confound the community and to spread angst and hate in the community.

talk.start.para: —I rise on a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, the honourable member has been here for a considerable period of time and he ought to know that, in standing orders, he is not able to reflect adversely on judges-

—If you had been listening, you would have heard that I have already drawn the honourable member's attention—wait until I have finished—to that. The actual ruling is that you cannot refer to the judiciary itself. It does not exclude you from referring to decisions of the judiciary or decisions of the court. I did drawn the honourable member's attention to that. I have been listening to him very carefully, and he has been reflecting more on the actions of the court than on individual members of the court. While ever he does that—and do not jump up again—he is in order. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has the call.

—On a further point of order, the court basically is the collective number of judges of the court. I listened carefully to what the honourable member said, and he said something to the effect that the court existed to spread hatred. Those sentiments, I believe, are well and truly beyond the standing orders, and I would ask that he stay within the standing orders, accordingly.

—You may believe that. I am in the chair. I have made my ruling. For your benefit, I suggest that you read page 479 of House of Representatives Practice , under the heading `Reflections on members of the judiciary'. You will see that, as usual when I am in the chair, I am correct and you are incorrect. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie has the call.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I take personal exception to the comment that you made and I ask that you withdraw it. What you said was—
—If you take exception to what I say in the chair, there are measures available to you. You should pursue those rather than asking other things. So you should resume your seat.

—On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: you mentioned that `as usual' I am wrong when you are in the chair. That is a reflection and I would ask you not to generalise because, when I do take a point of order, as you would know I take it sincerely and upon consideration.
—You may think that, but I am in the chair. My ruling stands. The honourable member for Kalgoorlie.

—I might say to my honourable friend that I spent a lot of time on this and I am on the receiving end of considerable damages, so I probably know much more about this than you, from your limited knowledge as a lawyer. I can tell you this, with the greatest respect: given your lack of intellectual rigour, I am surprised that you have never been made a judge.
—The honourable member for Kalgoorlie should direct his comments through the chair and return to what we were talking about.
—I am happy to do that. It is quite clear. I am surprised the honourable member never made a judge.

speech.para: Having had my train of thought thoroughly dislocated, I am going to have to recapitulate some of this. Why can't we have a situation where people are encouraged in a tribunal format to discuss these things equitably between themselves? It does not happen. What happens, though, is that the court can come down very hard on the custodial parent and there is no room to move, no room to manoeuvre at all.

The law is the law. It is the embodiment of everything that is excellent, as the honourable member would know. But when it comes to the custodial parent, they can ignore orders of the court with absolute impunity, and they do. They can up and move interstate, imposing an enormous additional cost on the non-custodial parent, and nothing is done about it. Judges will say, as the previous speaker said, `What do you want me to do, gaol them?' If necessary, yes. Why should only one side be subject to the law? The whole thing is just a nonsense.

The other thing is this: you have the non-custodial parent paying out money week after week. A lot of them want to do it; they want to see their kids kept. But they have no say in how the money is spent, absolutely no say at all, and they are precluded by the law from having any say. In some cases, as I know from my experience of cases that come before my office, the money is often spent to keep the new boyfriend; it is spent on clothes. It is not spent on the children.

It is nonsense to suggest that a three-year-old child needs the same income as a 15-year-old child. There should be a way in which this money can be postponed. It would give, in that case, the non-custodial parent the chance in life. The greater income then comes when the child needs that income. Or at least there should be a mandatory requirement to put some of it away for those later costs that are going to be incurred. What happens inevitably is that, when those costs arise, the non-custodial parent is once again hit to meet those costs—and many of those do, if they can, because they have a regard for their children. These things will not be addressed in this act, and they are certainly not addressed by the Family Court.

I know that, when people go before this court, statements are made by the custodial parent. There is some view that custodial parents are somehow pure, and no attempt is made to check statements made by them. It is just not done. It is considered not right, apparently. So they lie and they get away with it, and then the good judge tells me that there is no perjury in his courts. What a nonsense.

I believe that this act, basically, goes nowhere. I am sure the committee laboured mightily but they brought forward, at the very best, a very small egg, and it is a dud one at that. I believe that we have to go to a situation where we have some tribunal arrangement, something very similar to the French model. We ought to be keeping those lawyers at bay as much as we possibly can, and we ought to be taking a much broader look at this whole thing. I can tell you now that this is not a male/female issue; it is the second wives, of second marriages, and the children of second marriages that we, in this parliament, are turning into second-class citizens. There is no justice in that. Of course there is no justice.

Before I was so rudely interrupted, I was going to make the point: why do we have to provide protection to judges in the Family Court? We do not provide it elsewhere. We have to provide protection to judges in the Family Court because the people know there is no justice—that is why. I believe that this act goes a very small way, a negligible distance. I suppose we should be grateful for crumbs. But what we really need is a complete revamp, a complete overhaul, and a sweeping away of the Family Court and returning it to courts where justice can be seen to be done.

talk.start.para: —As a member of the child support subcommittee I rise to take part in today's debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 , which will provide greater equality in the treatment of this very emotive and often difficult matter. As it is an emotional issue, there has been a lot of angst on behalf of both custodial and non-custodial parents in my electorate of Gilmore, and it has been apparent for a long time that changes had to be made. Some of these have been addressed by this government, as the previous Labor government thought it was all too hard. Bear that in mind.

speech.para: I can give members of the Main Committee a quick example of why the current legislation is not working. However, I am sure they all have plenty of their own cases where parents, and in particular children, are facing unnecessary extra financial and emotional burdens because of the unworkable nature of the current system. In Gilmore we have a number of non-custodial parents. It is a fact that they are mostly fathers, though this should not become an issue of gender because that serves only to cloud further a very muddy debate. But there are many non-custodial parents who are struggling to support two families under the current system.

We have grown men who have been forced to return home to the support of their parents in order to be able to continue to meet child support payments. We have non-custodial parents who are better off on welfare because they cannot meet the obligations set down by the Child Support Agency. In one particular case in Gilmore there is a gentleman who has had to resort to living in a tent in order to continue paying for the upkeep of his children, who live with their mother, even though he never sees them and rarely has other contact.

By the same token, the need for strong child support laws and their enforcement is undeniable. I have cases of custodial parents who cannot afford to clothe their children, while the non-custodial parent is living comfortably but refuses to pay their share in the raising of their children, which is still a joint responsibility of parents. And we have non-custodial parents who, far from being forced to apply for income support, do so in order to avoid paying their share of child support for their children.

It is a system which lays as much guilt on children as it does on each parent. Having gone through it myself, I can honestly say that no party is ever free from blame in the fallout from divorce. However, there are some things which can be done to make it easier for children and for their parents to fulfil their obligations and responsibilities to each other and their former families.

By introducing changes to the child support scheme this government has made steps, albeit small steps, in the right direction. For example, removing the obligation of the Child Support Agency to become involved has been a vital issue. There are cases in my electorate of Gilmore, as there would be throughout Australia, where the parents have come to a mutually agreeable arrangement on the issue of child support, yet the agency has determined a different figure and demands to be involved. This demand had the support of the original legislation and it came with an ultimatum from the Department of Social Security that unless the Child Support Agency's agreement was met, the custodial parent would lose their income support. Where is the logic in that?

Removing the Child Support Agency from all agreements, unless they are required to become involved, is a major step in ensuring the best outcome for both parents and, subsequently but more importantly, for the children. However the Child Support Agency should not be made out to be the big bad ogre in all of this, for the support I and my staff have received from agency officers has been tremendous. We have come to an arrangement whereby, every month, agency staff travel from their base in Wollongong to my electorate office in Nowra to hold private interviews with parents who have concerns over child support agreements. The feedback I am getting so far has been very positive. We have managed to resolve most cases just by arranging face-to-face meetings between parties and the agency. These interviews will continue for as long as necessary, even following the positive changes introduced by this government.

While the House is well aware of the changes which we introduced, I would like to quickly refer to the specific reforms which have made the most difference to the lives of many people in my Gilmore electorate. The change to the family payment income test for payers with second families will increase assistance for non-custodial parents with second families. This measure sees non-custodial parents with second families able to claim 50 per cent of any child support they pay as a deduction from the household income which is used for determining the family's entitlement to family payment and child-care assistance. This measure is fair to all parties as it ensures that custodial parents do not lose access to financial support for their children and non-custodial parents receive extra support for their second families.

Another measure was to introduce a minimum child support liability measure for all players, including those on income support at $260 per year or $5 per week, which, in the past legislation, was not introduced. This will fulfil the recommendation—of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues which looked into child support—that there should be minimum payment and the principle that some contribution towards the cost of raising a child is an obligation of all parents, even those who do not have the day-to-day demands of the child as part of their routines and their budgets.

One of the major reforms introduced by this government is one which I, as a former representative of the New South Wales Domestic Violence Advisory Council, totally support and that is to ensure consistency in the treatment of family violence cases.

Before 1 January this year, there was no mechanism to assist parents at risk of family violence to commence or continue collecting child support from their violent spouse. Imagine for a moment that you are at risk from a violent partner. Imagine the pain, humiliation and fear which is part of your everyday family life. When you finally gather the courage to make the move away from this intolerable and unacceptable position, you find yourself in the further untenable, unenviable situation of having to face your partner for funding for the upkeep of your children. This is a totally humiliating experience, to say the least, and it is certainly one which many custodial parents choose not to go through and, therefore, they are left without the financial support for the upkeep of their children which is their right under the law.

Now they have the support of the agency case managers to go through such demanding obstacles and they can continue with their lives with as few financial difficulties as possible. That is a move which has been a long time coming and one which I certainly applaud.

However, as I stated at the outset, these changes are just three of the 18 introduced by this government and they are just the tip of the iceberg in terms of what is required for greater support and equality in the child support scheme for all parents and their children. I am constantly reminded by letters and phone calls from constituents of Gilmore that the changes have not yet gone far enough. The fact that this government has recognised the need for change and done something about it is always commended by my residents who are affected by child support or who know of someone who is, whether it be their son who they are continuing to support as he faces financial difficulties or their daughter who cannot find enough money to feed and clothe herself and her children. But—and there is always a `but' at the end of their sentences—more needs to be done. This is something that we have recognised, with further reforms being debated in the subcommittee on child support.

We have presented submissions to the relevant ministers, the Minister for Social Security (Senator Newman) and the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp), outlining details of what must be done, and yes, they are listening. These changes include the need to reassess the amount of child support which is paid by a non-custodial parent to their former partner. At present, the means test for such arrangements is unfair and there are a number of proposals for reforming this issue, particularly in relation to overtime pay and changes in income following the time after the marriage is dissolved.

Why is it that non-custodial parents who spend their time doing overtime to better provide for their second families must be forced to pay some of that money to the first family, when it was not something that they had access to at the time of their marriage? Who pays when the child is with the non-custodial parent for a length of time? This alone often causes financial strain and when added to the cost of the visit—sometimes to another state and over which non-custodial parents have no control—the burden is and can be enormous.

This is one of the major `buts' which my constituents bring to me and it is one which needs to be addressed. There is scope for addressing it in the next round of reforms which this government will introduce. The changes which came into effect on 1 January were the second stage of a three-stage process which has been evolving over the two years that we have been in government. Understandably, in such an emotive issue, there must be a balance to achieve a fair outcome for all parties. To do so requires wide consultation with community groups and representative organisations, as well as with the agency itself, to determine the most appropriate changes to make and the most effective ways of implementing them. I welcome the chance to provide input to this debate from the people of Gilmore, and I will continue to work with the child support subcommittee for a fairer outcome for all parents and, more importantly, for their children.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, thank you for the opportunity to enter this debate on the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 . It is a very difficult time in the lives of so many people when they and their children are unfortunate enough to experience separation or divorce. No-one would argue with the fact that the child support scheme, as it stands, desperately needs overhauling. It is an unfair and inadequate system of assessing and collecting support for children whose parents are separated and/or divorced.

speech.para: The children of the nation ought to be the responsibility of all citizens, but primarily they are the responsibility of both parents. When, through no fault on the part of the children, the parents' relationship breaks down, the children should not be made the pawns. In an ideal world, both parents should continue to support the children financially, emotionally and in providing role models, but in most cases separation and divorce is not an amicable arrangement.

The usual arrangement, depending on the age of the child or on the ages of the children, is that one parent is given custody, with the other being given access. However, in too many instances the custodial parent uses child support as a bargaining tool. We need to establish a fair and just procedure for collecting child support that is based on the needs of the child or children and on the capacity of both parents to pay. It seems so simple, but in reality it is far from that.

The matter of child support affects so many of our citizens and causes much anger, angst, heartache and suffering. Something like 40 per cent of marriages in this nation end up in divorce, many involving children. A number of constituents have come to me for help with a wide range of personal examples that point to the inadequacies of the child support scheme.

There is no doubt that some custodial parents understate their income. Creative accounting for some self-employed persons can vary the income received, albeit legally, by conceding the income in several ways, not the least of which is by family trusts. On the other hand, there are many examples of a custodial parent denying access to the other parent whether or not child support is paid in that instance. Contributions should be assessed on net income, not on gross income, and overtime should not come into the equation.

Another area of concern raised by a constituent recently is losses from investment properties that should be considered in the assessment of child support liability. If the non-custodial parent were to realise a capital gain from selling the same property, the agency would include profits realised in the assessment. It is grossly unfair.

Other aspects which require addressing include the question of the formula, which I believe is too rigid. Individual assessments should be carried out which look at the needs of the child and the capacity of parents to pay. There needs to be a link between maintenance and support payments and access. If the custodial parent denies access for no valid reason, that parent should have to show cause as to why the child support maintenance payment should not be terminated. We owe it to the thousands who are affected by child support to provide real change which removes the biases and offers genuine and long-lasting solutions which are fair and just.

I hasten to add that I am not being critical of the agency which collects child support. They are doing the best they can with a complex and emotionally charged issue. However, there is no doubt that the agency can increase its vigilance and diligence in investigating individual cases. As is the case with other underresourced government departments, there is no doubt that the agency is overworked and understaffed.

The system needs overhauling in order to give equity and fairness to the parties concerned and, primarily, to safeguard the welfare of the children. The way child support operates at the moment pushes people into finding ways and means of avoiding the payment. If the system is not fair and not seen to be fair, why bother working? It is not flexible enough, in my view, to accommodate changes which are occurring in many cases within a short period of time in the working life of the parties involved.

Some of the people who have come to see me on the matter of child support are almost suicidal and in some cases they are undergoing psychiatric counselling because the system is stacked against them. How does all this impact on the children? Very negatively, I would suggest.

The bill before the House underscores the fundamental principle that parents are primarily responsible for the financial support of their children, and the government, through these measures, would not intrude unnecessarily into people's lives. I support some of the changes which have been proposed to the child support scheme which will address some of the concerns expressed by my constituents, such as the inclusion of net rental property losses and exempt foreign income into taxable income for child support purposes. The exempt income amount will be increased by 10 per cent, recognising the cost of employment faced by payers. Payers with second families will now be able to claim 50 per cent of any child support paid as a deduction from the household income used for determining the family's entitlement to family payment and child-care assistance.

The objectives of the scheme will be revised to recognise that both parents are responsible for the support of their children. Whilst many of these recommendations come into effect on 1 July 1998, regrettably some will have to wait until 1 July 1999. We must stop tinkering at the edges and provide real solutions by implementing the recommendations made by the joint select committee.

The proposals need to take into account the level of disregard of the income for custodial parents, that is, the amount the custodial parent can earn before any reductions in the non-custodial parent's child support payments. The government is encouraging parents to escape from the clutches of the Child Support Agency and deal with child support matters themselves, and that is a very important initiative. This is a very smart move, since estimates suggest that the money recovered by the agency is less than half the costs of administering the system.

The review system needs overhauling, and the need for introducing a less costly system of appeals is absolutely vital. Not a great deal more can be said about this. This is only a start. It is a step in the right direction and a lot more needs to be done. I would urge the government to move with haste in bringing these changes into effect so as to lessen the pain, suffering and anguish so many people feel at a particularly vulnerable period of their lives.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to offer my conditional—and I stress conditional—support for the Child Support Legislation Amendment Bill 1998 . I was here earlier when the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) made a suggestion that the government was supporting the Labor Party's child support formula, et cetera, and he made this observation on the basis that we were only `tinkering with the edges'. I suggest to you that the whole system is haemorrhaging. To suggest that we are fully supportive of it, quite frankly, is a nonsense. The problem, of course, is dollars and cents. It does cost a lot of money to deal with these issues and, unfortunately, given the position that we were left in, it is going to take some time to replenish the coffers to be able to give back to this the proper balance that is required.

speech.para: Having said that, the measures that are contained in this bill have been designed to introduce some flexibility into the child support scheme and reduce unnecessary bureaucratic intervention. As I said earlier, the measures certainly do not go far enough. They are just the first wave of reforms by this government—reforms that are becoming increasingly urgent, I might point out, as more families are drawn into the child support scheme at a tragically rapid rate.

My support for these reforms, as I have stated at all levels of debate on this issue, is given on the condition that a second wave of reform will follow very close behind, bringing fairer and more workable solutions to the enormous inequities in the child support scheme that is currently operating. A level of the problems out there could be demonstrated recently with the 60 Minutes program on problems within the child support system. It was reported at that time that it was one of the largest volumes of mail that they have received for any program. It shows that there are a lot of people out there sharing these concerns.

Since my election to the seat of Leichhardt in 1996, a significantly large and increasing number of constituent grievances received in my office have been associated with the child support scheme and the Child Support Agency. Problems relate to both the legislation governing child support and its administration. Grievances are received from both child support paying and child support receiving parents.

What most constituents complain about is the manner in which the system is administered and the problems subsequently caused by the shortcomings of this administration. It is a fact that many child support paying parents are living from hand to mouth. For them, life is mere existence. The enormous problems and obstacles child support parents face need to be recognised. Recent statistics provided by the Child Support Agency reveal that there are 7,587 child support payers and 4,920 child support payees in my electorate of Leichhardt. So the child support scheme invades the everyday lives of many thousands of my constituents and their families.

This bill will actively encourage parents to move away from the Child Support Agency into private collection agreements. This is designed to encourage parents to take greater responsibility for their child support arrangements. It will remove the bureaucracy from the lives of the payers, many of whom have contacted me and said they were completely disgusted that after many years of faithfully meeting their child support liability, they suddenly found their wages had been garnisheed and their tax refunds seized without any prior warning.

I should point out that you cannot entirely blame the bureaucracy for this. It is a very emotional issue. The first piece of advice that I give to anybody who comes into my office with a problem relating to these issues is that if they really want to get a fair and equitable solution, no matter how much they dislike their ex-partner they should sit down and talk to them. I advise that because anything that they can agree on is going to be infinitely better than anything that is going to be dictated to them by bureaucrats and by those who really do not have a real understanding of the situation. Unfortunately, there are very few who are able to do that, and as a consequence it is almost like a war zone out there.

For the first time ever there will be a minimum liability, an annual liability of $260 which has been applied to reinforce the principle that parents of the child have a primary duty to maintain that child and to share the costs of supporting that child. It will also be collected from recipients of social security benefits or pensions, and that is a great initiative. Irrespective of the amount of money, it is one way at least of acknowledging that there is some responsibility there, whatever the circumstance.

Under this bill the exempt income applicable to child support payers will be increased by 10 per cent to $9,907 for single payers and to $16,525 for payers caring for other children, plus additional amounts for each child for payers with natural or adopted children in their care.

This bill also introduces some flexibility by taking into account the paying parent's legal duty to maintain a stepchild. Payers with second families will now be able to claim 50 per cent of the child support payments as a deduction from household income used to determine eligibility for family payment and child-care assistance. Payers with second families have long been the poor relation of the child support scheme. Their child support liability often leaves them almost destitute and forces them to leave work to go on the dole because of the unfairness of the payments demanded of them.

An example brought to my office related to a constituent who had accrued a debt of $30,000. He was making payments directly to his ex-wife but the Child Support Agency had no details of these payments and his ex-wife denied receiving payments for child support. The Child Support Agency immediately garnisheed his wage and presented him with a bill for arrears of child support backdated to the date of his settlement in the Family Court. There were a number of reviews, the last one resulting in the advice that the review officer was unable to form a clear view as to what had happened in the past years. Therefore, the review officer declined to make any decision and my constituent's debt still stands.

He is remarried now and he is currently taking home one-third of his wages: one-third goes to child support payments, one-third to tax and one-third is left over to cover his daily expenses. As a result, his wife works 12 to 14 hours a day to help cover expenses. To add further stress to the situation, he has not seen his children for over two years. You would agree that this situation is far from conducive to a secure and happy marriage. There is no possibility of this couple considering having a family of their own at this stage as they simply cannot afford it.

This bill will enable child support assessments to be calculated using the most current taxable income available to each parent. Assessments are currently calculated according to a formula which uses taxable income from two years prior. Re-assessment based on income can only be requested where income drops by 15 per cent from that used for the initial assessment. Concern is frequently expressed about the accuracy of this assessment process. Measures contained in this bill should allow more accurate and timely assessment of the capacity of parents to pay child support. This bill will introduce significant reform in the area of objection and appeal rights.

A range of decisions, which are now only reviewable by the Family Court, will be subject to an internal review mechanism. It is hoped that this will improve perceptions of fairness, equity and the accountability of the Child Support Agency. Many instances are brought to my attention by paying parents where they have waited sometimes for months to have a review completed, then they receive notice that the review decision has gone against them. To add insult to injury, they then learn a decision can only be reviewed in the Family Court. This is often a last straw with limited access to legal aid and income already stretched to the limit with child support payments. They have no possibility of affording legal representation so they just accept the decision. It is just another body blow.

When I rose today I stressed that my support for the bill was conditional on further urgent reform to the child support scheme. The enormous distress and frustration suffered by parents when the system fails to work for them, and creates other difficulties as a result, does nothing for the betterment of the children involved and ultimately does a great disservice to the community in general. The child support paying parent has little relief under the current scheme. The fact is that these parents, too, need to set up a home, rebuild and stabilise their lives. The government must address ongoing reforms in the following areas.
Most of my constituents agree that some other type of formula is needed to arrive at a reasonable amount payable for child support—

para.inline: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

talk.start.para: —In view of the time, we will adjourn the Main Committee for today.
—I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

subdebateinfo.title: International Monetary Fund: Australian Economic Benefits
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2289)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 September 1997:

question.para: (1) Will there be benefits flowing to Australia and the Australian economy from decisions made at the annual meeting in September 1997 of the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the World Bank in Hong Kong; if so, what.
(2) What decisions were announced at the meeting with regard to the establishment of an Asian currency stability fund, and what involvement in the fund will the Australian Government have.
(3) Is he able to provide detail on progress made by the IMF to stabilise the Thai and other currencies in the region.
(4) Will the currency turmoil in Asia have any impact on Australian exports.
(5) What role is being played by Australia in dealing with currency stability in Thailand and Asia.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Decisions made at or in the context of the September 1997 IMF and World Bank annual meetings included a 45 per cent increase in IMF quotas, an allocation of Special Drawing Rights (SDRs) and an approximate doubling of the authorised capital of the Multilateral Investment Guarantee Agency (MIGA)

Quotas are the financial subscriptions made by member countries to the IMF. The agreement reached in September was formally adopted by the Board of Governors of the IMF in February 1998 and is currently awaiting ratification by members. The quota increase will expand the resources available to the IMF to fulfil its responsibilities including the provision of emergency assistance to members. Australia will benefit to the extent that IMF programs are able to be more effective in supporting the economic recovery of global and regional trading partners.

SDRs are financial assets created by the IMF and allocated to members to supplement their international reserves. The agreement reached for an SDR allocation of SDR21.4 billion will double the volume of SDRs on issue. Australia will receive SDR213.5 million, valued at about $A426.9 million, from the IMF as a result of this decision. Our international reserves will increase accordingly.

Agreement was also reached for a doubling of the capital of MIGA. MIGA provides political risk insurance and advisory services in relation to foreign investment in developing countries. Australia is in the process of finalising its membership of MIGA. Australia will benefit from the capital increase through the strengthening of MIGA's capacities to provide insurance and advisory services to Australian businesses investing in developing countries.

(2) The annual meetings did not make any decisions on the establishment of an Asian currency stability fund, but a meeting of officials to discuss a proposal for the establishment of an Asian monetary fund was held in Hong Kong at the time of the annual meetings. This meeting did not reach agreement. A further meeting of officials in Manila on 18- 19 November 1997 agreed on a new framework for enhanced Asian regional cooperation. This included a mechanism for regional surveillance to complement global surveillance by the IMF, enhanced economic and technical cooperation particularly in strengthening domestic financial systems and regulatory capacities, measures to strengthen the IMF's capacity to respond to financial crises, and a cooperative financing arrangement that would supplement IMF resources. This "Manila Framework" was endorsed by APEC Economic Leaders at their meeting in Vancouver on 25 November 1997 and by the ASEAN plus Six Finance Ministers meeting in Kuala Lumpur on 2 December 1997. Australia was represented at these meetings by the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, respectively.

(3) The governments of Thailand, Indonesia and the Republic of Korea have each agreed on reform programs with the IMF. Summaries of the programs are included in the latest edition of the Treasury Roundup. They include both macroeconomic and structural measures designed to restore market confidence.

Thailand and the Republic of Korea have both made good progress in implementing their programs and in reducing market turbulence. In Indonesia, less progress has been made and an IMF team is currently reviewing the program.

(4) The outlook for growth in many of Australia's trading partners in the East Asian region has weakened considerably in the face of financial market turbulence over the past six months and that is likely to have a negative impact on both the quantity and price of Australian exports to the region.

Most likely to be affected by the downturn are exports of manufactures and services (such as tourism and various business services), demand for which tends to be influenced by changes in incomes in countries of destination. Indicators of a decline in tourism credits have already emerged, with arrivals from Asia falling by 23.5 per cent through the year to December 1997.

Non-rural exports may also be affected by a downturn in world industrial production. However, the impact is more likely to be felt through lower prices than through lower export volumes. This is because export volumes of some non-rural commodities are more likely to be affected by domestic production than income levels in export markets.

Asia accounts for a large proportion of our rural exports and the world price of some rural commodities have fallen as a result of the slowdown in Asia. However, as with some non-rural commodities, volumes of a number of important rural exports, such as cereals, are largely determined by the quantity produced rather than movements in the income levels of export markets. In addition, for some rural commodities, such as beef, veal and sugar, supply difficulties elsewhere in the world may work to the advantage of Australian suppliers, despite a downturn in demand from East Asia.

The impact on growth in the Asian economies affected by instability will be reduced by the positive effects of depreciation of their currencies on their exports. This in turn provides export opportunities for countries such as Australia, whose exports feed into the production of Asian exports.

(5) Australia has been active in regional consultations at Ministerial and official level on the crisis, and through our representatives on the Executive Boards of the IMF, World Bank and Asian Development Bank.

Australia is participating in support arrangements for the IMF-supported programs for Thailand, Indonesia and Korea. Japan and Australia are the only countries in all three support arrangements. In each case, Australia's support is for up to $US1 billion.

Australia's support for Thailand is being provided through currency swaps between the Reserve Bank of Australia and the Bank of Thailand. The size and timing of the swaps are in parallel with the disbursements being made to Thailand by the IMF. A first swap of $US400 million was made on 12 September 1997, a second swap of $US200 million was made on 17 December 1997 and a third of $80 million on 13 March 1998.

The support arrangements for Korea and Indonesia are based on the Manila Framework and constitute a second line of defence which can be called upon in the event that unanticipated adverse external circumstances create the need for additional resources to those provided by the IMF and other international financial institutions. As at the end of February 1998, no funds have been transferred under these support arrangements.

On 25 December 1997, the bilateral supporters announced a willingness to activate up to $US8 billion (around a third) of the support funds for Korea in response to continuing market pressures and in conjunction with the announcement by the Korean Government of a revised adjustment program. With the subsequent improvement in market conditions, these funds have not so far been required.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice, upon notice, on 18 November 1997:

question.para: (1) Does Operation Mandrake monitor 1300 known paedophiles and approximately 400 additions each year.
(2) Is he able to say how many Australian Federal Police (AFP) officers are assigned to Operation Mandrake; if not, why not.
(3) Is it a fact that there is not one single full-time officer assigned to Operation Mandrake.
(4) Is it a fact that Operation Mandrake is managed by two part-time officers and one part-time staff member.
(5) Are the resources allocated by the Commonwealth to the AFP for the fight against paedophilia sufficient, if so, why.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) The AFP maintains an intelligence project codenamed `Mandrake' relating to paedophilia. The AFP investigates Australians involved in paedophile activities overseas and monitors in particular the overseas travel of those persons who are the subject of alerts. State/Territory police have the primary role in the investigation of paedophilia activities within Australia and the AFP provides information and international support on request.

As at 15 January 1998 the database contains 1854 names of which 330 are considered as potential offenders under the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Act. The rest are persons who, for a variety of reasons, have come to notice in relation to paedophilia. Some are convicted paedophiles, but the majority are suspects, to varying degrees.
On creation of the database in 1994, there were approximately 122 entries. In the last three years, entries have averaged 450 per annum.

It could, however, be misleading to draw inferences from these figures alone as to the scale of criminal paedophile activity. An assessment of the nature and scale of any criminal activity involves judgements drawn from a number of sources, of which statistics is only one.

(2) The AFP maintains a flexible workforce with a system of operational assessment which allows resources to be allocated according to priority. The AFP currently has nine people throughout Australia engaged in investigation and intelligence collection relating to paedophilia.
(4) No. See (2) above.
(5) I am satisfied that the AFP resources currently being allocated to the investigation of suspected paedophile activities meets Commonwealth responsibilities.

The Commonwealth Government, through the AFP, has responsibility for enforcement of the Crimes (Child Sex Tourism) Amendment Act 1994. This Act makes it an offence for Australians and permanent residents of Australia, to engage in child sex tourism overseas. The Act has extra-territorial powers and persons may be prosecuted for acts committed outside Australia.

The AFP, through its overseas liaison network and membership of Interpol, monitors overseas travel of persons suspected to be involved in paedophilia and also investigates the illegal use of the communications network (Internet) to transmit child pornography. This is carried out in close cooperation with State and Territory Police Services which carry the primary responsibility for investigating paedophile activity in Australia.

The Commonwealth Government remains concerned about Australians who engage in paedophile activity overseas and is working closely with other countries to discourage such activity. This includes encouraging countries to strengthen their laws and to give priority to the protection of children.

Australia has provided direct assistance to both Thailand and the Philippines in training of police officials to investigate sexual offences against children. Australia also recently entered into a Memorandum of Understanding with the Philippines to co-operate in the exchange of information relating to child sex activity.

subdebateinfo.title: Foundation for Survivors of Torture: Commonwealth Funding
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2671)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 2 March 1998:

question.para: Has the Commonwealth funded the Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture; if so, (a) under what category was the funding provided, (b) what tendering process was followed, (c) how many organisations applied for the funding, (d) did the Foundation receive additional funding for the purchase of major capital items such as vehicles; if so, under which funding round, (e) for what period has the funding been allocated under the service agreement between him and the Foundation, (f) what were the Foundation's client outcomes in 1996-97, (g) were the outcomes considered in the tendering process and (h) does the Foundation receive recurrent funding; if so, for how many positions.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Yes.

(a) The funding provided by the Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to the Victorian Foundation for Survivors of Torture (VFST) is under the Community Settlement Services Scheme (worker based) category.

(b) The VFST received funding through the standard grants process in accordance with the guidelines for the Community Settlement Services Scheme for worker positions and projects which fitted the priority categories of the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy as identified by the Government in its Budget Statement of May 1997.
(c) Six hundred and seventy organisations applied for funding in 1997-98.
(d) No.
(e) Funding was allocated for 1997-98 for twelve months commencing 1 October 1997.

(f) In 1996-97, the VFST provided services to 744 refugee and humanitarian entrants who have experienced some form of torture and trauma, mainly from Bosnia, Iraq and Somalia. These services included an early intervention program (assessment and counselling) for 511 clients placed in On Arrival Accommodation (OAA). One hundred clients were assessed as requiring short term counselling and 102 clients required medium to long term counselling. The VFST also works in collaboration with mainstream and specialist agencies to provide specialist health services and other generalist settlement services.
(g) Yes.
(h) The VFST was funded for 12 months from 1 October 1997 until 30 September 1998. Funding is sufficient for approximately ten positions.
